column9: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On June 23rd, striking security guards (likely from Insight security, and coded as such) demonstrated at the UN compound in Juba. Some of the demonstrators threw stones at what the source describes as two ""male national UN guards"", who were both injured and received medical treatment.[size=100]

On June 24th, an NGO vehicle travelling from Torit to Kapoeta was ambushed by unknown armed individuals at an unspecified location (coordinates for Kapoeta, Eastern Equatoria, used at prec2). The aid workers were robbed, with at least one aid worker (possibly more) assaulted.
On June 24th, an unidentified armed group attacked and wounded a civilian at an unspecified location in Abiemnom county (Unity state, coordinates used at prec2).
On June 24th, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed an off-duty police officer, as he travelled to Bang Bang (Unity state, approximate coordinates used, based on humanitarian map).

On June 25th, fighting between Thorny, Muok, Yar and Apuk-Juwiir communities (coded as Tonj communal militias) clashed at an unspecified location in Mayangok county in the disputed Tonj state (coordinates for Dirdi, Warrap state, used at prec2), killing 15 (some of whom were likely civilians), and seizing approx. 3,000 head of cattle.

On June 25th, SSPDF soldiers were reported to have attacked SSOA forces at Mogoroko village (Western Equatoria state, coordinates for Zumb used at precision 2). Two brothers of a rebel commander were killed (note: event coded as armed clash with actor2 SSOA, on the assumption that the relatives of the SSOA commander were rebels).

column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column16: Gurtong Trust; Aid Worker Security Database; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On June 26th, armed raiders (suspected, but not confirmed, of coming from Wan-Alel, and coded as Tonj militia) attacked Akucheng cattle camp in Mayangok county (Warrap state, coordinates for Dirdi used at prec2), killing four, including the paramount chief of the Padek section of the Rek Dinka, as well as a South Sudanese aid worker. The group then stole six cows.

On June 26th, two Agaar Dinka sections (the Gony and Thuyic) clashed in the area of Alou cattle camp in Western Bahr Naam county (Lakes state, coordinates for Naam used at precision 2). Three Thuyic Dinka were killed during the attack, whilst one Gony raider died later. Six were wounded.

On June 30th, unknown gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying 12 passengers, wounding five. The event took place at an undisclosed location on the road between Nhialdiu (Unity state, coordinates used) and Bentiu. SPLM-IO elements were blamed for the attack; a spokesman said they do not have troops in the area.

On July 1st, raiders from Yirol in the disputed Eastern Lakes state attacked an unspecified location in Paloich county (Lakes state, coordinates for Paloich used at prec2). Four people were killed (including two of the attackers), and between one and three were wounded. 17 cattle were stolen.

At an unspecified time (implied to be early July) a group of armed men abducted six students at an unspecified location in or near Bahr Grinti county (coordinates for Kondoagoi used at prec2). Police later rescued the students.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: At an unspecified time (though implied to be early July) the SPLM-IO were alleged to have abducted three women who reported their husbands had joined the NAS rebellion. The event occurred at an unspecified place in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria), and has been denied by the SPLM-IO.

On July 4th, a police officer was shot dead by gunmen in the Ringasi area (Western Equatoria state). A local government official claimed the gunmen belonged to the SSNMC rebel group, which has been refuted by the SSNMC, who say they do not have troops in the area (actor1 coded as UAG pending further information).

On July 5th, armed youth from the disputed Western Lakes state attacked Alel village in the disputed Gok state (Lakes state, coordinates for Abiriu used at prec2). 7 were killed during the ensuing clashes (four from Gok state, and three from Western Lakes), and three from Gok were wounded. The attack was in retaliation to an earlier cattle raid.

On July 6th, attackers abducted two children at Loulang (Eastern Equatoria state). Local authorities have accused Murle raiders from the disputed Boma state of being responsible for the abductions, which has been denied by Boma authorities (actor1 provisionally coded as Murle Ethnic Militia).

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya; Daily Monitor (Uganda)
column17: On July 9th, unknown gunmen attacked a passenger vehicle in Aswa (one reports says Orobe) village (Eastern Equatoria), killing one South Sudanese and one Uganda civilian.

On July 9th, gunmen (accused of being from Eastern Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked and killed a local government official at an unspecified location in or near Bahr Grinti county (Western Equatoria, coordinates for Kondaogoi used at precision).

On July 10th, attackers abducted a child at Lofiriha (Eastern Equatoria state, approximate coordinates based on IOM map used at prec2). Local authorities have accused Murle raiders from the disputed Boma state of being responsible for the abductions, which has been denied by Boma authorities (actor1 provisionally coded as Murle Ethnic Militia).

On or around July 14th, unknown raiders attacked an unspecified location in Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), stealing 46 head of cattle. The source implies that a gunfight ensued as they raided fired upon the raiders (actor 2 coded as Wau militia). There are no reports of injuries.

On July 14th, armed men shot and killed a man as he chopped firewood near Baidit (Jonglei state). The assailants also stole the victim's gun (coded as a civilian as no indication of affiliation to armed group or attempted use of weapon during attack).

On July 15th or 16th, raiders attacked Maal Kheer cattle camp (Unity state, coordinates for Maal are approximate based on UNICEF map), killing five (including two children), and stealing over 1,200 head of cattle. The governor of the disputed Southern Liech accused the raiders of coming from Tonj; the Tonj governor accused the raiders of coming from Lakes state (actor1 coded as UCM).

On July 15th, attackers (believed to be from the Jagei clan, and coded as such) ambushed a group of civilians at an unspecified location along the Nhialdiu road (Unity state, coordinates for Nhialdiu used at prec2), killing four and wounding seven. The incident was reported to be a revenge attack.

During the month of July, an unknown group (coded as Torit East communal militia) attacked and killed two civilians along the road between Torit and the Imatong mountains (Eastern Equatoria state; coordinates for Oguruny used at prec2). 12 suspects were arrested in Haforiere in Tori East.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column7: Gajaak-Eastern Jikany Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2019 (month of), SPLM-IO forces under the command of Maj. Gen James Ochan recruited 1,800 soldiers (including some children, and involving some forcible recruitment) from the Cie-Waw sub-section of the Gajaak Nuer section of the Eastern Jikany Nuer, in advance of a showdown with a rival commander. 1,000 of the soldiers came from Maiwut town (Upper Nile state), and the remainder from villages in the area.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Petroleum Protection Force
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On July 16th, four members of the SSPDF Petroleum Protection Force were abducted by SPLM-IO rebels at an unspecified location between Guffa and Keweji (Upper Nile state, coordinates for Guffa used at prec2). The SPLM-IO denies abducting any soldiers.
On or after July 17th, a man was killed by unknown attackers near Idolu Bridge as he walked from Haforiere village (Eastern Equatoria state, coordinates for Idolu Bridge used at prec2).

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column16: Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On July 17th, police and NSS agents engaged in heavy fighting with each other in two markets in Tonj (Warrap state). Conflicting reports as to the number injured have emerged (between 2 and 4 police, up to 4 NSS, and up to 2 civilians). 7 have been arrested, though the reason behind the clashes is unclear.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Petroleum Protection Force
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or around July 17th, SSPDF Petroleum Protection Force personnel abducted three SPLM-IO rebels at an unspecified area at or near Guffa or Keweji (Upper Nile state, coordinates for Guffa used at prec2), in retaliation for the alleged abduction of four of their own by IO elements on July 16th. The three IO rebels were released on July 31st.

column6: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On July 17th, several sections of the Dinka Rek clashed at an unspecified location in Thiik county (Warrap state, coordinates for Ngabagok used at prec2), killing 23.

On July 18th, an armed group ambushed and killed a man near Kotalo (Jonglei state, no geographic information found, coordinates for Ayod used at prec2). The attack was reportedly a retaliatory attack linked to sectional fighting in the disputed Bieh state (actor1 coded as Bieh Communal Militia).

On July 18th, Thuyic Dinka youth attacked Gony Dinka youth (both of the Agar Dinka clan, and coded as such) at an unspecified area in Western Bahr Naam county (Lakes state, coordinates for Naam used at precision 2). One member of the Gony Dinka youth was killed.

On or before July 19th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern Liech state, and coded as such) attacked an unspecified area in Akop county (Warrap state, coordinates for Akop used at prec2), killing three, and looting between 100-1000 head of cattle.

On July 22nd, two Agaar Dinka sections (the Gony and Thuyic) clashed at an unspecified location in Western Bahr Naam county (Lakes state, coordinates for Naam used at precision 2). Eleven were killed, and up to four injured. The event was in retaliation for an earlier attack against the Gony Dinka.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column16: Sudan Tribune; Gurtong Trust; Radio Miraya; CTSAMM
column17: On July 23rd (some reports say 22nd and 23rd), NAS rebels clashed with government forces (since clarified as being NSS agents, and coded as such) at Karpeto near Lobonok (Central Equatoria). Although initial reports suggested the clashes related to control of a mining area, and that 8-13 people were killed, subsequent reports suggest there were no fatalities, nor any known cause.
On July 25th, gunmen shot and wounded two youths at Sanjasiri (Central Equatoria state).
On July 27th, gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle at Logboronga (Central Equatoria state, coordinates for Yei used at prec2). There is no further information.

column16: Radio Miraya; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On July 27th, an armed group ambushed vehicles at Payawa (Central Equatoria state). Three civilians were abducted (two Ugandans, and a South Sudanese), and three South Sudanese were wounded on the spot. The bodies of the two Ugandans were found two days later. Local authorities blamed NAS rebels; NAS rebels denied involvement (though has launched an investigation), and implied that government forces or paramilitaries were responsible. Actor1 coded as UAG pending further information.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 29 July 2019, a former local government minister from Eastern Lakes state survived an attempted assassination attempt by SSPDF Military Intelligence personnel at a hotel in Juba. The individual was taken to Giyada (a barracks in central Juba) and detained without release (as of late April 2020), and has likely been tortured along with numerous others who have been abducted (seemingly for extortion purposes) in the barracks since early 2019.

On July 31st, and following a clash at an unspecified location in the Paya hills close to Karpeto and Umo (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Umo used at prec2) an SSPDF soldier shot dead a civilian, after the civilian refused to carry the body of a slain soldier killed by NAS rebels that same day.

On July 31st, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF soldiers at an unspecified location in the Paya mountains close to Karpeto and Umo (coordinates for Umo, Central Equatoria, used at prec2). One SSPDF soldier was killed, and around 1,000 civilian households fled the area.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 July 2019, SPLM-IO forces associated with two rival commanders clashed in Maiwut (Upper Nile state), with the attacking forces repulsed by IO forces operating alongside Ciee-Waw militiamen (coded as Eastern Jikany Nuer militia). Unspecified number of fatalities reported, coded as ten, as well as sexual violence, and large numbers of the population were displaced by repeated fighting.

During the week beginning 29th July, armed youth attacked the area of Kanhial in Panyijiar county (Unity state, coordinates used at prec2), killing three (including a child) and stealing 830 head of cattle. The SPLM-IO commissioner of the county blamed authorities in the disputed Southern Liech state of arming local youth, which has been denied by a government official.

On August 1st, armed men (allegedly of the NAS rebellion, and coded as such pending further information) clashed with SSPDF soldiers in Kicak village (Eastern Equatoria; no geographic information found, coordinates for Torit used at prec2). Two civilians were killed in the fighting, and the village was burned, causing civilians to flee.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column9: Gajaak-Eastern Jikany Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 August 2019, SPLM-IO forces associated with two rival commanders clashed in Maiwut (Upper Nile state), with the attacking forces taking the town from IO forces operating alongside Ciee-Waw militiamen from the Gajaak sub clan of the Eastern Jikany Nuer. An unspecified number of fatalities occurred, as well as sexual violence (14 women and 8 girls were pared across this event and the event on 1 August), and large numbers of the population were displaced by repeated fighting. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

At an unspecified time following a disarmament sweep beginning July 24th (event coded as August 1st at time prec3), security forces (coded as army) killed six civilians for resisting disaramament, at an unspecified location in the disputed Western Lakes state (coordinates for Rumbek, Lakes, used at prec2).

Between July and September, the governor of the disputed Kapoeta state announced that violence and revenge killings between the Boya and Toposa ethnic groups had occurred in Kapoeta state, resulting with eight killed and one injured. The event coded at time prec3.

On August 2nd or 4th, NAS rebels accused government forces of shelling an unspecified village in the Lowi hills (Eastern Equatoria; no geographic information found on Lowi hills, coordinates for Torit used at prec3), killing two civilians and wounding three others.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column9: Gajaak-Eastern Jikany Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 6 August 2019, SPLM-IO forces associated with two rival commanders once again clashed in Maiwut (Upper Nile state), with the town being retaken by IO forces operating alongside Ciee-Waw militiamen from the Gajaak sub clan of the Eastern Jikany Nuer who were dislodged on August 1. An unspecified number of fatalities occurred, as well as sexual violence (14 women and 8 girls were raped across this event and the event on 1 August), and large numbers of the population were displaced by repeated fighting. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.
On August 6th, a teacher was killed by unknown gunmen in Cueibet town (Lakes state), in what is described as a revenge attack.

On August 6th, attackers abducted three children at Lowoi (Eastern Equatoria state). Local authorities have accused Murle raiders from the disputed Boma state of being responsible for the abductions, which has been denied by Boma authorities (actor1 provisionally coded as Murle Ethnic Militia).
On August 6th, an unknown gunman fired upon a crowd of mourners at Akor-kor Rok (Lakes state), killing two. There is no further information.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column7: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On or after 6 August 2019, SPLM-IO forces aligned to one of the rival commander fighting in Maiwut - operating alongside Ciee-Waw militiamen (coded as Eastern Jikany Nuer militia) - burned down the town of Turow (Upper Nile state) in retaliation for a prior seizure of Maiwut by a commander stationed in the area. Unspecified numbers (likely to be civilians belonging to a different section of the Eastern Jikany Nuer) were killed (10 fatalities coded), alongside sexual violence and looting.

On August 7th, armed men (wearing military uniforms, and accordingly coded as army) attacked a commercial vehicle in the area of Bangachorot (Lakes state, approximate coordinates based on REACH humanitarian map used at prec2) as it travelled to Bor. The driver and a passenger were killed, and another passenger was seriously wounded. The attackers then looted the vehicle. Note: a police official suggested the attackers were rebels.

On August 7th, police arrested two men accused of witchcraft, beating both and arresting one of the men, who later died in police custody following repeated beatings at a temporary police post 3km south of Yambio (Western Equatoria, coordinates for Yambio used at prec2). Three police officers have been arrested.

On August 8th, a pastoralist was killed at an unspecified location between Duk Pagak county and Ayod town (Jonglei state, coordinates for Pagak used at prec2). There is no information on the attackers.

On August 8th, eight cattle traders were attacked at an unspecified location between Poktap and Duk Padiet (Jonglei state, coordinates for Poktap used at prec2), killing one. The surviving traders alleged that the attackers were from the disputed Fangak state.
On August 8th, security forces (coded here as SSPDF) clashed with cattle raiders (allegedly from the disputed Gok state, and coded as such) in Abeer (Lakes state), killing one raider.
On or before August 12th, unidentified attackers killed 12 civilians and wounded 5, at an unspecified location close to Juba along the Juba-Bor road.

On August 12th, men in military uniforms (and coded as SSPDF) attacked three men at an unspecified location between Roc Roc Dong (Western Bahr el Ghazal state, approximate coordinates based on IOM map used at prec2) and Manaloor, killing two (who were brothers).

On or before August 12th, unidentified attackers killed 13 civilians (including a child) and wounded 7, at an unspecified location in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (Lakes state, coordinates for Yirol used at prec3). The assailants looted cattle.

During the month of August 2019, a skirmish between unspecified armed forces (coded as SSPDF and NAS, given their activity in the area at the time) one kilometre west of Landili (Western Equatoria state, coordinates for Bingo used at prec2) killed one, and injured two civilians, one of whom was a 2 year-old child.

During the month of August, unidentified raiders attacked a cattle camp in Ger county in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (coordinates for Ramayang, Lakes state, used at prec2), killing two and stealing 15 head of cattle.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: During the month of August 2019, the NSS began training around 10,000 recruits at Yithkuel in Tonj South (Warrap state, coordinates for Tonj used at prec2). The recruits comprised both voluntary and forcibly recruited individuals (including some children) and some army deserters, who had been recruited in the disputed Tonj, Twic and Gogrial states.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On August 15th, unknown gunmen killed an NSS officer (implied to be off-duty) in a residential area of Torit (Eastern Equatoria state).
On August 16th, SS-UF rebels attacked SSPDF soldiers at War Ayen (Northern Bahr el Gahzal state). Reports suggest fatalities occurred, but do not specify how many (3 fatalities coded).

column9: Misseriya Ethnic Group (Sudan); Civilians (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On August 17th, gunmen attacked Sudanese Misseriya traders (alongside Nuer traders, of unspeicifed nationality, coded as South Sudanese civilians) in between Kaikang and Daira in Mayom county (Unity state, coordinates for Kaikang used at prec2). 12 civilians were killed (one of whom was South Sudanese) with another dying of gunshot wounds on Aug 19th. An unspecified number were injured, and a large amount of money was stolen. The survivors alleged that South Sudanese soldiers were responsible for the attack, and actor1 has been coded as such.

On August 17th, gunmen (suspected of being raiders from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) attacked a cattle camp in the area of Akwai-Deng in Athooc county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Yuai used at prec2), killing an elderly woman and a young child.
On August 17th, SSPDF alleged that they were attacked by NAS rebels at Jambo, Western Equatoria, resulting in three SSPDF injuries between this incident and a related clash in Lainya the same day.

On August 17th, NAS rebels and government soldiers clashed at Lainya, Central Equatoria with both sides accusing the other of initiating the attack. The SSPDF spokesman said three soldiers were injured between this attack and another in Jambo the same day with no fatalities reported, whilst the NAS claimed that at least 8 SSPDF were killed at Lainya (no fatalities coded).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On August 17th, gunmen (accused of being SPLM-I and coded as such) attacked the county commissioner's house at Tambura (Western Equatoria state), and engaged in a gunfight with his bodyguards. One bodyguard was wounded. SSPDF arrived after 15 mins, prompting the attackers to flee.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 18 August 2019, an NGO worker was attacked by men in NSS uniforms (and coded as such) at an illegal checkpoint in Juba, who shot him in the leg after pulling him from his vehicle. The victim was then detained and robbed.

On August 20th, gunmen shot and wounded a boda boda (motorcycle taxi) driver at an unspecified location along the road between the disputed Western Lakes and Gok states (coordinates for Rumbek, Lakes state, used at prec2).

On 21 August 2019, NAS rebels ambushed 8 SSPDF soldiers moving supplies between baracks near Loka West (Lainya county, Central Equatoriastate ). The rebels claimed to have killed 20 soldiers, although the information in CTSAMM reporting indicates that 1 SSPDF soldiers was killed and 6 were injured. The report notes that it is unclear whether there were NAS casualties or fatalities.

On or before August 21st, South Sudan United Front forces clashed with SSPDF in disputed circumstances at Wathok (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state). Reports indicate that one senior rebel commander was killed with a total of 5 fatalities resulting from the clash. Another commander captured along with other rebels were captured.

On August 21st, a passenger vehicle was attacked on a road coming out of Ye, killing two (one of whom was a foreigner) and wounding one. SSPDF have blamed NAS rebels for the attack (NAS provisionally coded as actor1).

On August 21st, NAS rebels alleged that SSPDF once again attacked their positions in (or near) Loka West (Central Equatoria). The rebels claimed to have killed 20 soldiers, and caused SSPDF to retreat.

On August 24th, six armed youth from Western Lakes attacked the Eastern Bahr Naam county HQ at Aduel, Lakes killing a soldier and member of the 'community police' and wounding a police officer and a student. One person has since been arrested.
On August 24th or 25th, a bus was attacked in the area of Buaji, Western Equatoria by an unknown group, who killed the driver and conductor, and wounded a passenger.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On August 25th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Fangak state) attacked an unspecified location in Duk Pagak county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Pagak used at prec2), killing a prison guard in the cattle raid (coded as VAC/attack, with actor 2 as civilians and AssocActor2 Prison Guards).

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before August 25th, an SPLM-IO prison officer was killed by unknown gunmen near Mandeng (Upper Nile state) (circumstances unclear- event coded as VAC/Attack, with civilians as actor2 and SPLM-IO as AssocActor2).

On August 26th, gunmen killed a woman and abducted one of her sons near Lolere bridge, Eastern Equatoria. Local authorities have accused Murle raiders from the disputed Boma state of being responsible for the abductions, which has been denied by Boma authorities (actor1 provisionally coded as Murle Ethnic Militia).

On August 27th, SSUF rebels attacked an SSPDF base at Khor Shamam, Western Bahr el Ghazal. ~Reports suggest that 3 government soldiers and 5 rebels were killed in the fighting, and 18 rebels (including a deputy commander) were captured.
On August 27th, SSUF allegedly abducted three farmers on the outskirts of Raja, Western Bahr el Ghazal following clashes between SSUF rebels and SSPDF that same day.
On August 27th, civilians were ambushed by an unspecified group between Ombasi and Mongo. Several civilians were injured in the attack.

From August 27th-30th, around 160 SSUF/A rebels attacked an SSPDF base in Dako (Western Bahr el Ghazal, coordinates for Khor Dako used at prec2). SSPDF reported to CTSAMM that the attackers were weak, and that 88 surrendered or were captured (inc. 16 children), several wounded, and 5 killed (fatalities spread across 3 events).

On August 27th, raiders (suspected of being from the disputed Southern Liech) killed an elderly man and robbed eight cows at an unspecified location in Rubkway county (Unity state, coordinates for Methiang used at prec2).
On August 27th, SSPDF attacked SSUF rebels at an area implied to be close to Khor Shamam, Western Bahr el Ghazal killing 2 rebels and capturing 16.

From August 27th-30th, around 160 SSUF/A rebels attacked an SSPDF base in Dako (Western Bahr el Ghazal, coordinates for Khor Dako used at prec2). SSPDF reported to CTSAMM that the attackers were weak, and that 88 surrendered or were captured (inc. 16 children), several wounded, and 5 killed (fatalities spread across 3 events).

column6: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On August 29th, two sections of the Pakam Dinka (Aniin and Niel-niel sections) clashed at Jalla cattle camp (Lakes state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Rumbek used at prec2). Two were killed, and one injured. The cause of the clash was a dispute over a bull.

From August 27th-30th, around 160 SSUF/A rebels attacked an SSPDF base in Dako (Western Bahr el Ghazal, coordinates for Khor Dako used at prec2). SSPDF reported to CTSAMM that the attackers were weak, and that 88 surrendered or were captured (inc. 16 children), several wounded, and 5 killed (fatalities spread across 3 events).

On August 30th, a Somali fuel driver was shot dead by unknown gunmen 3 km outside of Nesitu, Eastern Equatoria. The killing prompted a five day strike by truck drivers of various nationalities on the Ugandan side of the border.

column6: USSOM: United South Sudan Opposition Movements
column8: SSNDA: South Sudan National Democratic Alliance
column9: SS-UF: South Sudan-United Front; R-SPLM: Real Sudan People's Liberation Movement; NDM: National Democratic Movement
column17: On August 30th, several rebel groups and former politicians announced the formation of the United South Sudan Opposition Movements after a meeting in the Netherlands. Notable members include Paul Malong's SSUF; the SSNDA umbrella group (led by Thomas Cirillo); and two prominent SPLM-FD's (Lt Gen Oyai Deng Ajak and Pagan Amum). Pagan Amum also announced the formation of a new political party called Real SPLM. At this stage it is in unclear as to the degree of coordination in the coalition.

On August 31st, armed youth (coded as Western Lakes militia) attacked two villages at Adol and Neemthok, Lakes. The attackers raped a woman at each location, and looted the villages. Two events coded at geoprecision 2 using Aduel and Leik as locations.

On August 31st, armed youth accused of being involved in an attack on August 24th at Aduel (and accordingly coded as Western Lakes militia) attacked two villages at Adol and Neemthok (Lakes state, two events coded at geoprecision 2 using Aduel and Leik as locations). The attackers raped a woman at each location, and looted the villages.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On August 31st, SSPDF who were taking cattle to Cueibet (n.b. the cattle were a blood payment for a recent killing) were attacked in the Gulek area near Good Lake cattle camp (Lakes state, coordinates for Cueibet used at prec2). In the clash, eight soldiers were killed and one injured (one source says nine were killed), whilst two of the attackers (coded as communal militia from the disputed Gok state) were killed (10 fatalities total coded).

On September 1st and 2nd, clashes broke out between the communities of Thiik, Akok and Jalwaau villages in Tonj East county (Warrap state, coordinates for Akok used at prec2), killing 31 and wounding over 70 (fatalities distributed across two events).

On September 1st, a truck (belonging to Lt. Gen Pieng Deng) was fired upon by unknown gunmen 1km away from a security checkpoint, in the area of Abeer (Lakes state). The windscreen was shattered, but no one was injured.

According to a report of September 18, since mid-August 2019, there were at least five incidents of attacks against civilians (including sexual violence, robbery, and beatings, including against international aid workers) by armed men at checkpoints in Juba (coded as military, pending further information). One event coded at time prec3, with AssocActor2 coded as women and aid workers.

On September 1st and 2nd, clashes broke out between the communities of Thiik, Akok and Jalwaau villages in Tonj East county (Warrap state, coordinates for Akok used at prec2), killing 31 and wounding over 70 (fatalities distributed across two events; actors coded as Thiik and Tonj East communal militias).
On or before September 3rd, health workers protested at the lack of full remuneration at Wau teaching hospital, Western Bahr el Ghazal. [size=no report]

column8: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On September 3rd, IDPs (largely comprising women and children) gathered in the UN PoC site in Juba, in a bid to stop UN Police from arresting men involved in rebel activities. A clash between demonstrators and UN Police was reported, which reportedly led to UN Police withdrawing. [size=hundreds]
On September 3rd, SSPDF clashed with SS-UF rebels near Deleba, Western Bahr el Ghazal (coordinates are approximate). Government forces claimed to have captured 55 rebels (including a Brig. Gen).

On September 4th, NAS rebels allegedly abducted three civilians at an unspecified area in Mukaya county (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Mukaya used at prec2). The NAS has denied being involved in the abductions.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune
column17: On 4 and/or 5 September 4th, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF (and an unspecified militia, coded as Yei communal militia) attacked their positions at Bereka (Central Equatoria state), and that that NAS rebels then proceeded to overrun the SSPDF positions at Bereka (Central Equatoria). NAS claimed 25 SSPDF were killed and 5 rebels wounded in this and other fighting in the nearby area, but the SSPDF have claimed there were no fatalities, and the clashes related to ownership of a mine (no fatalities recorded).

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column16: Sudan Tribune; CTSAMM; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 5 September 2019, NAS rebels attacked an SSPDF barracks at Lorega (in Mukaya payam) and the nearby Mukaya administrative HQ (Central Equatoria state, one event coded at geoprec2 using location of Mukaya). Three soldiers and a major in the prison service were killed; three civilian abducted (two children and the mother of one child); and looting occurred.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On September 4th and/or 5th, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF (and an unspecified militia, coded as Yei communal militia) attacked their positions but were repulsed, and that that NAS rebels then proceeded to overrun SSPDF positions at Mukaya and Bereka (both Central Equatoria, two events coded at timeprec2). NAS claimed 25 SSPDF were killed and 5 rebels wounded, but the SSPDF have claimed there were no fatalities, and the clashes related to ownership of a mine (no fatalities recorded).

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On September 4th and/or 5th, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF (and suspected Yei communal militia) attacked their positions but were repulsed, and that that NAS rebels then proceeded to overrun SSPDF positions at Mukaya and Bereka (both Central Equatoria, two events coded at timeprec2). NAS claimed 25 SSPDF were killed and 5 rebels wounded, but the SSPDF have claimed there were no fatalities, and the clashes related to ownership of a mine (no fatalities recorded).

On September 6th, NAS rebels claimed to have ambushed SSPDF soldiers (and suspected Yei militia) at an unspecified location along the Maridi-Yei road (coordinates for Tore, Central Equatoria, used at prec2), killing 16 and wounding 13.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 6th, NAS rebels alleged that SPLM-IO troops looted and ""tortured"" the residents in the area of Mangalla (Central Equatoria), following fighting between the two rebel groups earlier that day.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 6th, NAS rebels claimed that they repulsed an attack by SPLM-IO rebels near Mangalla (Central Equatoria). There are no reports of casualties.
On September 7th, around 35 armed suspected Tonj attacked 8 cattle traders at an unspecified location in Aguka payam (Warrap state), killing four. 76 head of cattle were also stolen.
On September 8th, SSPDF clashes with suspected NAS rebels in Logo (Central Equatoria). Over 200 civilians were displaced in the fighting, but there are no reports regarding casualties.
On September 8th, unknown gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle travelling between Juba and Rumbek, wounding two passengers. The attack occurred near Aduel (Lakes state).

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On September 8th or 9th, NAS rebels clashed with SSPDF at the Lorogo (or Lofugo) area (Central Equatoria, no geographic information found, coordinates for Lainya used at prec2 given recent NAS and SSPDF clashes in and around the area). Four government soldiers (one of whom was reported to work for the Prison Service) were killed.

On September 9th, gelweng (cattle guards) from the disputed Eastern Lakes state (coded as Eastern Lakes militia) killed three civilians at Kindilo close to the border between the the disputed Eastern Lakes and Terekeka states near Tali. The killings were in retaliation for an earlier raid by a Mundari militia from the same area.
On September 10th, NAS rebels accused SSPDF and unspecified allied militias (coded as Yei militia) of attacking their positions near Lasu (Central Equatoria). There is no information on casualties.

On September 11th, armed youth (suspected of coming from the disputed Eastern Lakes state, and coded as such) killed three civilians who were pursuing cattle raiders from Terekeka. The event occurred at an unspecified location between Tindalo (coordinates used) and Dwor (Central Equatoria).
On September 11th, armed youth (coded as Western Lakes militia) killed an off-duty SSPDF sergant at Mathiang Abuoi (Lakes state, coordinates for Naam used at prec2).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 11th, the SPLM-IO announced it was relocating its headquarters to Juba, from the IO-established 'Pow state'. The move follows two days of talks between rebel leader Dr Riek Machar and President Kiir in Juba, where the two men agreed to set up a committee to break the impass on the number of states in South Sudan.
On September 11th, SSPDF and local militia clashed with NAS rebels in the area of Tore (Central Equatoria state). Fatalities unknown but scores have been displaced.
On September 12th, an unspecified armed group carried out ambushes and abductions in the areas of Mambe and Kerika (Western Equatoria, two events recorded). There is no further information.
On September 12th, an unspecified armed group carried out ambushes and abductions in Mamber and Karika (Western Equatoria, two events recorded). There is no further information.

On September 12th, SSPDF clashed with """"armed civilians"""" (coded as UCM) in the area of Wut-Beel (Warrap state, coordinates for Wun Lit used at precision 2). Three civilians were wounded in the crossfire.
14 September. In Jalle cattle camp, two armed pastoralist groups clashed. Two fatalities.
17 September. An unknown armed group has abducted 17 people in Marini state. Motive unknown.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column17: On 17 September 2019, a woman was raped at Gumbo (Juba county, Central Equatoria state) by two men, one of whom was a Military Intelligence officer with the SSPDF Tiger Division. The two men had posed as NSS agents. The Tiger Division officer was arrested, and has been linked to other cases of sexual assault as well as robbery.

On or around September 17th, armed youth (alledgely from the disputed Gok state and coded as such) ambushed three people on the road between Maker-Padeek and Akuc-Chieng (Warrap state, coordinates for Tonj used at prec2). The rider and a female passenger were shot, and another passenger was beaten on the head.

column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column17: On September 18th, SSPDF (including Tiger Divsion soldiers) clashed with an armed youth group in Malek Agok (Lakes state). One soldier was killed and one Tiger Division soldier seriously wonded, whilst one armed youth (coded as Western Lakes militia) was killed, and two wounded.
20 September. An unknown armed group has abducted and tortured about 13 people while they were going to Morsak. Motive unknown.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column7: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On September 20th, a senior IO commander (Major General James Ochan Puot) broke away from the IO along with several other IO elites (with more defecting on Sep 25th) following clashes between Cie-waw branch of the Eastern Jikany Nuer and the IO in Maiwut. He has announced his intention to align with the government, and arrived in Juba with 22 others on October 2nd.
21 September. Unknown armed people killed two civilians in Abegi. One of the people killed was a community health worker and the other was a motorcycle operator. Motive unknown.
22 September. In Wau, a woman was raped and killed by unknown people.
On September 22nd, armed youth (coded as Western Lakes militia) shot and wounded two women at an unspecified location in Western Bahr Naam county (Lakes state, coordinates for Naam used at prec2).
22 September. In Yirol, 11 people were killed and 14 wounded in South Sudan on Sunday during tribal clashes over a contested land between the Nuer and Dinka clans.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On September 23rd, four SSOA officers were allegedly abducted by SPLM-IO elements in Akobo (Jonglei state), and ""deported"" to Gambella in Ethiopia.

column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division; Unidentified Armed Group (South Sudan)
column17: On September 26th, six attackers (two soldiers (one Tiger Division), and four gang members (coded as UAG)) raped a woman in Juba (Central Equatoria), who died the following day. The six have been arrested.

On 27 September 2019, four village elders were abducted from Mukaya (Central Equatoria) by NAS rebels. Two escaped; the whereabouts of the other two is unknown. Rebels also looted livestocks and property. Escapees identified a prominent local commander as being involved in the attack.

On September 30th, two unknown gunmen fired upon the house of senior military commander Lt. Gen. Malual Ayom Dor (who was not in the residence at the time) in Juba, killing his security guard right after they robbed the lieutenant's nephew outside of the house.

During the week beginning September 30th, unknown raiders (coded as UCM) attacked an unspecified cattle camp in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (coordinates for Payii, Lakes state, used at prec2), killing two.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 7th, SPLM-IO forces arrived at Luri (Central Equatoria), to begin training for the 3,000 strong VIP protection force along with SSPDF soldiers. This follows from earlier movements of opposition forces to cantonment sites across South Sudan beginning late July.

On October 9th, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Western Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked pastoralists at an unspecified location on the Yirol-Aluakluak road (on the side of the disputed Eastern Lakes state, coordinates for Wunapout (Lakes state) used at prec2), killing him and stealing nine animals.

On October 10th, a police officer kicked a 16 year-old student to death, after the student, who was working as a seller to support his studies, refused to sell him confectionary at a discounted rate. The incident occurred in Rumbek (Lakes state), and is being investigated by police.

column9: Christian Group (South Sudan); Labour Group (South Sudan)
column17: On October 11th, NAS rebels allegedly abducted a chief, a pastor, and a businessman from the village of Yondoru (Central Equatoria). The rebels have denied being behind abductions in the area.
On October 11th, NAS rebels allegedly abducted a chief from the village of Dimo (Central Equatoria). The rebels have denied being behind abductions in the area.

On October 13th, an off-duty, unarmed police officer (coded as civilian, with police as assoc actor2) was killed by unknown assailants outside of his house in Bor (Jonglei state). The victim was killed with a stick.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 14th, SPLM-IO soldiers killed a businessman in Maper village near Thar Jaath (Unity state). There is no further information.

During the month of October 2019, UPDF were reported to have been deployed at an unspecified location in the disputed Yei Rivers state (coordinates for Yei, Central Equatoria, used at prec2). The deployment is in violation of the peace agreement.

column15: UN House/UN Protection of Civilians Site
column17: On October 15th, a pastoralist militia shot two IDP youths outside of the UN PoC site at UN House (Central Equatoria state), killing one and wounding the other. The incident relates to a dispute over the harassment of women, though the details are unclear.

At unspecified times between early/mid September and early/mid December 2019, NAS forces were reported to have attacked SSPDF barracks at Lasu and Lainya (Central Equatoria). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities. Two events coded at timeprec3.

column8: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Ajuong Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: During the month of October 2019, armed fishermen attacked Chuei-akuet (Lakes state, coordinates for Adundit used at geoprec2), clashing with Ciec and/or Ajuong Dinka clans in the area (both actors coded). The sources makes no mention of deaths or injuries. One event coded at time prec3.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 15th, SPLM-IO soldiers were alleged to have entered Rimenze IDP camp (Western Equatoria state), and abducted six residents of the camp who were former IO combatants that had been released due to being underage.

column15: Malakal UNMISS Protection of Civilians site
column17: On October 21st, 2019, IDPs demonstrated at the PoC site in Malakal (Upper Nile state), against the lack of adequate water supplies at the camp. [size=dozens]
On October 22nd, unknown gunmen attacked a police convoy at an unspecified location on a road leading out of Leer (Unity state). Two police were wounded in the clash, and two of the attackers killed.

column16: Radio Miraya; CTSAMM; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 27 October 2019, NAS rebels and SSPDF clashed at Esebi (Central Equatoria state, approximate coordinates based on WHO map used at prec2). Three IOM volunteers were killed and two injured in the crossfire (and two missing, including the four year-old boy of one of the deceased). There are conflicing accounts of the fatalities, with SSPDF saying 10 killed (9 rebels, 1 SSPDF) and NAS saying 19 (17 SSPDF, 2 rebels). Lower (SSPDF) estimate used pending further info.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column9: Former Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 27 October 2019, SPLM-IO soldiers abducted between 7 and 10 civilians (including 3 former soldiers) at Bazumbura boma (Western Equatoria state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Rimenze used at geoprec2, as the source suggest it is nearby), where they were taken to James Diko camp. Several abductees were released, but two are unnacounted for. Reports indicate that the IO has abducted numerous individuals from across the country, who are located in the camp.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Sudan Tribune; CTSAMM
column17: On October 27th, NAS rebels and SSPDF clashed at Isebi (Central Equatoria state, approximate coordinates based on WHO map used at prec2). Three IOM volunteers were killed and two injured in the crossfire (and two missing, including the four year-old boy of one of the deceased). There are conflicing accounts of the fatalities, with SSPDF saying 10 killed (9 rebels, 1 SSPDF) and NAS saying 19 (17 SSPDF, 2 rebels). Lower (SSPDF) estimate used pending further info.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On October 28th, CTSAMM announced that SSPDF troops had failed to register at all but two cantonment sites (Renk, Upper Nile state, and Bentiu, Unity state, with forces at the latter returning to outlying areas). Of those SPLM-IO and SSOA combatants who have showed up to register, reports emerged of many leaving cantonment sites in Mirmir, Kendila, Sue, Ngo Alimah and Pantiit, due to a lack of food and other essential supplies.

column6: Panaguong Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Panawur Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On October 28th, members of the Panaguong Dinka clan attacked Abeicok (Lakes state), killing the chief and sub-chief of the Panawur Dinka clan. Two of the attackers were killed in the clash, which appears to be a revenge attack for the killing of a Panaguong chief in 2017.

On October 30, 2019, gunmen (suspected of being NAS rebels, and coded as such) attacked the convoy of the governor of the disputed Yei River state at an unspecified location 10km from Yei on the road to the DRC (Central Equatoria state, coordinates for Megiri used at prec2). There were no injuries.

On October 30th, an unknown group of six attackers (some armed, some unarmed) attacked government forces (coded as SSPDF) at Labalwa (Eastern Equatoria state). No injuries or fatalities occurred; the attackers dropped two weapons, and are being pursued.

On October 31 and November 1, 2019 (note: one report says October 13 and November 1. Oct 31 used at prec2), 17 or 18 South Sudanese tax agents were abducted by armed men in the border areas of Adham and Gongbar (Upper Nile state, no geographic information found, coordinates for Chimadi used at prec2). Reports indicate that Sudan Armed Forces were behind the abductions, although this is denied by the Sudanese embassy in Juba. (Actor1 provisionally coded as SAF).

On October 31 and November 1, 2019 (note: one report says October 13 and November 1. Oct 31 used at prec2), 17 or 18 South Sudanese tax agents were abducted by armed men in the border areas of Adham and Gongbar (Upper Nile state, no geographic information found, coordinates for Chimadi used at prec2). Reports indicate that Sudan Armed Forces were behind the abductions, although this is denied by the Sudanese embassy in Juba. (Actor1 provisionally coded as SAF).
On Novermber 1 2019, unidentified assailants abducted four NGO workers in Bentiu. The worker's current location and the reason for their abduction is not known.

During the month of November 2019, two boda boda riders were killed by unknown gunmen on separate occasions on unspecified main roads leading out of Rumbek town (Lakes state). 2 events coded at time prec3, with one fatality each.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 3 November 2019, SPLM-IO forces abducted six SSOA officers (coded as civilians, given the context) at Akobo (Jonglei state). The abductees have reportedly been tortured, and detained in hazardous conditions.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On November 4, 2019, NSS agents stormed a meeting of youth from Gogrial that was taking place in Juba. 13 were arrested, several of whom were beaten. The youth are suspected of being lured to the event to be arrested, with the Information Minister of the disputed Gogrial state claiming they were ""accusing the state government falsely on their social media"".
On or after November 5, 2019, a soldier was killed by unknown assailants as he was gathering firewood on the outskirts of Waat (Jonglei state). He was shot several times.
On November 6, 2019, unknown gunmen shot dead a man and abducted his wife, at an unspecified location west of Tambura (Western Equatoria state, coordinates used at prec2).
Around 7 November 2019, an unexploded ordnance detonated during funeral proceedings at Lawaci (Eastern Equatoria state), wounding four.
On 8 November 2019, NAS rebels ambushed army vehicles and attacked SSPDF positions at Lora (Central Equatoria state). The source does not mention whether or not there were fatalities.

On November 10, 2019, there were clashes between gunmen (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) and the local militia in Wanglei (Jonglei state) after they shot a mother and her child in what the source suggest was a botched abduction.

On or around November 12, 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Eastern Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked an unspecified location in Western Bahr Naam county (coordinates for Pacong, Lakes state, used at prec2), killing three, and stealing an unspecified number of cattle (which were reported to have been recovered).
On November 12, 2019, market vendors demonstrated at the mayor's office and Chamber of Commerce in Yei (Central Equatoria), following a deterioration in security in the town. [size=small]
On November 14, 2019, a grenade was thrown into a shop in Aweil (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), killing a shopkeeper and wounding three civilians. There is no information on the attacker.

On 15 November 2019, the NSS alleged that NAS rebels abducted 7 civilian, at an unspecified location likely to be in Juba county (coordinates for Juba, Central Equatoria state, used at geoprec2). There is no information on the whereabouts of the abductees.

At unspecified times between early/mid September and early/mid December 2019, NAS forces were reported to have attacked SSPDF barracks at Lasu and Lainya (Central Equatoria). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities. Two events coded at timeprec3.

During the month of November 2019, two boda boda riders were killed by unknown gunmen on separate occasions on unspecified main roads leading out of Rumbek town (Lakes state). 2 events coded at time prec3, with one fatality each.

On November 16, 2019, unknown gunmen (allegedly linked to state security service, although this is unconfirmed) entered the residence of a Ugandan businessman in Juba, and forced him at gunpoint to sign documents to sell his company. The man refused, and has been taken to an unknown location by the gunmen.

On or around November 17, 2019, SSPDF shot and killed an elderly deaf man, who was unable to comply with orders to stop moving, when he went to investigate a raid on his son's house. The event occurred in Joppa (Central Equatoria), which was subject to security sweeps in the area.
On November 18, 2019, unidentified raiders attacked a cattle camp near Wun Lit (Warrap state), killing two women, and stealing 50 head of cattle.

On November 20, 2019, SSPDF clashed with Sudanese armed men in military uniform (coded as SAF) who were heading to a farm in the area of Dung Cam 15km from the Sudanese border into South Sudan (coordinates for Renk, Upper Nile state, used at prec2). Five Sudanese soldiers were arrested. It is unclear whether fatalaties occurred.

On November 20, 2019, unknown gunmen killed a motorbike rider at an unspecified location on the road between Rumbek and Cueibet (Lakes state, coordinates for Abiriu used at prec2). It is unclear if the attackers are the same as those who fired upon local govt officials the same day.

On November 20, 2019, unknown gunmen fired upon a vehicle carrying two local government directors, in the area of Ajook boma in Abiriu county (Lakes state, coordinates for Abiriu used at prec2). The vehicle was damaged, but its occupants were unhurt. Three people have been arrested.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column8: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 21 November, two groups of drunken IDP youths clashed in the Bentiu PoC site (Unity state). UNMISS police attempted to separate the clash, prompting the youths to turn on the police. 2 youths were killed (the sources imply they were killed by other youth), and five UNMISS police were injured. [size=no report]

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Vigilante Group (South Sudan)
column8: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 22 November 2019, IDP youths attacked UN staff, peacekeepers and vehicles at the Bentiu PoC site (Unity state), as the UN were meeting with the family who had lost their relative during the previous days violence. Two UNMISS vehicles were torched, two civilian staff member and a Ghanian peacekeepers were wounded. Youth were dispersed by warning shots after they attacked two guard posts. [size=no report].

On 22 November 2019, an armed group (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) abducted 20 youth (15 of whom were female) near Panyok (Jonglei state). Four young girls are suspected to be with the abductors, whilst the remainder escaped. The gender of the women may be a reason for the attack.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards; Teachers (South Sudan)
column17: On 23 November 2019, gunmen (suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state, and coded as such) attacked a motorbike carrying a prison officer, teacher, and one other civilian, killing the prison officer and wounding the others. The attack occurred between Aguka and Tonj (Warrap state, coordinates for Kair Yair used at geoprec2).

On 24 November 2019, an armed group (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) killed two traders and wounded another at an unspecified location in the disputed Bieh state as they travelled to Duk Padiet (coordinates for Bieh state capital Waat, Jonglei state, used at prec2). There is no further information.
On 24 November 2019, an armed group (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) abducted 10 children from Wei-Kol (Jonglei state), five of whom were able to escape.

On 24 November 2019, an armed group (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) killed two women and injured another civilian near Pamai (Jonglei state). There is no further information.

On 26 November 2019, a militia from Duk Pagak county clashed with an armed group (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) who abducted four girls several days before. The location is not specified (coordinates for Pagak, Jonglei state, used at geoprec3), and one injury occurred. The four abductees were rescued.

column6: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 26 November 2019, a trader was killed by a Pakam Dinka militia at an unspecified location between Rumbek town and Rumbek North county (coordinates for Shuai, Lakes state, used at geoprec2).

column6: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 27 November 2019, two sections of the Pakam Dinka clan (the Gak and Manuer sections) clashed in Maper town (Lakes state. Note that one source says the incident occurred in Alor village), resulting in 23 fatalities and 47 injuries. The clashes appear to relate to the killing of a trader by an unspecified Pakam Dinka clan the previous day.

On 27 November 2019, students marched in Bor (Jonglei state), calling for their lecturers (who have gone on strike) to be paid salary arrears. (Note: the source implies the road was barricaded, but accompanying photos suggest this wasn't the case). [size=dozens]

column6: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column16: Xinhua; Radio Miraya; UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 29 November 2019, the Gak and Manuer sections of the Pakam Dinka clan clashed once again in or near Maper (Lakes state). Reports indicate at least 56 were killed (some of whom may have died of injuries from the previous clash on 27 November), and that over 100 were injured between this clash and the clash on 27 November. UN peacekeepers have been deployed to Mapel from Rumbek.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 29 November 2019, SSPDF and armed pastoralists clashed at Yolbok cattle camp in Nabagok county (Warrap state, coordinates for Nabagok used at geoprec2). 12 soldiers and two ""civilians"" (presumed to be armed pastoralists) were killed, and 5 soldiers and 4 ""civilians"" wounded. The clash was likely related to an on-going disarmament campaign in the disputed Tonj state.
On 29 November 2019, unexploded ordnance detonated at Omaliha market in Torit town (Eastern Equatoria state), destroying nine shops and injuring a child.
On 30 November 2019, unknown gunmen ambushed and shot dead a traffic police officer as he was travelling through Ligi (Central Equatoria state) on a motorbike.

column6: SPLM-N-Agar: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Malik Agar faction)
column17: On 1 December 2019, armed men reported to be in military uniform (subsequently revealed to be members of the SPLM-N Malik Agar faction) attacked a Relief International compound in Bunj (Upper Nile state), assaulting five aid workers and robbing additional aid workers. Later reports indicated that one or more of the aid workers was raped. The perpetrators have been arrested by the SSPDF.

On 2 December 2019, fighting erupted between residents of the Shirkat area of Gumbo (Central Equatoria state) and SSPDF, after soldiers began demolishing houses in the area. No fatalities were reported; soldiers reportedly looted the houses. This is the third such demolition in the area in recent weeks.

On 2 December 2019, an executive chief was shot dead by suspected raiders from the disputed Western Lakes state, at an unspecified location between Yirol, Ngop and Aluakluak counties in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (coordinates for Lual Maker, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). The attackers also looted 200 head of cattle.

On 3 December 2019, refugees from the Nuba Mountains of Sudan demonstrated at the UNHCR office in Yida Refugee Camp (Unity state), protesting the lack of food, water and medicine in the camp, which have reportedly been lacking over the past three months. [size=hundreds]

column6: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Nyarweng Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 4 December 2019, a clash over the disputed island of Chuei-akuet in the area of Shame in Yirol East county (Lakes state) occurred (likely between the Nyarweng Dinka and Ciec Dinka clans who inhabit the area). 86 people are reported to be missing, although the source does not mention whether there are fatalities.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: Eastern Jikany Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column16: CTSAMM; Sudan Tribune; UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 6 December 2019, SPLM-IO forces clashed with armed youth (likely from the Cie-Waw section of the Eastern Jikany Nuer, and coded as such) said to be under the command of a senior IO officer who recently defected to the government (assoc actor2 coded as IO splinter faction). The clashes occurred in Nyoplew, Gokjak, Baar and Wecgatluakrik areas of Maiwut county (Upper Nile state, coordinates for Khor Bar used at geoprec2, with one event coded), as IO forces were attempting to guard a barge transporting goods from Nassir to Jikou. One source indicates seven civilians and/or youth militia were killed, though details are unclear.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before 6 December 2019, SPLM-IO forces under a prominent commander were alleged to have abducted children from Nabiama (Western Equatoria state; approximate coordinates based on Ebola response map used at geoprec2. Note that the source says the event took place close to Tambura, but there is no clear geographic information of such place in that area). Two of the youth escaped; the commander has denied that the abductions occurred.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or before 6 December 2019, SPLM-IO forces were alleged to have attacked civilian farmers at Jikou (Upper Nile state). There is no further information, including on fatalities or casualties.

column7: SPLM/A: Sudan People's Liberation Movement/Army; Women (South Sudan)
column17: On 6 December 2019, youth and women (described as ""aligned"" to the SPLM, and coded as such) protested in Torit (Eastern Equatoria state), calling for further states to be created beyond the current (disputed) 32 states. Petitions were handed to the governor and CTSAMM ceasefire monitors. [size=no report]

On 7 or 8 December 2019, in-fighting was reported within an unspecified rebel group (coded as UAG, pending further information), at an unspecified location in north-west Unity state (coordinates for Abiemnom, Unity state, used at geoprec3). The source does not mention whether there were casualties.

column8: Pakam Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 8 December 2019, clashes between Rup Dinka (a.k.a Agaar Dinka) and Pakam Dinka clans occurred at Cuei-Adukan (Lakes state). The governor of the disputed Western Lakes state was present at the time, and was fired upon by unspecified militiamen, wounding a soldier. In total, at least 3 fatalities occurred, alongside 12 injuries. One source suggests multiple violent incidents occurred in this area on the same day, though this is currently unclear (one event coded).
On 9 December 2019, an unexploded grenade detonated at an unspecified location in the disputed Rokon county (Central Equatoria state, coordinates for Rokon used at geoprec2), wounding six children.
On 10 December 2019, SSPDF were alleged to have killed six civilians in the Loka and Lainya areas (Central Equatoria state), according to NAS rebels. One event coded at geoprec2.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 10 December 2019, SPLM-IO forces clashed with former IO forces under Maj. Gen Ochan (which have recently become aligned to the government) at an unspecified location along the Sobat river (coordinates for Torpot, Nasir county, Upper Nile state, used at geoprec2). 4 were killed, and 10 wounded.

On 11 December 2019, demonstrators marched to the UNMISS base in Aweil (Northern Bahr el Ghazal), calling for the government, opposition groups, international community and the UN to ensure that there are no further delays to the formation of the transitional government. [size=no report]

On 11 December 2019, two youth groups clashed at an unspecified location in the disputed county of Alabek (Warrap state, coordinates for Alabek used at geoprec2), resulting in at least 9 fatalities and 11 injuries. The clashes were sparked by the renaming of Alabek county to Lou county.
On 13 December 2019, unknown raiders attacked an area near Patuet (Jonglei state), wounding two and stealing 320 head of cattle.

On or before 13 December 2019, SSPDF soldiers were implicated in the arrest and torture of a civilian in Kopera (Lainya county, Central Equatoria state), and the rape of an 11 year-old girl. One event coded at time prec2.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; UN Panel of Experts; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 13 December 2019, NAS rebels captured an SSPDF base at Lasu in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). During two days of clashes at Lasu and Mitika, NAS rebels claimed to have killed a total of 19 SSPDF, although the army has said that it suffered no casualties. Four events coded with zero fatalities.

On 13 December 2019, during a two day battle between NAS rebels and government soldiers, NAS rebels and SSPDF clashed in the area of Mitika in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). During two days of clashes at Lasu and Mitika, NAS rebels claimed to have killed a total of 19 SSPDF, although the army has said that it suffered no casualties. Four events coded with zero fatalities.

On 13 December 2019, residents of Yei (as well as members of the state assembly, coded as SPLM) marched through Yei town (Central Equatoria state), handing petitions to the governor of the disputed Yei Rivers state and to UNMISS, calling for the controversial 32 states system to be preserved, and for the inclusion of Abyei in South Sudan. [size=hundreds]

column16: UN Panel of Experts; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 14 December 2019, NAS rebels and SSPDF clashed in Lasu (Central Equatoria state), following the capture of the SSPDF base by NAS rebels the previous day. During two days of clashes at Lasu and Mitika, NAS rebels claimed to have killed a total of 19 SSPDF, although the army has said that it suffered no casualties. Four events coded with zero fatalities.

On 14 December 2019, during a two day battle between NAS rebels and government soldiers, NAS rebels and SSPDF clashed in the area of Mitika in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). During two days of clashes at Lasu and Mitika, NAS rebels claimed to have killed a total of 19 SSPDF, although the army has said that it suffered no casualties. Four events coded with zero fatalities.

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), a university student who was transporting cattle to the port at Bor (Jonglei state) was killed at an unspecified location, likely in the vicinity of Bor. Two attackers (presumed to be Bor Dinka) have been arrested and sentenced to death.
On 15 December 2019, unknown cattle raiders attacked Bilinyang payam in Mangalla (Central Equatoria, coordinates for Mangalla used at geoprec2), killing three.

On 15 December 2019, raiders (likely from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) attacked pastoralists near Paliau (Jonglei state). Three of the raiders and four of the pastoralists (coded as Twic East militia) were killed, and two wounded. 1,000 head of cattle were looted, some of which were recovered.

On 15 December 2019, gunmen in military uniform (suspected of being from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle ethnic militia) abducted two children near Jebel Muluk (no geographic information found, coordinates for Longairo, Eastern Equatoria state, used at geoprec2).

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Around 15 December 2019 (month of), SSPDF Military Intelligence recruited 1,500 Ciec and Aliab Dinka youths from the areas of Adior, Wunthou and Pagarau around Yirol in the disputed Eastern Lakes state (Lakes state), in breach of the R-ARCSS peace agreement. A military site has been established in Adior, whilst arms (including heavy weapons) have been distributed to the youths, and to Military Intelligence-linked militia in Panyiar area of southern Unity state.

On 16 December 2019, armed youth attacked stranded passengers near Atiaba (Lakes state), engaging in a firefight with an SSPDF soldier travelling with them. The soldier was killed, and one of the attackers wounded. Note that source is unclear as to whether other passengers were killed.

Around 16 December 2019, SSPDF executed an unspecified number of youth (accusing them of being rebels), raped women (including a pregnant woman), and burned and looted property in Lasu (Central Equatoria state). The attacks appear to be reprisals after the NAS briefly occupied the village. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.
On 16 December 2019, SSPDF retook Lasu in Yei county (Central Equatoria state) from NAS rebels. The source makes no mention of casualties or fatalities.

As reported on 17 December 2019, hundreds of pro-government protesters delivered a petition to the Governor of the disputed Eastern Lakes state (the location is presumed to be Yirol, Lakes state, and has been coded as such at geoprec1), calling for the controversial 32 states system to remain. [size=hundreds]
On 18 December 2019, NAS rebels were reported to have attacked an SSPDF barracks at Kalipapa (Juba county, Central Equatoria state). There is no further information.

On 20 December 2019, residents of the disputed Maridi state gathered in Maridi (Western Equatoria), calling for the disputed state to remain intact, as negotiations over state boundaries continue between the government and rebels. [size=hundreds]
On 21 December 2019, raiders attacked a cattle camp near Jalle (Jonglei state), wounding six, and looting 700 head of cattle (which were later retrieved).

column6: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Nyarweng Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 22 and 23 December 2019, Dinka youth (belonging to the Ciec clan, and the Adhioc (likely a section of the Nyarweng clan) clashed once again at the disputed Cuet-Akuet island near Shambe in Yirol East county (Lakes state). Reports indicate 2 killed (fatalities spread across 2 events), 3 wounded, and 5 missing. Note that one source describes the deceased as ""security officers"", although this is not corroborated by a more detailed account.

On 23 December 2019, Sudan and South Sudan reached an agreement on a three-year deal regarding fees for South Sudan's access to oil pipelines running through Sudan. The fees are now $24 and $26 per barrel, whilst South Sudan will also provide 28,000 bpd to Sudan.

column6: Ciec Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Nyarweng Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 22 and 23 December 2019, Dinka youth (belonging to the Ciec clan, and the Adhioc (likely a section of the Nyarweng clan) clashed once again at the disputed Cuet-Akuet island near Shambe in Yirol East county (Lakes state). Reports indicate 2 killed (fatalities spread across 2 events), 3 wounded, and 5 missing. Note that one source describes the deceased as ""security officers"", although this is not corroborated by a more detailed account.
On 24 December 2019, unknown gunmen killed a male civilian at an unspecified location in Abiemnhom East county (Unity state, coordinates for Amiemnhom used at geoprec2).

On 24 December 2019, raiders abducted a child and looted around 70 cows in an unspecified area between the disputed Eastern and Western Bahr Naam counties (Lakes state, coordinates for Aduel used at geoprec2). The child and cattle were peacefully released following intervention from state authorities.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 25 December 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Western Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked traders moving cattle to the disputed Maridi state, in the area of Madeira (no geographic information found; coordinates for Dodo Goey, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). Six traders were killed, and 12 wounded. 1,400 cattle were stolen.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 25 December 2019, unknown attackers stabbed an NSS officer as he was on patrol in Tambura town (Western Equatoria state). The attackers also attempted to disarm the officer.

On 26 December 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Northern Liech state, and coded as such) attacked pastoralists in the area of Makol in Ajak Kuac county (Warrap state, coordinates for Ajakuac used at geoprec2), killing one and wounding two, and stealing 800-1,000 head of cattle.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 26 December 2019, an NSS officer (or multiple NSS agents) shot a killed a young man at Aru Junction (Central Equatoria state). The victim was the brother of a local area chief. One NSS officer has been arrested.

On 26 December 2019, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) killed a pastoralist near Boungjok (Jonglei state), and looted 350 head of cattle (which were later retrieved by local youth).

On 30 December 2019, a Sudanese pastoralist was killed by unexploded ordnance at an unspecified location in Manyo county (Upper Nile state, coordinates for Wadakona used at geoprec2). Two others were injured. Note: given that the grenade was picked up at a military base in the area, actor1 is coded as SSPDF.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column17: Around 31 December 2019 (end of month), an SPLM-IO splinter group aligned with the government clashed with regular SPLM-IO soldiers in the area of Jikou (Upper Nile state), in fighting linked to an ongoing dispute between two commanders. At least 10 civilians were killed across this event and fighting in two events on 5 July in Maiwut. Fatalities distributed across three events.

Around 31 December 2019 (end of month), SSPDF executed three farmers at an unspecified location in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state), after they were accused of being supporters of NAS rebels. The families of the victims fled for Uganda after the killings.

On 1 January 2020, an unknown group armed with simple bladed weapons attacked a Pentecostal pastor in Aweil (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state) as he attempted to clear the group from his church (the group had been preventing worshippers from entering). The pastor sustained an injury to his face.

On 1 January 2020, gunmen (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) killed a civilian in the area of Kongor (Jonglei state). There is no known motive for the attack.

On 1 January 2020, unknown attackers intercepted four commercial vehicles at an unspecified location(s) on the Juba-Rumbek road in the disputed Eastern and Western Bahr Naam county (coordinates for Aduel, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). Two civilians were wounded; one event coded.

On 2 January 2020, an unknown armed group (reported to be ""youth"", and coded as UAG) fired upon a military convoy at an unspecified location in Western Bahr Naam county (coordinates for Aduel, Lakes state, used at geoprec2), killing one solider.

On 2 January 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle in the Khor Makuac area (Jonglei state, coordinates for Langbar used at geoprec2), killing one and wounding three. There is no clear motive for the attack.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 2 January 2020, President Salva Kiir pardoned 30 prisoners, including two high-profile detainees held by the NSS, who's detention and trial had resulted in international condemnation.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On or around 3 January 2020, fifteen SPLM-IO soldiers of Balanda ethnicity fled from Sue cantonment site, where they had been detained on the orders of a senior Zande IO general amidst rivalries among IO forces in the area. The Balanda soldiers were reported to have clashed with other SPLM-IO soldiers at an unspecified location in the area of Tambura (Western Equatoria state). The sources do not mention whether there were casualties.
