On 3 January 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a fuel tanker in the Kubri-Mohandessin area (Jonglei state, no geographic information found, coordinates for Bor used as geoprec2), killing a soldier in the process. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 4 January 2020, cattle raiders from both the disputed Western and Eastern Lakes state raided an unspecified area in the disputed Paloc county (Lakes state, coordinates for Pagan used at geoprec2). In the firefight, two of the attackers were wounded (and later arrested) and one of the defenders (coded as a Western Lakes pastoralist militia) was killed. 24 head of cattle were stolen.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column16: Radio Miraya; UN Panel of Experts; UNSC; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 5 January 2020, an SPLM-IO splinter group aligned to the government attacked regular SPLM-IO soldiers at Wech Gatluak Rik in Jotome payam in Maiwut county (Upper Nile state). At least 10 civilians were killed between this event, another at Jikou the same day, and another clash in late December (fatalities distributed across three events). One source notes that casualties were sustained by both combatants, but does not state whether fatalities occurred.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column16: Radio Miraya; Eye Radio (South Sudan); UN Panel of Experts; Radio Tamazuj; UNSC
column17: On 5 January 2020, an SPLM-IO splinter group aligned with the government clashed with regular SPLM-IO soldiers at Jikou (Upper Nile state), with the splinter group then seizing control of Jikou town. At least 10 civilians were killed between this event, another in Jotome payam the same day, and another clash in late December (fatalities distributed across three events). One source notes that casualties were sustained by both combatants, but does not state whether fatalities occurred.

On 6 January 2020, demonstrators marched in Bor (Jonglei state) calling for the disputed 32 state system to remain intact or be further expanded, as negotiations over state boundaries continue between the government and rebels. [size=dozens]

On 7 and 8 January 2020, two Lou Nuer clans (the Cie-Pajok and Cie-Bur) clashed at an unspecified part of the disputed Padiek county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Weykol used at geoprec2) over a cattle dowry payment. Two were killed on each day, and one injured on 8 Jan.
On or before 7 January 2020, three girls (aged between 11 and 12) were raped by unknown armed men as they were gathering firewood at Akuac village (Lakes state).

column9: SPLM-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Taban Deng Gai Faction)
column17: On 8 January 2020, the US government announced that sanctions would be imposed upon First Vice President Taban Deng, accusing him of frustrating peace efforts and being responsible for human rights abuses, including the disappearance and likely execution of two SPLM-IO dissidents in Kenya. The move follows sanctions imposed on several NSS operatives in December, and upon the ministers of Defence and Cabinet Affairs on 16 Dec.

On 7 and 8 January 2020, two Lou Nuer clans (the Cie-Pajok and Cie-Bur) clashed at an unspecified part of the disputed Padiek county (Jonglei state, coordinates for Weykol used at geoprec2) over a cattle dowry payment. Two were killed on each day, and one injured on 8 Jan.

column6: Atuot Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: During early January 2020, Agar and Atwot Dinka clans clashed in Mabui in Yirol West county (Lakes state), displacing 2,871 people. The source does not mention any fatalities. The reasons for the fighting are not specified.

column8: Atuot Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: During early January 2020, an armed group from Mvolo county clashed with Atwot Dinka clan in Aguraan in Yirol West county (Lakes state), displacing at least 2,605 people. The source does not mention any fatalities. The reasons for the fighting are not specified.

On or around 8 January 2020, demonstrators marched in Tonj (Warrap state), calling for the disputed 32 state system to remain intact or be further expanded, as negotiations over state boundaries continue between the government and rebels. [size=no report]

On or before 9 January 2020, demonstrators marched at an unspecified location in the disputed Gogrial state (Warrap, coordinates for Gogrial used at geoprec2) calling for the disputed 32 state system to remain intact or be further expanded, as negotiations over state boundaries continue between the government and rebels. [size=no report]

column9: Amadi Communal Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On 11 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Eastern Lakes state, and coded as such) clashed with police and armed pastoralists (coded as militia from the disputed Amadi state) who were retreiving stolen cattle from the raiders, at an unspecified location in the disputed Bahr Grindi county (Western Equatoria state, coordinates for Mvolo used at geoprec2). A police officer and a pastoralist youth were killed in the firefight.
On 11 and/or 12 January 2020, three women were raped by armed men in the outskirts of Yei (Central Equatoria state). One event coded at time prec2.

On 11 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Western Lakes state, and coded as such) attacked cattle camps in the area of Anuol (Lakes state), wounding six, and looting approx. 95 head of cattle (most of which were recovered). Event coded as VAC, as the source does not specify whether a firefight took place.
On 11 January 2020, unknown gunmen shot dead a police officer in Yambio (Western Equatoria). The motive for the killing is unclear.

column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On 12 January 2020, gunmen wearing police uniforms shot dead a Law lecturer from the University of Juba (who was also a practicing lawyer), near Gudele police station (Central Equatoria state). After a manhunt, several (including a Military Intelligence officer) were arrested in the Rumbek area connection with the killing.

On 13 January 2020, striking employees of a Chinese-owned power company demonstrated outside the police headquarters at Buluk in Juba (Central Equatoria), following the deaths of two employees, and pressures for workers to work without overtime pay. [size=400]

On 13 January 2020, students of the University of Juba marched to the National Assembly building in Juba, calling for justice following the killing of a Law lecturer by men in police uniform the previous day. [size=no report]

column9: Civilians (Uganda); Aid Workers (Uganda); Aid Workers (South Sudan); UN: United Nations
column17: On 13 Janary 2020, a UN humanitarian convoy was attacked as it travelled from Juba to Warrap through Awerial county near Awachi village by unknown armed men. A Ugandan national truck driver working with a UN humanitarian agency was taken to a local clinic at Bunagok Payam following the attack.

On 14 January 2020, an SSPDF soldier shot and killed a civilian at an unspecified location in the disputed Akon county (Gogrial West county, Warrap state. Coordinates for Akon used at geoprec2), during a disarmament campaign. The soldier was arrested.

On 14 and 15 January 2020, and following a dispute the previous day over land, two men were killed in ambushes at or near Leteji village (Lafon county, Eastern Equatoria state). Two events coded with fatalities spread across both days, and actor 1 coded as Lopit ethnic militia.

On or before 14 January 2020, an unknown armed group attacked a civilian between Wargiir and Bomthok north-east of Tonj (Warrap state, no geographic info found, coordinates for Waratit used at geoprec2). The civilian escaped from the attackers. There is no further information.

On or before 14 January 2020, raiders (implied in the source of coming from the disputed Gok state, and coded as such) attacked pastoralists at Kolngap 10km south-west of Tonj (Warrap state, no geographic information found, coordinates for Kombania used at geoprec2), killing two and wounding two, and stealing approx. 2,000 head of cattle. Event coded as VAC, as the source does not specify whether a firefight took place.

On 14 and 15 January 2020, and following a dispute the previous day over land, two men were killed in ambushes at or near Leteji village (Lafon county, Eastern Equatoria state). Two events coded with fatalities spread across both days, and actor 1 coded as Lopit ethnic militia.

On 15 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Eastern Lakes state, and coded as such) killed three people at an unspecified location in the disputed Bahr Grindi county (Western Equatoria state, coordinates for Mvolo used at geoprec2). Event coded as VAC, as the source does not specify whether a firefight took place.

column7: Bul Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Bul Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 January 2020 (month of), SSPDF Special Forces (a Bul Nuer unit controlled by Maj. Gen Matthew Puljang) clashed with forces (presumed to also be Bul Nuer) loyal to the governor of the disputed Northern Liech state in Mayom town (Unity state). The clash is reported to be linked to efforts by the governor to remove Puljang from control of the Special Forces. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); Health Workers (South Sudan)
column17: On 17 January 2020, a national NGO staff member was seriously injured when a group of armed men attacked a clinic in Kauch (Guit, Unity). Official reports indicate the suspected motive is a revenge killing.

On 18 January 2020, retaliatory cattle raids by pastoralists in the disputed Gok state (coded as Cueibet pastoralist militias) resulted in 15 deaths and between 7 and 14 wounded. Conflicting information suggestions that 4 were killed at or near Cueibet town, and 11 were killed in parts of the disputed Duony county (coordinates for Adholthec, Cueibet county, Lakes states, used at geoprec2). Two events coded with fatalities distributed as above.

On 18 January 2020, retaliatory cattle raids by pastoralists in the disputed Gok state (coded as Cueibet pastoralist militias) resulted in 15 deaths and between 7 and 14 wounded. Conflicting information suggestions that 4 were killed at or near Cueibet town, and 11 were killed in parts of the disputed Duony county (coordinates for Adholthec, Cueibet county, Lakes states, used at geoprec2). Two events coded with fatalities distributed as above.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 20 January 2020, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels clashed in or near Rasolo in Yei county (Central Equatoria state), displacing 612 to Maridi county. There is no mention of fatalities. An unconfirmed report says that NAS rebel abducted 26 civilians.

On 21 January 2020, armed youth (likely from the disputed Torit East county, and coded as such) attacked a fuel vehicle near Oguruny (Torit county, Eastern Equatoria state). Soldiers then became involved, causing a firefight between SSPDF and the youth, with two youth being killed and one wounded, and a civilian also being wounded (seemingly in the crossfire).

On 22 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) attacked Paluony village in Pathai payam (Uror county, Jonglei state. Coordinates for Pathai used at geoprec2), stealing 56 head of cattle, which were later recovered. The source notes that clashes occurred (actor2 coded as Jonglei communal militia), but that no injuries occurred.

On 22 January 2020, students from the University of Juba demonstrated against the University's new policy to refuse students who were in fee arrears from sitting final examinations, vandalising property in the University buldings. The University has indicated that it will be changing its approach. [size=no report]

On 24 January 2020 (and possibly over the subsequent one or two days), 10 people were killed in Tonj town (Warrap state) in what is described as a land dispute among communities residing in counties bordering the town. An unspecified number were injured. One event coded at time prec2.

On 24 January 2020, over 100 protesters from Abyei (assoc actor coded as Ngok Dinka) marched in Juba, following the killing of 32 civilians in Abyei two days prior. The protesters delivered a letter to the UN Mission, and to the Sudanese embassy. [size=over 100]

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 24 January 2020, three SPLM-IO rebels attacked a civilian at Yaribe boma (Morobo county, Central Equatoria state), breaking his back using a hammer after beating him. The soldiers also robbed money from an elderly woman.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 27 January 2020, a vehicle was fired upon by unknown attackers at Affa (Maridi county, Western Equatoria state), wounding two. Three or four civilians were then abducted by the group.

On 27 January 2020, an SSPDF soldier was attacked by an armed group suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state (and coded as such) at an unspecified location in Wulu county (implied to be near Bahr Gel, Lakes state, which has been used at geoprec2). Although the soldier received five gunshot wounds, he survived the attack. Authorities from Gok dispute the allegation that the attackers are from Gok state.

On 27 January 2020, a civilian was killed by an armed group suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state (and coded as such) at an unspecified location in Wulu county (coorindates for Bahr Gel, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). Authorities from Gok dispute the allegation that the attackers are from Gok state.

On 27 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Boma state, and coded as Murle militia) attacked armed youths (coded as Lou Nuer militia) in the area of Guer in the disputed Pading county (coordinates for Pakum, Nyirol county, Jonglei state, used at geoprec2). One Lou Nuer and three of the raiders were killed.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 28 and 29 January 2020, two sections of the Agar Dinka (the Athoi and Rup sections) clashed in the area of Bahr Aguoc (Rumbek East county, Lakes state), reportedly in response to a prior killing. There is currently no information regarding casualties or fatalities.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On or before 28 January 2020, an NSS officer shot dead two of his colleagues after they attempted to prevent him from taking an assault rifle from the armoury in Wanyjok (Aweil East county, Northern Bahr el Ghazal state). One of the victims died later in hospital.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition-Fertit Lions: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Fertit Lions Faction)
column7: Balanda Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Boor Clan Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 28 January 2020, SPLM-IO Fertit Lions forces under the command of a Balanda (Boor clan) general (based in the area of Bazia south of Wau) abducted 62 people from an unspecified area near Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal state, location of abduction is presumed to be south of the city). The source indicates that the abduction is linked to disputes among IO commanders belonging to different Balanda clans, although it is does not specify whether the abductees are affiliated with the IO.

On 29 January 2020, a 16 year-old boy was wounded in Domolotto payam (coordinates for Dodo Goey, Wulu county, Lakes state, used at geoprec2) when a grenade he had found exploded whilst he was holding it.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 28 and 29 January 2020, two sections of the Agar Dinka (the Athoi and Rup sections) clashed in the area of Bahr Aguoc (Rumbek East county, Lakes state), reportedly in response to a prior killing. There is currently no information regarding casualties or fatalities.

Around 29 January 2020 (week of), Thony and Muok sub-sections of the Rek Dinka clashed in several areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Warkar, Nyincuei, Majol Titaba, and potentially other locations in and around Tonj. The clash, which was linked to a land dispute, displaced 12,547 people. At least 16 were killed and an unspecified number wounded (fatalities distributed across four events).

During the week commencing 27 January 2020, unidentified armed group(s) abducted 62 civilians in Rasolo and Minyori (Yei county, Central Equatoria state), with a teacher among the abducted in Minyori. A child was also killed and 25 dwellings torched. The source implies the bulk of the abductions, as well as the killing and burning, took place in Rasolo. Two events coded at time prec2.

During the week commencing 27 January 2020, unidentified armed group(s) abducted 62 civilians in Rasolo and Minyori (Yei county, Central Equatoria state), with a teacher among the abducted in Minyori. A child was also killed and 25 dwellings torched. The source implies the bulk of the abductions, as well as the killing and burning, took place in Rasolo. Two events coded at time prec2.

On 29 January 2020, unknown gunmen attacked an aid worker convoy travelling between Panyagor and Poktap (coordinates for Poktap, Duk county, Jonglei state, used at geoprec2), shooting and wounding one aid worker, before robbing the convoy.

In late January 2020, armed youth were reported to have clashed at an unspecified location(s) in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria state), displacing approx. 5,000. There is no further information, and the source does not mention whether there were fatalities.

Around 29 January 2020 (week of), Thony and Muok sub-sections of the Rek Dinka clashed in several areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Warkar, Nyincuei, Majol Titaba, and potentially other locations in and around Tonj. The clash, which was linked to a land dispute, displaced 12,547 people. At least 16 were killed and an unspecified number wounded (fatalities distributed across four events).

Around 29 January 2020 (week of), Thony and Muok sub-sections of the Rek Dinka clashed in several areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Warkar, Nyincuei, Majol Titaba, and potentially other locations in and around Tonj. The clash, which was linked to a land dispute, displaced 12,547 people. At least 16 were killed and an unspecified number wounded (fatalities distributed across four events).

Around 29 January 2020 (week of), Thony and Muok sub-sections of the Rek Dinka clashed in several areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Warkar, Nyincuei, Majol Titaba, and potentially other locations in and around Tonj. The clash, which was linked to a land dispute, displaced 12,547 people. At least 16 were killed and an unspecified number wounded (fatalities distributed across four events).

column6: Gok Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 30 January 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state, and coded as Gok Dinka militia) attacked unspecified areas of Mayom payam in the disputed Malek county (coordinates for Malek, Rumbek Centre county, Lakes state, used at geoprec2), killing 8 or 9 (8 fatalities coded) and wounding four, and stealing around 60 cows and goats. The source does not indicate a firefight took place (event coded as VAC/Attack). 150 dwellings were torched between this and intra-Agar Dinka fighting in the following two days.

On 30 January 2020, armed youth (suspected of coming from the disputed Gok state, and coded as such) clashed with SSPDF and SSNPS at Cuei Arol (implied to be near Rumbek town, Lakes state (coordinates used at geoprec2)). Four were killed, which appears to include one SSPDF soldier and two police, and an unspecified number were wounded.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 January and 1 February, the Gony Dinka sub-section of the Athoi section of the Agar Dinka clashed with the Rup section of the Agar Dinka at unspecified areas of the disputed Western Lakes state, implied to be in Rumbek East county (coordinates for Pacong, Rumbek East county, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). 53 were reported killed (fatalities split across 2 events) and over 40 were injured, with 150 dwellings torched between this event and separate attacks by Gok Dinka militias the previous day. The source suggests these attacks are a series of retalliatory clashes.

On or before 1 February 2020, two people were killed and three wounded in the Chuolakol area near Tonj town (Warrap state, coordinates used at geoprec2) during a cattle raid, in which 152 head of cattle were stolen. Event presumed to be a clash, with actor coded as an unknown militia, and actor2 (the defenders) as Tonj communal militia.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition-Fertit Lions: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Fertit Lions Faction)
column7: Balanda Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Boor Clan Group (South Sudan)
column8: SPLM-In Opposition-Fertit Lions: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Fertit Lions Faction)
column17: On 1 February 2020, SPLM-IO Fertit Lions forces under the command of a Balanda (Boor clan) commander attacked a rival Balanda IO general's base at Faraj Allah in Wau county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), ""razing"" it. The source does not mention whether there were casualties. The attack prompted the general whose base was destroyed to defect to the government on Feb 10.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 January and 1 February, the Gony Dinka sub-section of the Athoi section of the Agar Dinka clashed with the Rup section of the Agar Dinka at unspecified areas of the disputed Western Lakes state, implied to be in Rumbek East county (coordinates for Pacong, Rumbek East county, Lakes state, used at geoprec2). 53 were reported killed (fatalities split across 2 events) and over 40 were injured, with 150 dwellings torched between this event and separate attacks by Gok Dinka militias. The source suggests these attacks are a series of retalliatory clashes.

On or before 2 February 2020, an armed group (comprising gunmen from the areas of Yar and Thiet near Tonj, but who had falsely claimed to be from Thony) attacked the house of the Deputy Speaker of the (disputed) Tonj state assembly, and were later apprehended by police. The attack comes amidst ongoing clashes involving communities living near Tonj. The source implies there were no injuries or fatalities.

On 2 February 2020, armed youth from the disputed Western Lakes state attacked Manykony boma in the disputed Gok state (no geographic information found, coordinates for Gok state capital Cueibet, Lakes state, used at geoprec2), killing one and wounding several.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: As reported on 3 February 2020, a ""security officer"" (and presumed to be NSS) shot and killed a non-South Sudanese civilian who was held in police custody in Juba (the victim had injured a girl in a vehicle accident, who was a relative of the perpatrator), and also shot and wounded a police officer who attempted to intervene.

On 3 February 2020, several hundred female market vendors demonstrated in Juba after the local authorities attempted to expel them from Konyo Konyo market without providing adequate alternatives. Two market directors have been suspended. [size=several hundred]

On 4 February 2020, unknown gunmen clashed with SSPDF in Madol (Tonj South county, Warrap state), killing one soldier. Although the attackers are described as ""armed robbers"" in the source, they were active in an area of military residences, and there is no mention of robbery.
On or before 4 February 2020, two women were raped by armed men in the area of Ameth Chok (Tonj South county, Warrap state. Approximate coordinates based on IOM database used at geoprec2).

On 4 February 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a group comprising two armed men (coded as Twic East militia) and five women who were gathering materials for building thatched tukuls in the area of Werawullen near Wanglei (Twic East county, Jonglei state, coordinates used at geoprec2). The two armed men were killed by the group, and their guns taken.
On 5 February 2020, unknown attackers (suspected of belonging to the Murle ethnic group) killed a farmer in the Buong area of Pochalla county (Jonglei state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

On or before 5 February 2020, unknown raiders attacked Makuei Karshit 7km from Tonj town (no location found; coordinates for Tonj, Warrap state used at geoprec2), wounding one, and stealing 50 head of cattle (10 of which were recovered).

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: On 5 February 2020, a prison officer (who was the son of a General in the Prison Service) was shot dead with five gunshots from three armed men (one in military uniform, assoc actor1 coded as SSPDF) as he walked home in Juba, and refused to hand over his phone to the gunmen. Event coded as VAC/Attack given the circumstances those involved - targeted killings are often made to look random in South Sudan.

On 11 February 2020, unknown gunmen killed one person and wounded two in the Jebel Yesua area of Gudele (Central Equatoria state). There is no clear motive for the attack. One person has been arrested.

column7: Vigilante Group (South Sudan); Murle Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 12 February, local youths attacked and killed the driver of an INGO vehicle travelling between Lawol and Gumuruk (Pibor, Jonglei), after the vehicle was involved in a collision that killed one youth. The other three national staff in the vehicle escaped the scene on foot and reports indicate they have all been accounted for. [size=no report]

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 12 February 2020, unknown gunmen (presumed to be Murle militia) attacked a vehicle carrying aid workers at an unspecified location along the Gumuruk-Pibor road in Pibor county (coordinates used for Lawol, Jonglei state). The attackers shot dead a South Sudanese aid worker. There is no clear motive for the attack.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or before 12 February 2020, IDPs (presumed to be Nuer) demonstrated in Bentiu (Unity state), calling for the transitional government to be formed in time for the 20 Feb deadline. [size=no report]

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 12 February 2020, Nuer IDPs marched into the UN office in Juba, calling for a return to the 10 states system. [size=no report]

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or before 12 February 2020, IDPs (presumed to be Nuer) demonstrated in Bor (Jonglei state), calling for the transitional government to be formed in time for the 20 Feb deadline. [size=no report]
On 12 February 2020, hundreds of pro-government demonstrators (including government officials) held a rally in Juba, calling for the controversial 32 states system to remain in place. [size=hundreds]

During the week beginning 10 February 2020, two Sudanese Misseriya traders were killed in the vicinity of Yith Pabol in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state). The motive for the attack is unclear; three suspects have been arrested.
On 12 February 2020, a pro-government march took place in Rumbek (Lakes state), in favour of retaining the controversial 32 states system. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column17: On 13 February 2020, SSPDF Tiger Division soldiers attacked Rubeki in Lasu payam (Central Equatoria state), gang raping one women, and raping three other women (including a pregnant woman, and a woman who was farming). Civilians were beaten; had possessions stolen from them; and a woman was forced to cook for the soldiers at gunpoint. A civilian was reported to have been shot dead by the soldiers.
On 14 February 2020, pro-government protests took place in Yirol (Lakes state), calling for the controversial 32 states system to be maintained. [size=no report]

column7: Lou Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Government of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 14 February 2020, residents of Nyirol county (assumed Lou Nuer ethnic group), alongside members of the local government, marched in Lankien (Jonglei state), calling for a return to the 10 states system. [size=no report]

On 14 February 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from Panyijar county in Unity state) attacked Pakujiak in Yirol East county (Lakes state), killing at least five and wounding two. 200 head of cattle were looted.

On 15 February 2020, the government of South Sudan reversed its position on maintaining the controversial 32 states system and instead backed a return to the 10 states system which have been in use since 2005 (though with exceptions for the areas of Ruweng and Greater Pibor). The move comes as the deadline to establish a transitional government nears, and President Kiir has instructed the judiciary to immediately implement the directive. All 32 governors have been dismissed.

During the month of February 2020, an unspecified armed group attacked the villages of Akoor and Pawadukel in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state). The attack comes amid tensions between pastoralists and farmers in the area, which has involved pastoralist militias from neighbouring Tonj. There is no mention of casualties or fatalities in the source.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column7: Gajaak-Eastern Jikany Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 February 2020 (month of), an SPLM-IO splinter faction aligned to the government and operating in conjunction with Cie-Waw militia (a sub-section of the Gajaak Nuer section of the Eastern Jikany Nuer) was reported to have engaged in sexual violence (including the mutilation of male and female genitalia) at an unspecified location of Maiwut county (Upper Nile state), presumed to be close to Jikou. The attacks are said to have been targeted at supporters of regular IO forces in the area. Note that the source mentions that civilians were killed, but it is unclear whether the source is referring to two civilians killed by the same forces on 19 Feb, or to additional killings.

On 15 February 2020, dozens of youths demonstrated in Renk town (Upper Nile state), following the dissolving of the controversial 32 states system in favour of a return to a modified version of the 10 states system. [size=dozens]
On 15 February 2020, unknown raiders attacked a cattle camp in Poktap town in Duk county (Jonglei state), killing one and stealing 200 head of cattle.

On 16 February 2020, youths burned tires on a main road in Renk town (Upper Nile state), following the dissolving of the controversial 32 states system in favour of a return to a modified version of the 10 states system. [size=no report]

On 16 February 2020, armed groups residing in Rumbek North (and presumed to be of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka, who are resident in the area) clashed in or near Amok (Lakes state), displacing 2,738 people. The source does not mention whether there were any fatalities or casualties, and does not explain the reason for the clashes.

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 17 February 2020, youths continued to protest in Renk town (Upper Nile state), following the dissolving of the controversial 32 states system in favour of a return to a modified version of the 10 states system. NSS and SSPDF were reported to have arrested several youth, with the mayor of Renk also being arrested by the NSS. [size=at least several]

As reported on 17 February 2020, a group of men in military uniforms (coded as army) beat and raped a woman as she gathered firewood in Amica in Magwi county (Eastern Equatoria state). There have been no arrests.

column7: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 February 2020, thousands of pro-government protesters from the Ruweng Dinka community demonstrated at an unspecified location in the defunct Ruweng state (presumed to be former state capital Paraing, Unity state), in support of the new Ruweng Administrative Area established by the president. [size=thousands]

On 18 February 2020, Lou Nuer militia clashed with Murle in the Nanaam and Bith Bith areas of Pibor county (Jonglei state), amidst repeated violence incidents between the two groups. There are no currently no reports on fatalities, although 30 families have fled to Bor county. One event coded.
On 19 February 2020, raiders from the Jalwau area of Tonj East county attacked Abar in Tonj South (Warrap state), killing one and wounding another, and stealing 350 head of cattle.

On or around 19 February 2020, raiders from the Thiik community of Tonj East county attacked members of the Jalwau community at an unspecified location (note that the central population centre of the Jalwau is Wunlit, Torit East county, Warrap state). Three people were killed and two injured, with members of both groups sustaining casualties.

column6: Apuk Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On or around 19 February 2020, Apuk clan raiders operating in conjunction with armed youth from the Thony community of Tonj South county attacked the Wanhalel community at an unspecified location in their home area in Tonj South (Warrap state). Three were killed, and two wounded.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column7: Gajaak-Eastern Jikany Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 19 February 2020, an SPLM-IO splinter faction aligned with the government and operating in conjunction with Cie-Waw militia (a sub-section of the Gajaak Nuer section of the Eastern Jikany Nuer) killed two civilians at an unspecified location of Maiwut county (Upper Nile state), presumed to be close to Jikou. The killings are said to have been targeted at supporters of regular IO forces in the area.

On 20 February 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from the Fangak area) attacked a cattle camp at Werashu (assumed Werthou) near Duk Padiet (Jonglei state), killing one and wounding another. 100 head of cattle were stolen, although these were later recovered by local youth.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 21 February 2020, a senior doctor was abducted from Aweil town (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state) by four Military Intelligence personnel, who tortured him at a nearby military facility. The doctor explained the attack as relating to an ongoing embezzlement case at the hospital.

On 21 February, two national INGO staff were seriously injured when their vehicle was ambushed by unknown armed men on the Tonj-Cueibet Road in Warrap. Reports indicate they were able to escape the attack in the vehicle.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Abu Tira
column17: On 21 February 2020, around 30 armed members associated with a branch of the Central Reserve Police/Abu Tira paramilitary force engaged in clashes with Sudanese soldiers in the disputed town of Kafia Kingi (Western Bahr el Ghazal state). Varying reports of fatalities suggest that two SAF soldiers were killed and three wounded and that three Abu Tira paramilitaries were killed and one wounded (note that some estimates are higher, and include civilian casualties).

On 21 February 2020, Sudanese soldiers fired upon three miners (reportedly linked to the Central Reserve Police/Abu Tira paramilitary force) after they ran a checkpoint at the disputed town of Kafia Kingi (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), wounding two.

On 22 February 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked Panyim in Nyirol county (Jonglei state), killing one elderly lady, wounding another civilian, and abducted three children (the victims are likely to be of Lou Nuer ethnicity). The attackers stole a small number of livestock, and burned dwellings and killed sheep.
On 22 February 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked Dakriang in Nyirol county (Jonglei state), wounding one (likely of Lou Nuer ethnicity). There is no further information.

column16: Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor
column17: On 22 February 2020, farmers from Kuajiena county in the defunct Wau state attacked armed pastoralists from Tonj at a water point at Akou near Maper in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), leading to a firefight which killed 1 and wounded between 3 and 5 people.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (Pakam Section) (South Sudan)
column17: On 22 February 2020, armed youth (suspected of being from the Pakam Dinka section of the Agar clan) attacked a health centre in Malek in Rumbek Central county (Lakes state), killing a doctor and burning his body. They then looted the facility and nearby properties.

On 22 February 2020, unknown gunmen attacked and wounded three travelling on the road between Juba and Nesitu (Central Equatoria state) at the Jebel Amiyan area. One of the victims was a police officer (assumed off-duty).

On 23 February 2020, Dok Nuer raiders attacked an unspecified location in Leer county (Unity state), prompting a fire fight between (Dok Nuer) cattle guards. At least six were reported to have been killed and two missing, with three of the attackers arrested. No cattle were taken.

On or around 23 February 2020, amidst ongoing clashes between farmers and pastoralists from Tonj in the Mapel area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), armed pastoralists raped a female farmer. The source does not mention whether other casualties or fatalities occurred when the pastoralists launched a retaliatory attack against farmers, following clashes on 22 Feb.

column6: Malual Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 23 February 2020, Malual Dinka hunters (note that one source reports that SSPDF soldiers rather than hunters were involved) clashed with Rizaygat pastoralists near Nyinbuoli in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), with two Rizaygat pastoralists killed and two hunters wounded. The attack is linked to an unspecified dispute.

On 22 or 23 February 2020, raiders from an unspecified area attacked Tabur payam in Tonj East county (Warrap state), killing one, wounding one, and abducting five women (who were released the same day). The attackers also stole 350 head of cattle.
On 25 February 2020, Murle raiders attacked Waat in Nyirol county (Jonglei state), killing six, and wounding 13 (the victims are likely to be of Lou Nuer ethnicity). 250 head of cattle were stolen.

On 25 February 2020, the driver of an INGO vehicle was ambushed by a group of unknown armed men while travelling on the Kapoeta-Budi Road in Eastern Equatoria. The staff member sustained a gunshot wound to the leg and was robbed once the vehicle stopped.

column9: Malual Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 25 February 2020, Sudanese Misseriya militiamen killed three Malual Dinka civilians and wounded a woman at Mathiang-Bul in the northern area of Baac payam in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state). Compensation has now been paid by the Misseriya, as of 22 April.

column9: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 26 February 2020, Murle raiders attacked Waat in Nyirol county (Jonglei state), clashing with Lou Nuer militiamen, SSPDF soldiers and police. 16 were killed (eight defenders, two of whom died later, and eight attackers), and 11 wounded. The violence comes amidst a spate of raids in the area.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (Pakam Section) (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (Ruop Section) (South Sudan)
column17: On or before 26 February 2020, two sections of the Agar Dinka clan (the Ruop and Pakam) clashed at unspecified location(s) (likely in the area of Malek, Lakes state, and potentially other locations), resulting in almost 200 households being displaced. The clashes are reportedly linked to a land dispute. The source makes no mention of fatalities or casualties.
On 27 February 2020, armed local youth shot and killed a police officer at Mambolo 40 km from Wulu town (Lakes state). The motive for the attack is unclear.
On 28 February 2020, women marched in Bor (Jonglei state), calling for the 35% quota on women in the newly constituted Government of National Unity to be honoured. [size=no report]

column7: Kuei-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Athoi-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Panyar-Gok Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 29 February 2020, raiders from three Agar Dinka sections (the Pakam, Kuei and Athoi (Gony subsection)) attacked cattle camps in Marial Bek (Rumbek East county, Lakes state), engaging with armed youth from the Rupo section of the Agar Dinka and the Panyar section of the Gok Dinka. At least 14 were killed (8 Ruop and Panyar; 5 Pakam, 1 Athoi), over 20 were wounded, and 300 head of cattle stolen (but later recovered).

column9: Murle Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 29 February 2020, attackers (presumed to be Lou Nuer given their attacks against Murle targets in the area over the past two weeks) raided Manyireng village in Pibor county (Jonglei state), stealing cattle. The report does not mention whether there were fatalities.

column16: Radio Miraya; SSBC TV; Radio Tamazuj; UNMISS; ICRC
column17: On and/or around 1 March 2020, Lou Nuer raiders clashed with Murle fighters in Bolotinganu (Jonglei state) amidst serious clashes between thousands of Murle and Lou Nuer armed men in and around Pibor. MSF and ICRC reports indicate that at least 100 people have been treated for gunshot wounds in the various events, although there is no information on fatalities.

column16: UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya; ICRC; SSBC TV
column17: On or before 1 March 2020, Lou Nuer raiders seized the town of Likuangole (Jonglei state) amidst serious clashes between thousands of Murle and Lou Nuer armed men in and around Pibor. MSF and ICRC reports indicate that at least 100 people have been treated for gunshot wounds in the various events, although there is no information on fatalities.

column16: Radio Miraya; SSBC TV; ICRC; Radio Tamazuj; UNMISS
column17: On and/or around 1 March 2020, Lou Nuer raiders clashed with Murle fighters in Lokurmach (Jonglei state) amidst serious clashes between thousands of Murle and Lou Nuer armed men in and around Pibor. MSF and ICRC reports indicate that at least 100 people have been treated for gunshot wounds in the various events, although there is no information on fatalities.

column16: ICRC; SSBC TV; UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On 1 March 2020, attackers (presumed to be Lou Nuer given their attacks against Murle targets in the area over the past two weeks) raided Manyabol village in Pibor county (Jonglei state), amidst ongoing violence in the area. The attackers abducted civilians and killed at least one person, with others being reported as missing.

On 1 March 2020, members of the Thony community clashed with the Apuk and Yar communities in the area of Majakot in Tonj South county (Warrap state), with at least 9 being killed, and around 21 wounded. The clashes are reported to be based on a land dispute.

column16: Radio Miraya; UNMISS; UNOCHA; Radio Tamazuj; SSBC TV; ICRC
column17: On or before 1 March 2020, Lou Nuer raiders seized the town of Likuangole (Jonglei state) amidst serious clashes between thousands of Murle and Lou Nuer armed men in and around Pibor. MSF and ICRC reports indicate that at least 100 people have been treated for gunshot wounds in the various events. Whilst there is no precise death toll, a UNOCHA update states that ""Dead bodies of humans and animals are reportedly in the streets in Likuangole town"".

On and/or around 1 March 2020, Lou Nuer raiders clashed with Murle fighters in unspecified areas of Akobo county (Jonglei state, event(s) presumed to be in the southern part of the county near Pibor county) amidst serious clashes between thousands of Murle and Lou Nuer armed men in and around Pibor. MSF and ICRC reports indicate that at least 100 people have been treated for gunshot wounds in the various events, although there is no information on fatalities.

On 2 March 2020, members of the Thiik, Akook and Jalwau communities clashed in the area of the Acuk cattle camp in Tonj East county (Warrap state), killing at least 26 (on both sides, as well as women and children) and wounding around 22. Dwellings were torched, and an unspecified number have been displaced. There is no clear reason for the fighting at present.

On 2 March 2020, an international NGO vehicle was attacked by unknown armed youths near Chueideng on the road between Yuai and Pieri in Uror county (Jonglei state), killing a contractor and wounding the driver. The youths were said to be conducted cattle raids in the area when they attacked the vehicle.

On 2 March 2020, unknown attackers fired upon a vehicle belonging to a British NGO in the Pieri area of Uror county (Jonglei state), killing a woman and wounding the driver of the vehicle. Three other passengers escaped. There is no further information on the attack.

On 3 March 2020, gunmen (suspected of coming from the Greater Pibor area, and recorded as Murle) abducted five civilians (likely of Lou Nuer ethnicity), including three children (who were the progeny of a local chief), at Partet village in Pamai paym in Uror county (Jonglei state).

On 3 March 2020, youth from the Duk Padiet area clashed with the unknown raiders who had earlier abducted children, at an unspecified location near Duk Padiet in Duk county (Jonglei state). One of the Duk youth was killed and another wounded, and two children were recovered. One child remains with the captors.

On 3 March 2020, unknown raiders abducted three children and killed one child at an unspecified location along the road between Duk Padiet and Panaru in Duk county (Jonglei state). The identity of the attackers is unclear.

On 5 March 2020, Jie raiders attacked Murle settlements at an unspecified area (or areas) in Marow/Maruo payam of eastern Pibor county (Jonglei state), killing one, wounding two, and setting dwellings on fire. Around 27,500 cows were reported to have been seized.

On 6 March 2020, an unknown group attacked one (or several) 'security' personnel (recorded as army) and a civilian at Lohiari Boma in Iyire payam in Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state), wounding two (including one of the security personnel). The circumstances of the attack are unclear, but it appears to relate to efforts by local authorities to prevent illegal logging activities in the area.

column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Miraya; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 8 March 2020, opponents of the new Archbishop of Juba attacked a Friar at the cathedral in Kator (central Juba), wounding him, before preparing to march from the cathedral grounds to denounce the new Archbishop. Police and military forces intervened, arresting five. [size=at least five]

On 8 March 2020, a truck carrying an SSPDF soldier, a Kenyan truck driver and a co-driver of unspecified nationality was attacked by unknown gunmen at Makuei on the Cuiebet-Tonj road in Tonj South county (Warrap state). The attackers killed the driver, but fled once the soldier returned fire.

On 8 March 2020, an unknown militia attacked Yikana village in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal). Around 800 people were displaced between this and a subsequent attack on 15 March. The attack comes amid tensions between pastoralists and farmers in the area, which has involved pastoralist militias from neighbouring Tonj.

On 8 March 2020, an unspecified youth militia attacked pastoralists at Dhiaj (and possibly other areas in the vicinity) (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), reportedly in response to the killing of a trader the previous day. At least two were killed (including a chief of the cattle camp) and several wounded.

On or around 8 March 2020, violence - likely involving Murle attacks against Lou Nuer - continued in Uror and Nyirol counties of Jonglei state, with at least 68 wounded Lou Nuer arriving in Pieri (Uror county).

On or around 8 March 2020, violence - likely involving Murle attacks against Lou Nuer - continued in Uror and Nyirol counties of Jonglei state, with at least 15 wounded Lou Nuer arriving in Lankien (Nyirol county), including a woman whose unborn baby was killed when her stomach was slashed with a bladed weapon.

On 9 March 2020, raiders from Iloli village attacked Hiyala in the east of Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state), stealing goats. Two people were killed between this and a subsequent event in Iloli (where one of the fatalities was confirmed). Fatalities split across both events.

On or after 9 March 2020, armed militia from Hiyala entered Iloli village to retrieve stolen goats. Upon retrieving the animals, the militia killed a woman on the road to Burung close to Iloli in the east of Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state). One other person was killed between this and the previous event in Hiyala. Fatalities split across both events.

On 9 March 2020, 'unknown gunmen' shot and killed a woman at her home in the Jebel Keer neighbourhood of Wau city (Western Bahr el Ghazal state) whilst her family were present. There is no established motive at this time.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Fishermen (South Sudan)
column17: On 11 March 2020, an unknown group from Sudan attacked an unspecified fishing village in Abiemnom county (Unity state), killing three and seriously wounding three (all likely to be members of the Ruweng Dinka clan). There is no clear motive for the attack.

column9: Twic Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or before 11 March 2020, raiders from Unity state (presumed to be Bul Nuer, based on previous raids in the area) attacked the area of Majok Noon in Twic county (Warrap state), killing one and wounding three (all victims presumed to be Twic Dinka). There is no further information.

column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); WFP: World Food Programme
column17: On 13 March 2020, unknown armed youth attacked a WFP truck in or near Maper town in Rumbek North county (Lakes state), killing two civilians (including a mother who was breastfeeding). The attackers then stole from the survivors.
On 13 March 2020, an unknown armed group shot and killed a man in Zambago village in Yambio county (Western Equatoria state). There is no further information.

column9: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (Sudan)
column16: Radio Miraya; Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 13 or 14 March 2020, unknown gunmen killed two elderly Agar Dinka men as they slept outside Gun cattle camp (which they are presumed to have been guarding) in the Marial Bek area of Rumbek East county (Lakes state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

column9: Miners (South Sudan); Lujulu Communal Group (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 13 or 14 March 2020, the chief of Lujulu payam was killed in either Wudabi village of Wudabi payam in Morobo county (Central Equatoria) or Kolobgo village (presumed to be in or near Lujulu payam, Central Equatoria state), reportedly for mobilizing refugees to return home after the recent formation of the unity government. Two women have also been abducted in the area. Local authorities have accused NAS rebels of being responsible, with the rebels in turn accusing SSPDF soldiers of killing the chief when they attacked mine workers in Kologbo.

column7: Aliamtoc-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Kuei-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Pakam-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On 14 March 2020, Agar Dinka from the Kuei and Pakam sections and the Gony and Dhiei subsections (of the Athoi and Aliamtoc sections) clashed with the Ruop section in one or more locations in the Marial Bek area of Rumbek East county (Lakes state), reportedly in retaliation for the recent killing of two elderly men at Gun cattle camp. At least 41 were reported dead (although estimates do not state whether the two elderly men are counted in this figure) and around 60 injured.

On 15 or 16 March 2020, gunmen (suspected of coming from the Thony community of Tonj South county) attacked fishermen at an unspecified area of the River Tonj east of Tonj town (Warrap state), killing one and wounding two.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), NAS rebels clashed with SSPDF at Lorega village in Mukaya payam close to Roronyo (Central Equatoria state), displacing 6,021 civilians in the process. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), cattle keepers from Tonj clashed with Luo farmers in various locations in western areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Aluelagok, Cueiajei and Koorping (and potentially other locations in the western border area with Jur River county). The dispute are linked to contested land for grazing purposes, and displaced 6,149 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), cattle keepers from Tonj clashed with Luo farmers in various locations in western areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Aluelagok, Cueiajei and Koorping (and potentially other locations in the western border area with Jur River county). The dispute are linked to contested land for grazing purposes, and displaced 6,149 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), cattle keepers from Tonj clashed with Luo farmers in various locations in western areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Aluelagok, Cueiajei and Koorping (and potentially other locations in the western border area with Jur River county). The dispute are linked to contested land for grazing purposes, and displaced 6,149 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), cattle keepers from Tonj clashed with Luo farmers in various locations in western areas of Tonj South county (Warrap state), including Aluelagok, Cueiajei and Koorping (and potentially other locations in the western border area with Jur River county). The dispute are linked to contested land for grazing purposes, and displaced 6,149 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Around 15 March 2020 (month of), 3 women were raped by SSPDF soldiers in Lasu payam in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). 4 soldiers have been arrested, and confessed to the attack.

column16: Radio Miraya; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj
column17: Around 15 March 2020 (month of), SSPDF soldiers were implicated in the rape of around 19 women in Libogo, Rubeke and the areas of Otogo and Lasu across Yei county (Central Equatoria state).

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: Around 15 March 2020 (month of), 6 women were raped by SSPDF soldiers in Rubeke village in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). No arrests have been made.

On 15 March 2020, an unspecified armed group attacked Yikana village in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal). Around 800 people were displaced between this and a prior attack on 8 March. The attack comes amid tensions between pastoralists and farmers in the area, which has involved pastoralist militias from neighbouring Tonj. There is no mention of casualties or fatalities in the source.

On 16 March 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from Cueibet county) attacked Monjol village in Tonj South county (Warrap state), killing at least two, wounding three, and stealing around 2,000 head of cattle. A search party of five youths from the village that had been tracking the stolen animals was also reported to be missing.

On or before 17 March 2020, armed men in military uniform killed two in the Dhia area of the defunct Tonj state (Warrap state). There is no further information. Further attacks were carried out on several villages in the Chuei-Aja area in the defunct Tonj state (Warrap state). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities, though notes than 300 head of cattle were stolen.

On or around 17 March 2020, a Dinka spear-master (of unspecified lineage) was shot and killed by unknown gunmen as he was driving to Abiriu in Cueibet county (Lakes state). Another man on the same motorbike was wounded.

column8: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 17 March 2020, raiders suspected of coming from the defunct Northern Liech state (and likely of Bul Nuer ethnicity) attacked Malual-Adior cattle camp in Gogrial East county (Warrap state). In a firefight with youths from the Rek Dinka-inhabited area, two Rek Dinka were killed and eight wounded (three seriously, with two young girls among the wounded), before the attackers were repulsed.

On 17 March 2020, unknown armed youths attacked farmers in an unspecified area near Mapel in Kuajena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), killing one and wounding three. That attack comes amid a high level of violence involving raiders from Western Bahr el Ghazal and Tonj county.

On or around 17 March 2020, violence - likely involving Murle attacks against Lou Nuer - occurred in parts of Nyirol county, with attacks reported in the area around Thol (Jonglei state). The source makes no mention of casualties or fatalities, though notes that 2,000 people were displaced to Khorfulus town between this event and similar attacks in Pulturuk and Pieri.

On or around 17 March 2020, violence - likely involving Murle attacks against Lou Nuer - occurred in parts of Nyirol county, with attacks reported in the area around Pulturuk (Jonglei state). The source makes no mention of casualties or fatalities, though notes that 2,000 people were displaced to Khorfulus town between this event and similar attacks in Thol and Pieri.

On or around 17 March 2020, violence - likely involving Murle attacks against Lou Nuer - occurred in Uror county, with attacks reported in the area around Pieri (Jonglei state). The source makes no mention of casualties or fatalities, though notes that 2,000 people were displaced to Khorfulus town between this event and similar attacks in nearby Niyrol county.

column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 March 2020, raiders suspected of coming from the defunct Northern Liech state (and likely of Bul Nuer ethnicity) attacked villages around the Malual-Adior cattle camp in the Rek Dinka-inhabited Gogrial East county (Warrap state), burning houses. No injuries or fatalities occurred.

column7: Ngok Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 19 March 2020, Misseriya pastoralists were attacked by Bul Nuer youth (who the Misseriya allege were operating alongside Ngok Dinka) at an unspecified location in north-western Mayom county (Unity state). 10 Bul Nuer and 12 Misseriya were killed in the clash.

On 20 March 2020, raiders suspected of coming from the Cueibet area (and likely belonging to the Gok Dinka clan) attacked Lool-Akool cattle camp in Tonj South county (Warrap state), clashing with armed pastoralists from the area. Between 55 and 67 people were killed on both sides, and an unspecified number were wounded.
On 23 March 2020, communal violence between youths of Tonj-East and Tonj-South counties in Tonj town (Tonj South, Warrap) led to the deaths of two youths.
On 24 March 2020, five people were killed during fighting between Gak and Manuer sub-sections of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka, at an unspecified location in Rumbek North county (Lakes state).

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 25 March 2020, two NAS rebel soldiers on leave from combat duties were abducted by SPLM-IO soldiers at Liruba village in Yei county (Central Equatoria state), according to a statement released by the NAS. One source indicates the NAS attacked the position twice, which is presumed to have occurred on the same day given information in the other source.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; BBC News; Catholic Radio Network; Radio Miraya; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 25 March 2020, the South Sudanese government introduced a partial daytime lockdown, and a nationwide night-time curfew, in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Schools were closed and restrictions on internal and external flights introduced, along with quarantining measures. Military re-training and integration exercises (required under the terms of the peace agreement) were also suspended. On 22 April, lockdown measures and border closures (some of which had been intended to last six weeks) were extended indefinitely. On 7 May, lockdown measures were eased in spite of rising cases of coronavirus, specifically with regards to transport (and air travel) and a relaxing of the curfew.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 25 March 2020, the National Salvation Front (NAS) accused the SPLM-IO of raping a woman and her daughter during attacks that took place in Moya village in Lasu Payam of Yei county (Central Equatoria state) (note that the group initially claimed it was government soldiers). The victims are reported to be the wife and child of a man the soldiers had been intending to arrest.
On 25 March 2020, unknown armed people killed two traders travelling on a motorcycle at an unspecified area of Abiemnom County in the disputed Ruweng administrative area of Unity state.

On 26 March 2020, a high school student was shot dead by soldiers as they attempted to disperse people fighting in Rumbek market (Kuei, Rumbek centre). No reason for the fighting was reported. At least four soldiers from the joint integrated security team were arrested over the killing.

column8: Luach-Jang Rek Sub Clan Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On or before 27 March 2020, clashes between youth from the Luach-Jang section of the Rek Dinka clan of Tonj East and the Manuer subsection of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka of Rumbek North were reported in Rumbek North (Lakes state), resulting in approximately 6 deaths.

On 28 and 29 March 2020, the Gak and Manuer sub-sections of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka clashed in the Malueth area of Rumbek North county (Lakes state), following the killing of two members of the Manuer sub-section on 28 March. At least 13 (one source says at least 17) were killed, and 16 were wounded. It is unclear if the fatality counts in the sources include the two Manuer members killed on 28 March. Fatalities distributed across two events.

On 28 and 29 March 2020, the Gak and Manuer sub-sections of the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka clashed in the Malueth area of Rumbek North county (Lakes state), following the killing of two members of the Manuer sub-section on 28 March. At least 13 (one source says at least 17) were killed, and 16 were wounded. It is unclear if the fatality counts in the sources include the two Manuer members killed on 28 March. Fatalities distributed across two events.

On 29 March 2020, unknown gunmen shot dead the Director of Administration and Finance at the Salva Kiir Mayardit Women's Hospital at his home in Rumbek (Lakes state). There is no clear motive for the killing.

On 30 March 2020, employees of Juba city council (who are implied not to be members of the security services) attacked female market vendors at Konyo Konyo market in the Hai Malakal area of Juba, beating them with sticks. The attack is linked to coronavirus enforcement measures, but the source notes that the women were not violating the order, as food vendors are permitted to continue operating. There are no reports of serious injuries. [size=no report]

column9: Akook-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 April 2020, three sections of the Rek Dinka clan (the Jalwau, Akook and Thiik) clashed at an unspecified area of Tonj South county (Warrap state). 4 people were killed, and 12 wounded. Note that it is unclear who was fighting who, and the reason for fighting is not mentioned.

column9: Akook-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 2 April 2020, three sections of the Rek Dinka clan (the Jalwau, Akook and Thiik) clashed at the Ameth Chok cattle camp in Tonj South county (Warrap state), during a second day of fighting in the region. 3 people were killed, and 1 was injured. Note that it is unclear who was fighting who, and the reason for fighting is not mentioned.
As reported on 3 April 2020, unknown gunmen abducted at least 107 civilians (mainly youth) from Mukaya payam in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). There is no further information.

On 4 April 2020 (one source suggests a time around 9 April 2020), two women and four girls (one source says three women and three girls) went missing in the area of Mayom-Juriir in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), whilst they were harvesting gum arabic from a nearby woodland. Their bodies were found a week later, with a source indicating they were killed by unknown armed elements. Unconfirmed rumours attribute the attacks to Misseriya pastoralists, although information is currently scarce.

On 5 April 2020, unknown gunmen abducted two young men from Malith village in Rumbek East county (Lakes state). Within a few days, the men - alongside five other men - either escaped, or were released or rescued.
On 5 April 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed a South Sudanese NGO staff member in Wath area of Nyirol county (Jonglei state). There is no further information.

On 6 and 7 April 2020, two (or more) groups clashed in the areas of Khor Machar, Wechgatluak Rik and Torbar in Maiwut county (Jonglei state). There are disputed accounts of the actors involved; local authorities say that Gatjiok and Gatjaak sections of the Eastern Jikany Nuer were involved in clashes surrounding cattle raids, which may have involved SPLM-IO rebels. Former IO rebels under Maj. Gen James Ochan, who defected to the government last year, claim they were attacked by IO rebel forces, with three IO defectors wounded. The IO deny any involvement. The source does not mention fatalities.

On 6 and 7 April 2020, two (or more) groups clashed in the areas of Khor Machar, Wechgatluak Rik and Torbar in Maiwut county (Jonglei state). There are disputed accounts of the actors involved; local authorities say that Gatjiok and Gatjaak sections of the Eastern Jikany Nuer were involved in clashes surrounding cattle raids, which may have involved SPLM-IO rebels. Former IO rebels under Maj. Gen James Ochan, who defected to the government last year, claim they were attacked by IO rebel forces, with three IO defectors wounded. The IO deny any involvement. The source does not mention fatalities.

On 6 April 2020, a large number of unknown raiders attacked a kraal south of Torit (implied to be close to Torit town), along the road to Katiri (Eastern Equatoria state), killing the woman who owned the kraal, and seizing 21 head of cattle.

On 6 and 7 April 2020, two (or more) groups clashed in the areas of Khor Machar, Wechgatluak Rik and Torbar in Maiwut county (Jonglei state). There are disputed accounts of the actors involved; local authorities say that Gatjiok and Gatjaak sections of the Eastern Jikany Nuer were involved in clashes surrounding cattle raids, which may have involved SPLM-IO rebels. Former IO rebels under Maj. Gen James Ochan, who defected to the government last year, claim they were attacked by IO rebel forces, with three IO defectors wounded. The IO deny any involvement. The source does not mention fatalities.

On 6 and 7 April 2020, two (or more) groups clashed in the areas of Khor Machar, Wechgatluak Rik and Torbar in Maiwut county (Jonglei state). There are disputed accounts of the actors involved; local authorities say that Gatjiok and Gatjaak sections of the Eastern Jikany Nuer were involved in clashes surrounding cattle raids, which may have involved SPLM-IO rebels. Former IO rebels under Maj. Gen James Ochan, who defected to the government last year, claim they were attacked by IO rebel forces, with three IO defectors wounded. The IO deny any involvement. The source does not mention fatalities.

column9: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: On 7 April 2020, unspecified security forces (presumed to be army, given their recent activity in the same location) assaulted a South Sudanese employee of UNMISS at UN House on the outskirts of Juba, preventing them from entering the compound. The attacks come as SSPDF were reported to have been prevented IDPs from leaving the camp, having accused them of being infected with coronavirus.

As reported on 7 April 2020, unspecified security forces (assumed to be police) were reported to have engaged in multiple beatings of civilians in Bor town (Jonglei state), whilst enforcing the coronavirus night-time curfew.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 9 April 2020, NAS rebels attacked SPLM-IO rebels at their position in Kinyira in Mugwo payam, Yei county (Central Equatoria state), following what the NAS alleged is a spate of attacks against civilians (including civilians linked to the NAS) in the area. The SPLM-IO have stated that they lost one soldier during the attack, while the NAS have not announced whether they had any casualties or fatalities.

On 9 April 2020, the Panyar and Waat/Wat sub-sections of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clan clashed in the area of Alangtit in Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least 9 (7 from the Waat, 2 from Panyar) and wounding 15. A local official stated the clash was linked to ongoing revenge killings and cattle raiding.
As reported on 10 April 2020, unknown raiders attacked an unspecified cattle camp in Yirol East county (Lakes state), killing at least one, and stealing nearly 50 head of cattle.

On 11 April 2020, relatives of a cattle thief, who was killed the previous day, clashed with armed pastoralists responsible for his killing, likely in the area of Maleis and Mading Bor in Rumbek East county (Lakes state). 4 were killed, and 5 injured.

On 12 April 2020, the Panyar and Waat/Wat sub-sections of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clan clashed at a cattle camp in the Thiep Thiep/Tiap Tiap area of Citcok payam in Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least 9 (2 from the Waat, and 7 from the Panyar) and wounding 13. The clash was reportedly linked to a land dispute.

Around 12 April 2020 (week of), members of the Jalwau and Thiik sections of the Rek Dinka (one source mentions the involvement of the Akook section, but this is not confirmed) clashed at an unspecified area of Tonj East county (Warrap state), killing at least 8 and wounding 11. 8 women were raped, and dwellings and food stores were torched. 15 have been arrested.
On 12 April 2020, a South Sudanese NGO staff member was killed by unknown cattle raiders at or near the Pamot cattle camp in Twic East county (Jonglei state). There is no further information.

On or before 12 April 2020, attackers from Unity state (and presumed to be Bul Nuer, given contextual information in the source) attacked an unspecified area in Tonj North county (Warrap state), presumed to be in an eastern area of the county near the Unity state border. At least 10 were killed in the clashes (of unspecified ethnicity), and 25 wounded. Cattle were also stolen.

column8: Twic Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 14 April 2020, raiders from Unity state (and presumed to be of Bul Nuer ethnicity, given their frequent attacks in the same area) attacked an unspecified cattle camp in Ajakuac payam in Twic county (Warrap state). In the firefight with local Twic Dinka youth, 7 Twic Dinka and 1 of the attackers were killed. Three Twic Dinkas were also injured.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok, and Majokawet, displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok, and Majokawet, displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute.
