The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok, and Majokawet, displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok, and Majokawet, displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok (near Ngabagok), and Majokawet (near Ngabagok), displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column9: Kongor-Rek Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the Thiik sub-section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Jalwau and Kongor Rek sub-sections in various locations in Tonj East county (Warrap state), reportedly over a land dispute. Violence affected the locations of Wunlit, Mideer, Mading, Pajoot, Angohek, Malual-Cum, Matiok, and Majokawet, displacing 30,499 as a result of the clashes. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), NAS rebels were reported to have abducted an unspecified number of civilians in the area of Kuji (presumed to be a misspelling of Wuji, Lainya county, Central Equatoria state).
Around 15 April 2020 (month of), NAS rebels were reported to have abducted an unspecified number of civilians in the area of Rasolo in Yei county (Central Equatoria state).

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), unspecified raiders (implied to be Nuer) attacked Ruweng Dinka youth cattle guards at Wakyar cattle camp in the disputed Ruweng Administrative Area (comprising three counties of Unity state), with the Ruweng repulsing the attackers. There is no information regarding casualties or fatalities.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), Misseriya pastoralists killed a child at an unspecified area of the disputed Ruweng Administrative Area (coordinates for the disputed area capital Pariang used), amid deteriorating relations between the Ruweng Dinka and Misseriya. Compensation has since been paid.

column16: CTSAMM; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; VOA; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 17 April 2020, SSPDF soldiers deployed in Mukaya payam in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state) were reported to have beaten (and attacked with knives) civilians in the area, whom they accused of supporting NAS rebels, and burned dwellings and looted from the inhabitants. Over 3,000 civilians were displaced to Yei town (one source says 7,000). The SSPDF deny the accusation, and say that residents fled out of fear of a confrontation between government and rebel troops.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column9: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network; Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 17 April 2020, the Kok/Kook section of the Agar Dinka clan attacked members of the Duor section of the Agar Dinka at Malek cattle camp in Rumbek East county of Lakes state (note that the payam in which Malek cattle camp is location in is unspecified), killing three. Around two dozen were wounded between this attack and a clash the next day between the Kok and Duor sections.

column9: Twic East Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 or 19 April 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked an area to the west of Wanglei in Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing three, including an elderly man (victims are presumed to be Twic East Dinka).

column9: Lou Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 or 19 April 2020, suspected Murle raiders carried out two attacks on the Lou Nuer town of Pathai in Uror county (Jonglei state), killing two people and abducting two female children.

column9: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 or 19 April 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked the area of Baidit in Bor South county (Jonglei state), killing one youth (the victim is presumed to be Bor Dinka).

column7: Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column9: Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On 18 April 2020, the Duor section of the Agar Dinka clan attacked members of the Kok/Kook section of the Agar Dinka at Malek cattle camp in Rumbek East county of Lakes state (note that the payam in which Malek cattle camp is location in is unspecified). In the ensuing clashes, at least 13 were killed and around two dozen injured (including a police officer who was killed, and a soldier who was wounded. Note that the circumstances of their involvement is uncertain).
On 18 or 19 April 2020, unknown gunmen killed four members of the same family at an unspecified location in Manyang-Ngok payam of Tonj South county (Warrap state). There is no further information.

On 19 April 2020, unspecified ethnic sub-sections (presumed to be members of the Lotuko/Otuho ethnic group resident in the area) clashed at Burung village in Iloli boma in Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state), after attackers stole several hundred cows. Two were killed (one from each side), and two wounded.

column9: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 19 April 2020, unknown gunmen attacked two pastoralists (presumed to be Bor Dinka) as they travelled in Baidit payam (Jonglei state) to Pariak swamp within the payam, killing one.
On 19 April 2020, a young girl was raped by a group of pastoralists at a river bank in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria state). There is no further information on the identity of the attackers.

On 20 April 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a boda boda driver who was travelling with three passengers at an unspecified location on the road to Manyang-Ngok payam in Tonj South county (Warrap state), killing one person. There is no further information.

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or around 20 April 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked an unspecified area near Bor town (Jonglei state), killing two (presumed to be Bor Dinka), and looting cattle.

On 20 and 21 April 2020, attackers from Panyijar county (presumed to be Nyong Nuer) attacked a cattle camp at an unspecified location in Dok Nuer-inhabited Mayendit county (Unity state), leading to two days of fighting which resulted in 7 deaths and 4 wounded (fatalities spread across two events). 20,000 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen during the fighting.

column16: VOA; Crisis Tracker; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 20 April 2020, LRA rebels entered several areas of Western Equatoria state, in the vicinity of Sakure payam (and possibly in adjacent areas of southern Yambio county). LRA fighters were reported to have killed a soldier and a civilian boda boda driver in the areas of Duru and Kipaika (phonetic spelling used). LRA fighters were also reported to have abducted an unspecified number of civilians near a river in the area, and to have looted a market 4km south of Sakure. ""Scores"" have been displaced to Sakure town and Dungu camp in the DRC One local official has disputed claims that LRA have re-entered South Sudan.

column9: Labour Group (South Sudan); Gok Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 20 April 2020, unknown gunmen killed a cattle trader and wounded a companion (both from the Waat subsection of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka) in the area of Akuryiei in Ngap payam of Cueibet county (Lakes state). The attack is reported to have been a revenge attack.

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Twic East Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On or around 21 April 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked an area near Panyagor in Twic East county (Jonglei state), stealing 80 head of cattle.

On 20 and 21 April 2020, attackers from Panyijar county (presumed to be Nyong Nuer) attacked a cattle camp at an unspecified location in Dok Nuer-inhabited Mayendit county (Unity state), leading to two days of fighting which resulted in 7 deaths and 4 wounded (fatalities spread across two events). 20,000 head of cattle were reported to have been stolen during the fighting.

On 21 April 2020, Mundari militiamen (either the perpetrators or victims of an attack in Tali payam the same day) attacked the Mundari settlement of Mejiki in Terekeka county (Central Equatoria state), torching around 500 dwellings, and killing a boy who was trapped in burning house. Hundreds were displaced to nearby villages between this attack and another the same day in Tali payam.

On 21 April 2020, a Mundari militia - comprising relatives of a girl who was shot dead by a gunmen at a wrestling match at Golo the previous day - attacked another Mundari community they held responsible for her death at an unspecified location in Tali payam in Terekeka county (Central Equatoria state), killing at least six. Hundreds were displaced between this attack and another the same day.

column9: Fishermen (South Sudan); Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 21 April 2020, suspected Bul Nuer gunmen attacked Ruweng Dinka fishermen at a river near a location described as 'Abang Abang' in Abiemnhom county in Unity state (note that the source may have confused Abang in western Abiemnhom with Bang Bang payam in eastern Abiemnhom, both of which are close to rivers), killing 5 and wounding 1. There is no clear motive for the attack.

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Aliab Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 22 April 2020 (week of), raiders from Yirol East county attacked a cattle camp at an unspecified location of Awerial county in Yirol state (location presumed to be close to the border with Yirol East county), wounding four (presumed to be Aliab Dinka, who reside in the area), and stealing cattle. 75 cattle were recovered in Yirol East the following week, though more are unaccounted for.

Around 22 April 2020 (week of), SSPDF clashed with Mbororo pastoralists at an unspecified area (or areas) of Western Equatoria state (implied by one source to be in the vicinity on Sakure on the DRC border). The sources do not mention whether there were casualties. The pastoralists crossed back into the DRC after the clash.

Around 22 April 2020 (week of), Mbororo pastoralists were reported to have killed at least two individuals (in one or more events) at an unspecified location in Tambura county (Western Equatoria state). There is no further information.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 22 April 2020 (week of), two boda boda drivers were killed at an unspecified location(s) near Rumbek town (Lakes state), reportedly in connection to a series of revenge killings between Agar Dinka sections (presumed to be the attackers).
Around 22 April 2020 (week of), 11 women were gang-raped by men in military uniform (and coded as army) at an unspecified location in Yei county (Central Equatoria state).

On or before 23 April 2020, an unknown communal militia attacked an unspecified area near Ngap-agok in Tonj East (Warrap state), killing one. Security forces apprehended the perpetrators later the same day. There is no further information.

On 24 April 2020, youth from a cattle camp close to Mvolo town (Western Equatoria state) clashed with raiders (suspected of coming from Yirol county) who had earlier killed at least 8 at the cattle camp. One person (implied to be from the raiding group) was killed and two injured.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 24 April 2020, raiders (suspected of coming from Yirol county) attacked a cattle camp close to Mvolo town (Western Equatoria state), killing 10 and wounding approx. 4 to 6 people, and stealing 400 head of cattle.

On 24 April 2020, Major General Matthew Puljang was relieved of his command of the SSPDF Special Forces based in Mayom (Unity state), and the Special Forces have been absorbed into SSPDF Fourth Division. Puljang - a Bul Nuer rebel commander, who has built up a power base in and around Mayom county since joining the army in 2013 - has been summoned to Juba.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column17: As reported to authorities on 24 April 2020, an unspecified number of women at the police training centre at Rejaf (Central Equatoria state) reported that they had been raped by colleagues from the training centre. Large number of police trainees from different armed groups and government forces are being trained at the centre as per the peace agreement.

column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 25 April 2020, armed youth (presumed to be Agar Dinka) killed a police officer at the Abor-Jak/Mabor Jak cattle camp in Maboric boma of Rumbek East county (Lakes state). The police officer had intervened in an attempted theft being carried out by the youth.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 26 April 2020, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels exchanged accusations about an attack on Kala 2 in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS said they lost two soldiers across clashes in Senema (Yei county), Mediba (Morobo county) and Kala 2. SPLM-IO forces acknowledged the loss of one IO soldier and claimed that 12 NAS rebels were killed after they assaulted their position at Kala 2.Three NAS soldiers were also wounded. Three fatalities split across 3 events

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 26 April 2020, SPLM-IO forces claimed they were dislodged from their position at Kiju in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state) by an assault from NAS rebels. The SPLM-IO said it lost two soldiers, and that one was wounded.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 26 April 2020, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels exchanged accusations about an attack on Kala 2 in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS said they lost two soldiers across clashes in Senema (Yei county), Mediba (Morobo county) and Kala 2. SPLM-IO forces acknowledged the loss of one IO soldier and claimed that 12 NAS rebels were killed after they assaulted their position at Kala 2.Three NAS soldiers were also wounded. Three fatalities split across 3 events

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 26 April 2020, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels exchanged accusations about an attack on Kala 2 in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS said they lost two soldiers across clashes in Senema (Yei county), Mediba (Morobo county) and Kala 2. SPLM-IO forces acknowledged the loss of one IO soldier and claimed that 12 NAS rebels were killed after they assaulted their position at Kala 2.Three NAS soldiers were also wounded. Three fatalities split across 3 events

On 27 April 2020, two women were abducted by NAS rebels in the area of Kali (presumed to be at or near Kala) in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state). They were reportedly taken to the Lui area of Western Equatoria.

On 27 April 2020, government troops (presumed to be SSPDF) clashed with NAS rebels at Rasul on the border between Maridi and Mundri West counties (Western Equatoria state), after the NAS were alleged to have looted civilians along the road between the counties, according to a local official. There are no reports of injuries. NAS rebels have denied the claims.
On 27 April 2020, Murle raiders attacked Pamay in southern Uror county (Jonglei state), stealing 4,000 head of cattle, and injuring one.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 27 April 2020, arival armed youths (presumed to be Agar Dinka) clashed in the area of Cuei-Adukan in Rumbek Centre (Lakes state). A police officer was killed and another wounded during the clash under unclear circumstances. There is no mention of casualties or fatalities among the clashing youth groups, in what is implied to be a revenge attack among Agar sections.

column15: Malakal UNMISS Protection of Civilians site
column17: On 27 April 2020, soldiers beat an IDP attempting to leave the Protection of Civilians site in Malakal (Upper Nile state), and also beat butchers who had requested to enter the camp to sell meat, in what appears to be an unofficial coronavirus enforcement measure.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column15: Malakal UNMISS Protection of Civilians site
column17: On 28 April 2020, police and NSS personnel were reported to have beaten IDPs attempting to leave the Protection of Civilians site in Malakal (Upper Nile state), including a female IDP who was beaten in the back and the legs, in what appears to be an unofficial coronavirus enforcement measure.

On 28 April 2020, Murle raiders clashed with armed pastoralists from Pamay cattle camp at an unspecified location in southern Uror county (Jonglei state), who were seeking to recover cattle stolen the previous day. 600 head of cattle were recovered; the source does not mention whether there were any fatalities in the fighting.

On 28 April 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed a civilian travelling in an eastern area of the Himodonge mountains, on a road to Ilieu (and presumed to be in the Lobira area of Ikotos county, Eastern Equatoria state). There is no further information.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 April 2020 (week of), two boda boda drivers were killed in the area of Rumbek (Lakes state), in what are described as instances of revenge killings, amid clashes between various Agar Dinka sections in the area.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 April 2020 (week of), armed youth (presumed to be Agar Dinka) killed a police officer and a civilian in Rumbek (Lakes state), amid a series of incursion into the town by feuding youth.

column6: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column8: Agar Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 April 2020 (between 26 April - 29 April), four were killed and three injured amid revenge killings between different Agar Dinka sections in the Rumbek area (Lakes state). There are no further details.

column8: Boor Clan Balanda Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Balanda Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Farmers (South Sudan)
column17: On 29 April 2020, militiamen from Tonj South county clashed with farmers from Kuajiena payam (presumed to be members of the Boor clan of the Balanda) at an unspecified location in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal), likely close to the border with Tonj South. 3 Balanda were killed and 2 wounded; it is not clear whether there were fatalities from the Tonj militia. The fighting may be connected to a land dispute triggered by the establishment of two payams under the defunct 32 states system, which are no longer in effect.

column8: Boor Clan Balanda Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 April 2020 (week of), armed youth from Tonj South attacked several villages in the Mapel area of Kuajiena county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), leading to clashes with residents of the area (presumed to be of the Boor clan of the Balanda). Three were killed, four wounded, and four villages torched. Thousands were displaced (one source says """"up to ten thousand"""" displaced).

column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 April 2020 (week of), Bul Nuer militia attacked a cattle camp (assumed Rek Dinka) in an unspecified part of Tonj North county (Warrap state), presumed to be close to the border with Mayom county, stealing an unspecified number of cattle.

column7: Tonj North Communal Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), cattle keepers from Tonj South and North counties clashed with farmers (presumed to be of the Lou ethnic group) in eastern areas of Jur River county (Warrap state), in the areas of Mapel, Akou, Akuoyo and Maranya, displacing 836 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column7: Tonj East Communal Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), militias from Tonj South and East counties clashed with farmers (presumed to be of the Lou ethnic group) in eastern areas of Jur River county (Warrap state), in the areas of Tindil, Bobi, Abudugo (near Tumbur) and Magila (near Mapietic), displacing around 4,000 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

column7: Tonj North Communal Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), cattle keepers from Tonj South and North counties clashed with farmers (presumed to be of the Lou ethnic group) in eastern areas of Jur River county (Warrap state), in the areas of Mapel, Akou, Akuoyo and Maranya, displacing 836 people. column17: Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), militias from Tonj South and East counties clashed with farmers (presumed to be of the Lou ethnic group) in eastern areas of Jur River county (Warrap state), in the areas of Tindil, Bobi, Abudugo (near Tumbur) and Magila (near Mapietic), displacing around 4,000 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 30 April 2020 (as reported), suspected SSPDF soldiers killed at least 12 Sudanese Misseriya (including 5 children) and wounded 1 at an unspecified area of Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), likely in revenge for a recent attack on an SSPDF soldier at Majak Wuoi.

Around 30 April 2020 (as reported), Misseriya pastoralists were alleged to have stabbed and wounded an SSPDF soldier at Majak Wuoi in Aweil East (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), and reportedly stole his weapon.

column7: Tonj North Communal Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), cattle keepers from Tonj South and North counties clashed with farmers (presumed to be of the Lou ethnic group) in eastern areas of Jur River county (Warrap state), in the areas of Mapel, Akou, Akuoyo and Maranya, displacing 836 people. The source does not mention casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Dhornor (near Kuernoor) in Guit county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 321 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Yierliar, Dhorduanok, Pagdiek and Luithe (all near to Badak) in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Leek Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 616 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Kuerdeet and Maale (near Kwaich) in Guit county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 151 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Wangrial, Manwanbar, Kur and Kuoyna (the latter three near to Waa) in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clashes. 368 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Dongol, Kuiyrual and at Mapot and Lang (both with approximate coordinates from IOM map) at Mayendit county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Dok Nuer clan, given the location of the clashes. 606 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Nyagarang, Jieklong and Tocgatbal (near Boryien) in Mayom county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Bul Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 1435 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Mathiang 1 or 2, Bornyal (close to Mathiang 1 or 2) and Chotchara 1 in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Leek Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 321 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Mathiang 1 or 2, Bornyal (close to Mathiang 1 or 2) and Chotchara 1 in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Leek Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 321 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Biu in Guit county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. There is no further information.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Dongol, Kuiyrual and at Mapot and Lang (both with approximate coordinates from IOM map) at Mayendit county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Dok Nuer clan, given the location of the clashes. 606 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Tuarkiel, Bool, Mathiara and Wangjuak (the latter three near to Nhialdiu) in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clashes. 412 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Mathiang 1 or 2, Bornyal (close to Mathiang 1 or 2) and Chotchara 1 in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Leek Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 321 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Tor and Biu in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Leek Nuer clan, given the location of the clash. 265 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), communal clashes were reported at Tuarkiel, Bool, Mathiara and Wangjuak (the latter three near to Nhialdiu) in Rubkona county (Unity state), with at least one of the actors presumed to be from the Western Jikany Nuer clan, given the location of the clashes. 412 were displaced; there is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 May 2020 (between 25 April - 8 May), three farmers were killed by unknown persons in Pochalla county (Jonglei state). There is no further information.

column7: Bul Clan Militia (South Sudan); Bul West Communal Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 2 May 2020, unspecified forces loyal to Matthew Puljang (the former commander of the recently dissolved SSPDF Special Forces (a Bul Nuer unit)) attacked the cattle camp of Dam (approximate coordinates for Dom, Twic county, Warrap state). 8 were reported to have died, though the source does not mention whether there was an exchange of fire. The attackers are presumed to be a mixture of soldiers from SSPDF Division 4 and Bul Nuer militia.

column8: Twic Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 2 May 2020, unknown raiders (described as coming from a neighbouring state, and presumed to be Bul Nuer based on the location of the attack (close to the border with Bul Nuer-inhabited areas of Unity state)) attacked a cattle camp and clashed with local militiamen in Pangwok village in Aweng payam in Twic county (Warrap state). During the clash, at least 10 were killed (including several Twic Dinka students serving as cattle guards) and two wounded. 3,000 head of cattle were stolen.

On 5 May 2020, unknown armed youth clashed with unspecified organised forces (presumed to be army) at Warkei in Tonj South county (Warrap state). The youth also killed a mentally-ill civilian, and torched 15 dwellings. An unspecified number have been displaced.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio (South Sudan); South Sudan Voice of Voiceless
column17: On 5 May 2020, NAS rebels were attacked by SSPDF in the area of Katigiti in the Wonduruba area of Juba county (Central Equatoria state). NAS forces claimed to have killed 4 SSPDF.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 5 May 2020 (as reported), SPLM-IO rebels were reported to have beaten and looted from residents (including recently returned refugees) in Wuji village in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). An unspecified number were displaced as a result of the attack. The IO have denied that they have forces in the area.

On 5 May 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked four SSPDF soldiers who were burning charcoal 5km north of Panyagoor village in Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing one soldier. The three other soldiers fled the area.

On 6 May 2020, a ""big number"" of boda boda drivers protested against the coronavirus lockdown measures in Torit town (Eastern Equatoria state), which have prevented them from earning a living. [size=big number]

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 6 May 2020, one or more villages were torched and over 2,000 civilians displaced during a two day battle involving NAS rebels against SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in Jungu boma near Lainya (Central Equatoria state). Both sides are implicated in beatings and burning of villages. A civilian alluded to killings taking place, but there is no clear information on this, nor of any fatalities that may have occurred between the belligerents.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 6 May 2020, SPLM-IO forces clashed with an IO splinter faction that defected to the SSPDF in February in the area of Bagari in Wau county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state). The source does not mention fatalities or casualties.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 6 May 2020, NAS rebels were attacked by SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces near Loka in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). NAS claimed to have destroyed a Technical, although the statement they issued does not mention whether there were any injuries or fatalities.

column6: Boor Clan Balanda Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 6 May 2020 (as reported), militia from the Mapel area of Western Bahr el Ghazal state (presumed Boor clan of the Balanda) attacked a cattle camp in an unspecified area of Tonj South county (Warrap state), presumed to be near the Mapel area. An unspecified number of people were killed, and an unspecified number of cattle looted. Unknown fatalities coded as 3

column6: Boor Clan Balanda Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Rek Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 6 May 2020 (as reported), militia from the Mapel area of Western Bahr el Ghazal state (presumed members of the Boor clan of the Balanda) attacked an unspecified village near Tonj town in Tonj South county (Warrap state). The attackers stole goats from the village. The report makes no mention of fatalities or casualties.

column9: Twic East Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 6 May 2020, unknown raiders attacked an unspecified cattle camp near Wanglei in Kongor payam (Jonglei state), killing 1 pastoralist (victim presumed to be Twic East Dinka), and looting an unspecified number of cattle.

column9: Twic East Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 6 May 2020, unknown raiders attacked an unspecified cattle camp near Panyagoor in Kongor payam (Jonglei state), killing 1 pastoralist and wounding another (victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka).

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 7 May 2020, one or more villages were torched and over 2,000 civilians displaced during a two day battle involving NAS rebels against SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in Jungu boma near Lainya (Central Equatoria state). Both sides are implicated in beatings and burning of villages. A civilian alluded to killings taking place, but there is no clear information on this, nor of any fatalities that may have occurred between the belligerents.

column8: Gok Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 7 May 2020, members of the Waat subsection of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clashed with members of the Panawur subsection (of unknown Gok Dinka lineage) at an unspecified area of Cueibet county (Lakes state), and presumed to be in the east of the county given contextual information in the soruce. One member of the Panawur was killed and one Waat member was wounded, in what is described as a revenge attack.

column16: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan Voice of Voiceless
column17: Around 7 May 2020 (as reported), SSPDF attacked NAS rebel positions at Buaji in Mundri East county (Western Equatoria state). The NAS statement says that they repulsed the attack and inflicting ""casualties"" upon the government troops, without mention of fatalities.

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Sudan Tribune
column17: Around 7 May 2020 (as reported), NAS rebels conducted attacks on SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in the area of Loka West in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). The rebels claimed to have destroyed two government vehicles, but source does not mention whether there were casualties or fatalities.

column9: Pojulu Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Christian Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

On 9 May 2020, the Awul and Rualbet sections of the Rek Dinka clashed at an unspecified area of Tonj North county (Warrap state), presumed to be on west-central belt of the county where the two sections reside. 5 were killed and 2 wounded, in what is described as a revenge attack.

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune
column17: On 9 May 2020, NAS rebels conducted attacks on SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces at Konkat military base close to Loka West in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). The rebels claimed to have killed an SSPDF commander and ""several"" soldiers. Several fatalities coded as 3.

Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

Around 9 May 2020 (between 4 May - 14 May), SSPDF burned at least 11 villages in Pojulu-inhabited areas of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), including Lomilikin, Jungu, Rego, Lora, Loka West, Gumbiri, Bereka, Langude, Konkat, Wulkilio, Jomboli and Kembe (all in Kenyi or Lainya payams). 2 civilians were killed in Gumbiri, 1 in Jomboli and 2 in Kembe (fatalities for the latter two spread across two events in Lainya and Kenya); 7 Episcopal church members arrested (with one being tortured at an unspecified location), and 22,000 civilians were displaced.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan News Now; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 10 May 2020, SPLM-IO forces claimed that NAS rebels abducted 8 IO officers, including 2 Brigadier Generals, at Kansuk in Kajo Keji county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS dispute the claim, and say that the IO arrested the 8 officers in April, as part of an internal power struggle.

On 10 May 2020, armed youth (accused by a local official of being involved in cattle raiding) shot dead a civilian at an unspecified location in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria state), as he travelled to neighbouring Lakes state.

column16: Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: Around 11 May 2020 (between 11 May - 12 May), Panyar and Waat sub-sections of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clan clashed at a swamp near Pabach and Tayar in a Panyar-inhabited area of Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least 14 (with 8 Waat, 6 Panyar confirmed dead). The fighting was sparked by the gang-rape of a pregnant woman on 11 May.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Gok Clan Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 11 May 2020, youth from an unspecified sub-section of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clan gang-raped a heavily pregnant woman (also from the Macar section of the Gok) at an unspecified location of Cuebeit county (Lakes state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

column7: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 11 May 2020, President Salva Kiir fired General Gabirel Jok Riak as head of the SSPDF, replacing him with General JJ Okot. Several senior army officers (who had defected to the government during the civil war) were also fired, and several establishment army generals promoted. The moves follow reports of an abortive coup which was scheduled for 2 May, and allegedly involved senior military and NSS personnel at the very core of the South Sudanese regime. Gen. Gabriel Jok was not among the coup plotters, but was reportedly dismissed for failing to swiftly respond to the coup threat.
On 11 May 2020, an SSPDF soldier shot a civilian in the head in the area of Poktap (Jonglei state). The victim survived the gunshot, and is in hospital. There is no information as to the motive.
On 11 May 2020, an SSPDF soldier opened fire in Mingkaman (Lakes state), wounding one civilian. There is no further information.

On 12 May 2020, unidentified attackers killed three civilians (one of whom was a trader from Somalia) and wounded around four others in the area of Lokurubang near Lainya town (Central Equatoria state). Officials have accused NAS rebels of attacking the civilian, who have denied the allegation.

column9: Mbororo Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: Around 13 May 2020 (week of), nine people - including eight children and a mother, with the majority of victims being female - from the Mbororo pastoralist community were abducted by local youths (presumed to be Zande) from a camp in the area of Yangiri in Ezo county (Western Equatoria state). Six of the children were released unharmed in late June, the others are still missing.

column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 13 May 2020, NAS forces alleged that a """"mobile contingent"""" of NAS rebels was attacked by SSPDF at an unspecified location in the Boma area of Pibor county (Jonglei state). The NAS stated that they repulsed the attackers.

On 13 May 2020, unknown attackers killed a soldier outside a UN PoC camp in Juba (presumed to be at UN House on the outskirts, due to a reference to the event taking place near ""Checkpoint"" (located nearby)), stealing his motorbike and weapon. Soldiers subsequently refused to allow IDPs to leave the camp.

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan Voice of Voiceless
column17: On 14 May 2020, NAS forces claimed they were attacked by a joint force of SSPDF and around 200 SPLM-IO soldiers at Konkat military base close to Loka West in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS stated that they repulsed the attack, with 5 NAS rebels killed and 9 wounded. They also accused retreating IO forces of killing four civilians as they fled south.

On 14 May 2020, unidentified armed youth killed two civilians (presumed to be of the Bongo ethnic group) near Bahr Gel in Wulu county (Lakes state). There is no clear motive for the attack, although clashes are reported to be continuing in the area.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Twic Media Reports; Radio Miraya
column17: On 14 May 2020, SSPDF soldiers clashed with raiders from Unity state (presumed to be Bul Nuer, given the proximity between Mayom county and Gogrial East) at Mayen Jur in Gogrial East, killing 17 or 18 people (9 of whom were soldiers), wounding four (including a former commissioner) and displacing hundreds (one source says up to 25,000 were displaced). The raiders attacked several villages in the area inhabited by members of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka, looting cattle.
On 15 May 2020, dozens of women protested in Juba against sexual violence in the country, following the gang-rape of an 8 year-old girl by youth in Gudele the previous week. [size=dozens]

column9: Apuk-Rek Clan Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Twic Media Reports
column17: On 15 May 2020, raiders suspected of coming from Unity state (presumed to be Bul Nuer on the basis of proximity and past attacks in the area) attacked Mayen Jur in Gogrial East county (Warrap state). 12 were killed in the clashes (presumed to involve the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka, who reisde in the county) including two SSPDF soldiers, and several wounded, including a former local official. Property was burned in the attack and cattle stolen, and an unknown number have been displaced to nearby villages.

column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Sudan Tribune
column17: Around 15 May 2020 (as reported), NAS rebels claimed to have killed 61 SSPDF soldiers in the area of Moje in Wonduruba payam (Central Equatoria state), and alleged that retreating SSPDF soldiers burned houses in the area. Fatalities could not be independently verified. The army has not yet commented.

On 15 May 2020, Jur Bel and members of the Ayiel section of the Gok Dinka clan clashed at an unspecified location of Ngap payam in Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least four. The clash is said to be a revenge attack.
Around 15 May 2020, four SSPDF soldiers were killed and four army vehicles destroyed in separate attacks in Mundri county (Western Equatoria state). The identity of the attackers is not specified.

column16: Sudan Tribune; MSF; BBC News; South Sudan News Agency; VOA; Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; UNOCHA; Juba Monitor
column17: Around 16 May 2020, during a two day battle between Murle militiamen and Lou Nuer militia, at least 242 were killed (some unconfirmed reports suggest between 700-1,000) and at least 300 injured at various locations in Uror county (Jonglei state), with many civilian casualties reported. Three aid workers were killed (including one from MSF) in Pieri on 17 May, an unspecified number of women abducted, and cattle stolen. Dwellings were torched, with Pieri and Pamai being burned to the ground. Fatalities evenly distributed across 9 events.

column16: BBC News; MSF; South Sudan News Agency; VOA; Radio Miraya; UNOCHA; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; Juba Monitor
column17: Around 16 May 2020, during a two day battle between Murle militiamen and Lou Nuer militia, at least 242 were killed (some unconfirmed reports suggest between 700-1,000) and at least 300 injured at various locations in Uror county (Jonglei state), including Tangnyang, Thardiok, Guangchat, Goakgoak, Panyok, Jokrial, Kaar, Wek, Oluwek, Partet, and Dhorganwel, with many civilian casualties reported. An unspecified number of women were abducted, and cattle stolen. Dwellings were torched in several locations. Fatalities evenly distributed across 9 events.

column16: BBC News; UNOCHA; Radio Miraya; South Sudan News Agency; Juba Monitor; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; VOA; MSF
column17: Around 16 May 2020, during a two day battle between Murle militiamen and Lou Nuer militia, at least 242 were killed (some unconfirmed reports suggest between 700-1,000) and at least 300 injured at various locations in Uror county (Jonglei state), including Tangnyang, Thardiok, Guangchat, Goakgoak, Panyok, Jokrial, Kaar, Wek, Oluwek, Partet, and Dhorganwel, with many civilian casualties reported. An unspecified number of women were abducted, and cattle stolen. Dwellings were torched in several locations. Fatalities evenly distributed across 9 events.

An unspecified number of women were abducted, and cattle stolen. Dwellings were torched in several locations. Fatalities evenly distributed across 9 events.

column16: MSF; VOA; Juba Monitor; UNOCHA; Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; BBC News; Radio Miraya; South Sudan News Agency
column17: Around 17 May 2020, during a two day battle between Murle militiamen and Lou Nuer militia, at least 242 were killed (some unconfirmed reports suggest between 700-1,000) and at least 300 injured at various locations in Uror county (Jonglei state), with many civilian casualties reported. column16: VOA; MSF; Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor; Radio Miraya; South Sudan News Agency; Sudan Tribune; UNOCHA; BBC News
column17: Around 17 May 2020, during a two day battle between Murle militiamen and Lou Nuer militia, at least 242 were killed (some unconfirmed reports suggest between 700-1,000) and at least 300 injured at various locations in Uror county (Jonglei state). Three aid workers were killed (including one from MSF) in Pieri on 17 May, an unspecified number of women abducted, and cattle stolen. Dwellings were torched, with Pieri and Pamai being torched.

On 18 May 2020, two sub-sections of the Macar Gok (the Panyar and Waat) clashed at an unspecified area of Pagoor payam in eastern Cueibet county (Lakes state), in response to a sexual assault committed by a member of the Panyar sub-section. At least 15 were killed (9 from the Waat, 6 from the Panyar) and 9 wounded.

Around 19 May 2020 (between 18-20 May), SSPDF were accused of killing four civilians at an unspecified area of Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), amid counter-insurgency operations against NAS rebels.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 19 May 2020 (between 18-20 May), SSPDF (possibly operating in conjunction with SPLM-IO forces) attacked Bereka in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), burning houses and reportedly abducting civilians. The attack comes amid clashes with NAS rebels in the area.

On 19 May 2020, armed men entered the house of a journalist in Juba, and stole various items (including a work laptop and mobile phones) from the premises. Upon leaving, they shot the brother of the journalist (who was outside the house) twice in the leg.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 20 May 2020 (as reported), SPLM-IO forces killed three civilians fleeing South Sudan into Uganda, at an unspecified location likely along the Central Equatoria state border with Uganda in Morobo, Yei or Kajo-Keji counties.

On 21 May 2020, cattle raiders from the Kidepo area (and presumed to be Lotuku) clashed with local youth (presumed to be Lopit) near the border between Lafon (a.k.a. Lopit) county and Kidepo Valley. One of the raiders was killed in the clash.

On 21 May 2020, unidentified raiders attacked soldiers who were escorting cattle from Kapoeta along the road to Torit, at Okuma Mafi close to Iliue (Eastern Equatoria state). Two soldiers and a civilian were killed in the firefight.
On 22 May 2020, armed youth attacked the house of a police officer (presumed to be off-duty) in Cueibet town (Lakes state), killing the officer and wounding his wife. There is no further information.
On 23 May 2020, unknown raiders abducted 10,000 head of cattle in the Kongor area of Twic East county (Jonglei state). The source does not mention whether fatalities or casualties occurred.

column9: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 23 May 2020, NAS rebels claimed to have repulsed an attack by SSPDF and IO forces at an unspecified location in Mundri West county (Western Equatoria state). There is no further information.

column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Miraya
column17: On 24 May 2020, an unknown group ambushed an SSPDF vehicle at the Mile 16 area along the Yei-Maridi road (presumed to be in Maridi county, Central Equatoria state). Three soldiers and a 19 year-old woman were killed in the ambush; IO and NAS rebels have exchanged accusations regarding ambushes in the area.

column16: Radio Miraya; CTSAMM; Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 24 May 2020, an unknown group (likely to be NAS rebels) ambushed a military convoy in Tore payam (Central Equatoria state), killing an unspecified number of SSPDF. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 24 May 2020, NAS rebels were reported to have attacked a civilian vehicle on the Yei-Juba road (presumed to be in Yei or Lainya counties, Central Equatoria state, given the presence of NAS forces in these counties). There are no reports on injuries or fatalities.

On 24 May 2020, an unknown group burned a vehicle and abducted three of its passengers at Koya in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state). NAS and IO forces have exchanged accusations about their involvement in a spate of ambushes in Central and Western Equatoria states.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: Around 24 May 2020, NAS rebels claimed to have ambushed an NSS convoy travelling to Mvolo county from Mundri town, likely in Gulu payam (Western Equatoria state). NAS stated that they killed 5 NSS soldiers, and seized ammunition.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); South Sudan News Now
column17: On 24 May 2020, raiders from Warrap state (presumed to be Rek Dinka given the location of the event) attacked a cattle camp in the Bul Nuer-inhabited Gamdhang area of Mayom county (Unity state), leading to a clash which killed ""around"" 17 people, and 20,000 head of cattle being raided.

On 24 May 2020, an unknown group attacked and burned a fuel tanker near Gulu in Mundri West county (Western Equatoria state), killing the driver and shooting the co-driver in both legs. NAS and IO forces have exchanged accusations regarding a spate of ambushes in the Central and Western Equatoria state areas.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; South Sudan News Now; Juba Monitor
column17: On 25 May 2020, raiders (presumed to be Western Jikany Nuer, given the direction of attack) attacked Kuek cattle camp (presumed to be in southern Pariang county, Unity state), killing at least two Ruweng Dinka and wounding at least three others (unconfirmed reports say 13 were killed and 90 injured, with over 23,000 head of cattle looted). Local officials have accused an SPLM-IO general of involvement in the raids, which has been denied by the IO.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Lakes Communal Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 25 May 2020, raiders from Warrap state (presumed to be Rek Dinka) operating alongside Dinka raiders from Lakes state (of unconfirmed clan lineage) clashed twice with Nyong Nuer in Mayom payam in Panyijiar (Unity state), who repulsed the attackers. The source notes that an unconfirmed number of civilian fatalities occurred between this and two other events in Mayom and Mayendit counties. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Lakes Communal Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Dok Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 24 May 2020, raiders from Warrap state (presumed to be Rek Dinka) operating alongside Dinka raiders from Lakes state (of unconfirmed clan lineage) attacked Dok Nuer-inhabited Madol payam (Unity state), killing an unconfirmed number of civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 26 May 2020, unknown raiders (likely to be either Bul or Leek Nuer, although the source does not specify the origin of the attackers) attacked an unspecified area of Abiemnom county, killing an unspecified numer (victim presumed to be from the Ruweng Dinka clan), and looting property.

Around 27 May 2020 (week of), 9 SSPDF were killed when unspecified cattle raiders attacked their position at an unspecified location in Mayom county (Unity state). It is unclear whether the SSPDF inflicted casualties or fatalities upon the attackers.

column7: Buk-Atok-Rek Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Apuk-Padoch-Rek Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 27 May 2020, members of the Buk section (who appear to be a sub-section of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka) were reported to have fatally assaulted a member of the Padoch sub-section of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka in Awul in Tonj North county (Warrap state). There is no stated motive for the attack. [size=no report]
Around 28 May 2020, unknown attackers killed three people at Ameth Chok in Tonj South county (Warrap state), and stole a small number of animals.
Around 28 May 2020 (as reported), unknown attackers killed a woman at Wun-Ameeth in Marial-Lou payam in Tonj North county (Warrap state). There is no further information.
Around 28 May 2020 (as reported), unknown attackers killed two sleeping cattle guards at or near Akop payam in Tonj North county (Warrap state). There is no further information.

On 29 May 2020, two women were gang-raped by six men - three of whom were armed soldiers in military uniform - at the Jebel neighbourhood of western Juba (Central Equatoria state). The attackers also looted the house the women were in, and a neighbouring property.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 29 May 2020, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces tortured and robbed displaced South Sudanese civilians fleeing from Morobo county to the Congolese border (event presumed to have occurred on the South Sudanese side of the border, in Morobo county).

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 30 May 2020, NAS rebels assaulted an SPLM-IO position at Busia in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state), killing one IO soldier and wounding thee.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 May 2020, SSPDF from Division 3 attacked a cattle camp in Tuoilok in western Mayom county (Unity state), in a bid to reclaim stolen cattle. 12 SSPDF were killed in clashes with the raiders (presumed to be Bul Nuer, given the location), and 3 raiders were killed.

On 31 May 2020, an NGO vehicle was ambushed by unknown gunmen at Cuiecok village in Awerial county (Lakes state), as it travelled to Awerial town from Terekeka county. The attackers demanded money; the driver of the NGO vehicle was shot in the hand after the staff refused to give it to them.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 31 May 2020 (end of month), armed pastoralists (presumed to be Bor Dinka, given their presence in the area in recent years) abducted around 7 children from Ayii, close to Magwi town (Eastern Equatoria state). All victims presumed to be Madi.

On 1 June 2020, SSPDF soldiers fired weapons into the air for three hours at Pochalla town (Jonglei state), causing residents to briefly flee the area. The soldier were demonstrating against non-payment of salaries for five months and a lack of food. The SSPDF announced it had now paid at least some of the salaries owed to the soldiers, and that food was now en route. [size=no report]

column9: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 1 June 2020 (beginning of month), unspecified raiders attacked pastoralists (presumed to be Bul Nuer) at an unspecified location in Mayom county (Unity state), leaving 12 killed and 8 wounded. Event presumed to be an armed clash, in line with similar incidents in the area.

column16: South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Radio Tamazuj; VOA
column17: Around 1 June 2020, an unknown group killed 6 civilians in Lujulu payam (with the village of Mongoyo being named in one source) in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state). SPLM-IO and NAS rebels have accused one another of being responsible for violence in the area. Hundreds have been displaced between this attack and violence in Panyume payam.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: CTSAMM; VOA; South Sudan Voice of Voiceless; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Around 1 June 2020, SPLM-IO and NAS rebels clashed in Loguni village in Panyume payam in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state). 15 civilians (two of whom were Ugandan) were killed in the clashes (with the NAS saying they were caught in the crossfire), and hundreds have been displaced between this attack and violence in Lujulu payam. It is not clear whether the clashing forces sustained casualties.

column7: Bor Clan Group (South Sudan); Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column16: South Sudan News Now; Dolku Media; HRW; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On 3 June 2020, at least 100 Bor and Twic East Dinka rioted in Bor (Jonglei state) and other (unspecified) locations in the same state, following a violent attack linked to the nephew of President Salva Kiir in the Gumbo suburb of Juba. In Bor town, demonstrators attacked the police commissioner and torched his vehicle; burned the house of the Secretary-General of Jonglei state; looted property; and damaged the SPLM party office building and the fence around the NSS compound (reportedly to rescue a journalist and another civilian detained by the NSS). NSS and Military Intelligence agents arrested several demonstrators, with unspecified security agents firing in the air. [size=at least one hundred]

column9: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column16: VOA; HRW; South Sudan News Now; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 3 June 2020, around 1,000 demonstrators gathered in Gumbo on the outskirts of Juba (Central Equatoria state), chanting slogans against President Salva Kiir and burning tires in the street, following violence initiated by the President's nephew that same day. Soldiers and police fired at the demonstrators, wounding three and killing one; NSS agents arrested at least 31. [size=around 1,000]

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 3 June 2020 (week of), an SPLM-IO Brigadier General was killed by armed youth from Fangak county (presumed to be Gawaar Nuer) in the area of Jualbor (Jonglei state), as he was leading a disarmament campaign. The source does not mention whether there were other fatalities.

Around 3 June 2020 (week of), SSPDF soldiers were reported to have beaten 30 civilians at Zabara in Lasu payam (Central Equatoria state), whilst looting and destroying crops in the area. The attack comes amid increased counter-insurgency activity in southern parts of Central Equatoria, though it is unclear if the attacks are linked.

column6: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column9: Bor Clan Militia (South Sudan); Twic East Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; VOA
column17: On 3 June 2020, an SSPDF Military Intelligence officer (who was the nephew of President Salva Kiir) alongside six soldiers (described as bodyguards in some sources) opened fire on residents (including Bor and Twic East Dinka residents of the suburb) of the Shirkat area of the Gumbo suburb of Juba (Central Equatoria state), killing at least 8 (revised up from initial reports of 3-5) including two Ugandans, prompting residents to attack the officer with machetes. The officer died of his wounds later after being arrested. The officer was attempting to violently obtain a plot of land from its owners, who had earlier refused to give it to him. Twenty have been arrested, including the six soldiers. UPDATE: a Brigadier General who was the former military attache to Uganda was arrested several weeks later in connection with the killing of the initial SSPDF MI perpetrator.
Around 3 June 2020 (as reported), unknown attackers (suspected of being Gok Dinka) killed two people at Chuei-Chok in Tonj South county (Warrap state). There is no further information.

column7: Leek Clan Group (South Sudan); Eastern Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Gawaar Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column9: Lou Clan Group (South Sudan); Western Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column17: On 5 June 2020, during a three day riot, IDPs at the UN House camp on the outskirts of Juba clashed in a fight reportedly sparked by the theft of a memory card, wounding 175 (2 seriously). The source indicates that Lou and Western Jikany Nuer were clashing with Gawaar Nuer and Nuer from the Greater Bentiu area (presumed to be Leek and Eastern Jikany). [size=at least 175]

column7: Leek Clan Group (South Sudan); Eastern Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Gawaar Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column9: Lou Clan Group (South Sudan); Western Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)

The source indicates that Lou and Western Jikany Nuer were clashing with Gawaar Nuer and Nuer from the Greater Bentiu area (presumed to be Leek and Eastern Jikany). [size=at least 175]

column16: Radio Miraya; Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 6 June 2020, SSPDF soldiers gang-raped a 14 year-old girl (and two other women, according to one source) at Zabara or Lata in Lasu payam (Central Equatoria state). The attack comes amid increased counter-insurgency activity in southern parts of Central Equatoria, though it is unclear if the sexual assaults are linked. One soldier has been arrested.

On 6 June 2020, a police captain travelling along the Yambio-Nzara road was attacked and wounded by unknown gunmen (implied to be unpaid members of the security forces, who are presumed to be army) in the area of Massia/Mazzia. There is no further information.

On 7 June 2020, members of an unspecified section of the Agar Dinka clan attacked Pan-Awac in Rumbek East (Lakes state), killing one and wounding nine (including the local chief). The attack is described as being motivated by revenge.

On 7 June 2020, two groups of armed youth from Aluak-luak and Amoli cattle camps in the Yirol area (Lakes state) clashed, killing at least 2 and wounding 4, with several children also suspected of being abducted. The attack is described as retaliatory in nature.

column7: Leek Clan Group (South Sudan); Eastern Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Gawaar Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column9: Lou Clan Group (South Sudan); Western Jikany Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column17: On 7 June 2020, during a three day riot, IDPs at the UN House camp on the outskirts of Juba clashed in a fight reportedly sparked by the theft of a memory card, wounding 175 (2 seriously). The source indicates that Lou and Western Jikany Nuer were clashing with Gawaar Nuer and Nuer from the Greater Bentiu area (presumed to be Leek and Eastern Jikany). [size=at least 175]

On 8 June 2020, youth militia (presumed to be of the Lopit ethnic group) intercepted suspected Boya cattle raiders at Libianga near Lwala boma in Lafon county (Eastern Equatoria state), killing one raider, and retrieving stolen cattle.
On 8 June 2020, suspected Boya raiders killed one person and stole 200 head of cattle during a raid in the area of Lwala boma in Lopit-inhabited Lafon county (Eastern Equatoria state).

column7: Lou Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 10 June 2020, a large number of armed youth from Bor (and presumed to be Bor Dinka) and from Akobo (and presumed to be Lou Nuer) clashed with Murle fighters (operating alongside unspecified ""outside people"") at Gumuruk, Kozchar and Katlint (phonetic spelling used) in Pibor county (Jonglei state), following months of clashes with the Murle in parts of Jonglei state. The UN reported that ""hundreds"" had been killed and a local official says around 20,000 displaced to Pibor town in two weeks of fighting. One hundred fatalities coded across nine events covering a two week period.

The UN has said ""hundreds"" have been killed and a local official says around 20,000 displaced to Pibor town in two weeks of fighting. column17: On 10 June 2020, unknown attackers ambushed and robbed female Congolese IDPs in the Rimenze area of Yambio county (Western Equatoria state). The women were assaulted after they attempted to resist.

column9: Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column16: South Sudan News Now; Radio Miraya; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 11 June 2020, four days of clashes between SSPDF and the 7th October Movement rebellion (likely operating alongside armed youth from the Agar Dinka) occurred in the Ayen Mayar area of Amongpiny payam in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state). At least six were killed across four days of fighting (four rebels - including founder of the group Kerbino Wol on 14 June - and a local chief and his son), though it is unclear if the military sustained casualties. Fatalities spread across four events.

column17: Around 13 June 2020 (weekend of), raiders from an unspecified neighboring state attacked a cattle camp in the Buow area of Rubkona county (Unity state), prompting a firefight with cattle guards (presumed to be Leek Nuer) that killed at least 9 and wounded 17. 155 head of cattle were stolen.

column9: Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)

column17: On 13 June 2020, four days of clashes between SSPDF and the 7th October Movement rebellion (likely operating alongside armed youth from the Agar Dinka) occurred in the Ayen Mayar area of Amongpiny payam in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state). Fatalities spread across four events.

On 14 June 2020, four civilians were abducted by an armed group in the Karika area of Mundri West county (Western Equatoria state), with one of the abductees (an elderly man) being released. A local official accused NAS rebels of being responsible; the NAS have denied the accusation.

The UN reported that ""hundreds"" had been killed and a local official says around 20,000 displaced to Pibor town in two weeks of fighting, while an unconfirmed report claims that 300 have been killed in fighting around June 14. One hundred fatalities coded across nine events covering a two week period.

column17: Around 14 June 2020, Bor Dinka youth operating alongside men in uniform (presumed to be army) clashed with Murle fighters (operating alongside unspecified ""outside people"") in the areas around Kozchar, Manyabol and Gumuruk in Pibor county (Jonglei state; note that there are two locations called Manyabol in the area).
