column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), SPLM-IO forces clashed with local militia (presumed to be Dok Nuer) at an unspecified location in Leer county (Unity state). The source notes that casualties occurred, but does not specify whether any were killed.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), SPLM-IO forces clashed with local militia (presumed to be Dok Nuer) at an unspecified location in Mayendit county (Unity state). The source notes that casualties occurred, but does not specify whether any were killed.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), SPLM-IO forces clashed with local militia at an unspecified location in Panyijar county (Unity state). The source notes that casualties occurred, but does not specify whether any were killed.

On 15 June 2020, striking oil workers demonstrated at one or more oil fields of the Greater Pioneer Operating Company (which include Unity, Toma, El Toor and Munga fields) in Rubkona county (Unity state), demanding compensation for unpaid overtime, and for improved working conditions and insurance policies. [size=no report]

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 June 2020, a local official claimed that unspecified youth from Jonglei state operating alongside SPLM-IO forces clashed with Murle fighters in the Gumuruk area of Pibor county (Jonglei state), killing at least 5 and wounding 12. The IO have denied their involvement in the ongoing violence.

column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Juba Monitor; VOA; Radio Miraya
column17: On 15 June 2020, Bor Dinka militiamen operating alongside unspecified men in uniform (presumed to be army) clashed with Murle youth in Manyabol in Pibor county (Jonglei state. Note that there are two locations called Manyabol in the area). The source reported that 14 were injured and ""some"" killed. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 15 June 2020, SPLM-IO forces clashed with NSS personnel at the market in Tambura town (Western Equatoria state), after security services intervened to stop IO forces from extorting a Darfuri merchant. Two people were killed, with sources suggesting one of these was an NSS officer and the other a civilian.

column9: Civilians (Sudan); Civilians (Eritrea); Didinga Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); South Sudan News Now; Radio Miraya
column17: On 16 June 2020, unknown attackers (which an unconfirmed report claims were a Toposa militia linked to the former Governor of Kapoeta state) attacked civilians travelling in a vehicle in the area of Lauru or Lupala (both in Budi county, Eastern Equatoria state). Seven were killed (including an Eritrean and a Darfuri civilian, as well as a policeman (presumed to be off-duty)) and one wounded, with the bodies of the victims burned by the attackers. One source indicates the majority of victims were of Didinga ethnicity.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); South Sudan News Now
column17: On 16 June 2020, SSPDF fired upon IDPs attending a funeral at or near UN House PoC site on the outskirts of Juba, killing one. The attack follows a spate of unexplained killings of IDPs in recent days.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: South Sudan News Now; Juba Monitor; VOA; Radio Miraya
column17: On 17 June 2020, SSPDF and a local militia from Tambura county attacked SPLM-IO forces at their cantonment site in the area of Namutina (Western Equatoria state; note that one source says the camp was located closer to Tambura town, in the Nambiana area), killing an IO Brigadier General and at least ten IO soldiers. Tents in the camp were also torched. 5,646 people were displaced by the fighting.

column9: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Juba Monitor; South Sudan News Now
column17: On 17 June 2020, suspected Murle raiders clashed with local youths (including the Alian subsection of the Athoc section of the Bor Dinka clan, and other unspecified Athoc subsections) at Aliang in Bor South county (Jonglei state), with Bor youth repulsing the attackers and recovering cattle stolen during the clash. Five were killed and seven wounded.

Around 17 June 2020 (week of), Zande and Balanda militias reportedly clashed at an unspecified location in Tambura county (Western Equatoria state), killing 4. A local MP says that the conflict was related to power-sharing and representation in Tambura county, which may be linked to the peace process.

column9: Bor Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 17 June 2020, Murle raiders attacked the Pamuon cattle camp near Akua-Deng in Bor South county (Jonglei state), killing nine or ten and wounding nine (all victims presumed to be Bor Dinka). Dwellings in the area were torched, and between 1,000-15,000 cattle were stolen. An unknown number of residents were displaced.

column9: Bor Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column16: South Sudan News Now; Juba Monitor
column17: On 18 June 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked Atet in Bor South county (Jonglei state), amid intensive fighting in southern Jonglei. 11 were killed (9 of whom were women), 5 wounded, and 1 child abducted (all victims assumed Bor Dinka). A large number of cattle were reportedly raided.

column9: Bor Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Women (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 June 2020, suspected Murle gunmen operating alongside men in ""mixed military uniforms"" (provisionally recorded as army) attacked an area in the far-west part of Makuac payam in Bor South county (Jonglei state). 9 were killed (7 of whom were women), 2 or 3 wounded, while a woman and a child were also abducted (all victims presumed to be Bor Dinka). An unspecified number were displaced. No cattle or livestock were stolen.

Around 19 June 2020 (as reported), a child was killed and two other children wounded when a grenade exploded at an unspecified location in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state). There is no further information at this time.

column16: South Sudan News Now; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 19 June 2020, suspected Murle raiders clashed with SSPDF in the Makuac area in Bor South county (Jonglei state), killing 12, including a child, and wounding 3 civilians.

column9: Christian Group (South Sudan); Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column17: On 20 June 2020, SSPDF raided a Christian college (where international NGOs are also based) at Romogi in Kajo Keji county (Central Equatoria state), stealing equipment and money (including US $17,000, and Ugandan and South Sudanese currency) from the Norwegian Refugee Council and American Refugee Committee, and then stealing from local youth nearby. The army has claimed that the offending soldiers are deserters from Mangalatore and Bore.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 20 June 2020, unspecified armed youth attacked the Panyagor area in Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing two civilians and wounding five (all victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka), and stole cattle. Local youth are said to pursuing the raiders.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Anuak Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 21 June 2020, a girl (presumed to be Anyuak) was abducted as she travelled between Ajwara and Pochalla town (Jonglei state) with her mother. Residents of the area suspect the attack was conducted by youth from Pibor (and presumed to be Murle).

Around 21 June 2020 (as reported), Bor Dinka militia attacked White Army militia of an unspecified Nuer clan as they were moving stolen cattle seized around Gumuruk (clash presumed to have taken place north of the Gumuruk area of Pibor county, Jonglei state, along the route to Nuer home areas). 1 White Army militiaman was killed and 3 wounded in the firefight. The cattle had earlier been seixed from members of the Murle community.

On 24 June 2020, unknown raiders attacked a cattle camp in the Duk Padiet area in Duk county (Jonglei state), stealing around 1,000 head of cattle. Local youth caught the raiders and recovered around 450 cows, with one of the youth sustaining injuries in the firefight with the raiders.
Around 24 June 2020 (week of), gunmen (likely from Alel village of Yirol West county) attacked and killed a farmer at Kakor village in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria state).

column9: Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Miraya; VOA; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 24 June 2020, armed Agar Dinka youth from an unspecified section attacked a dwelling (assumed Agar Dinka) in Pacong in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), wounding three. There is no further information.

column9: Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: VOA; Radio Miraya; Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 25 June 2020, armed Agar Dinka from an unspecified section raided cattle (assumed Agar Dinka) at Awei-Lual in the area of Pacong payam in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), stealing an unspecified number of cattle. The source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.

column7: Kuei-Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Pakam-Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Ruop-Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Athoi-Thuyic-Agar Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: VOA; Radio Miraya; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Juba Monitor
column17: On 26 June 2020, youth from the Pakam and Kuei Agar Dinka sections alongside youth from the Gony sub-section of the Athoi section of the Agar Dinka attacked cattle keepers from the Thuyic sub-section (of the Athoi section) and the Ruop section (all Agar Dinka) at Ting Atong near Meen Waal in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), killing one and wounding another. 130 head of cattle were stolen.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Juba Monitor
column17: On 26 June 2020, during a three day clash, armed youth from the Padoch sub-section of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka clashed with youth from the Buk (who appear to be a sub-section of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka) in the areas of Agany and Anyibuoth in Tonj North county (Warrap state), killing at least 32 (fatalities spread across three events) and wounding at least 7, whilst two villages were torched. The clashes are linked to the killing of a Padoch man in Awul in late May.

column16: Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 27 June 2020, during a three day clash, armed youth from the Padoch sub-section of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka clashed with youth from the Buk (who appear to be a sub-section of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka) at the areas of Agany and Anyibuoth in Tonj North county (Warrap state), killing at least 32 (fatalities spread across three events) and wounding at least 7, whilst two villages were torched. The clashes are linked to the killing of a Padoch man in Awul in late May.

column9: Kuei-Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Pakam-Agar Clan Militia (South Sudan); Athoi-Gony-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Pacuor-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Aliamtoc-Dhiei-Agar Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column16: VOA; Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: Around 27 June 2020 (weekend of), members of the Ruop section and the Thuyic sub-section of the Athoi section of the Agar Dinka clashed with the Kuei and Pakam sections alongside the Pacuor sub-section (of the Kook section), the Gony sub-section (of the Athoi) and the Dhiei sub-section of the Aliamtoc section (all Agar Dinka) at Meen Waal in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), following escalating violence among the groups. At least 33 were killed, and over 34 wounded. Security forces have since dispersed armed Gony, Dhiei and Kuei youth planning reprisal attacks.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 28 June 2020, armed Yiep youth from the Panyar sub-section of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clashed with NSS personnel (either one officer, or several) in the Panakol area of Cueibet county (Lakes state), wounding one officer, who is reported to be from a rival section.

column7: Aliab Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column9: Aliab Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 28 June 2020, two groups of youth (presumed to be Aliab Dinka) engaged in what was described as a ""brawl"" (and presumed not to have involved weaponry) at or near Mingkaman in Awerial county (Lakes state), resulting in the death of one youth and injuries to a further 10. Sixteen were arrested, in what is reported to be an leadership dispute within the local youth union. [size=at least 17]

Around 28 June 2020 (weekend of), unspecified raiders clashed with unspecified armed forces (presumed to be army) at Gar cattle camp in Rumbek North county (Lakes state; coordinates for Agar used at GP2), killing 8 security forces personnel and 1 civilian.

column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 28 June 2020, during a three day clash, armed youth from the Padoch sub-section of the Apuk section of the Rek Dinka clashed with youth from the Buk (who appear to be a sub-section of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka) at the areas of Agany and Anyibuoth in Tonj North county (Warrap state), killing at least 32 (fatalities spread across three events) and wounding at least 7, whilst two villages were torched. The clashes are linked to the killing of a Padoch man in Awul in late May.

On 28 June 2020, armed Yiep youth from the the Panyar sub-section of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka attacked and killed an ambulance driver as he transported a wounded NSS officer in the Panakol area of Cueibet county (Lakes state).

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 29 June 2020, President Salva Kiir appointed 8 out of 10 governors, as well as chief administrators for the disputed Pibor, Abyei and Ruweng Administrative Areas, after months of delays. Governors have not been appointed for Jonglei state (due to disagreement within SSOA), whilst the President has refused to accept the controversial senior IO commander Johnson Olonyi for Upper Nile.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya; Juba Monitor; VOA; Xinhua
column17: Around 29 June 2020 (as reported), suspected Murle raiders attacked Patiou village in Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing at least four and wounding several (all victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka). 1,000 head of cattle were stolen, and 5,000 were displaced between this attack and another a few days later.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), heavy fighting was reported between SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in northern and eastern Baac payam in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), with at least 30 killed in the northern area (coded here as taking place in the Rumaker area) and at least 20 killed in the eastern area (coded here as Malualkon). An unspecified number of civilians were displaced.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), heavy fighting was reported between SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces in northern and eastern Baac payam in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), with at least 30 killed in the northern area (coded here as taking place in the Rumaker area) and at least 20 killed in the eastern area (coded here as Malualkon). An unspecified number of civilians were displaced.

On 30 June 2020, SSPDF clashed with unspecified armed youth (presumed to be inhabitants of the area) at an unstated eastern area of Tonj South county (Warrap state), as the soldiers were conducting a civilian disarmament campaign. ""Many"" were killed, including at least 10 soldiers.

On 30 June 2020, at least six people were killed and an unknown number wounded in a cattle raid at an unspecified county within the greater Tonj area (Warrap state). There is no further information, including as to whether a firefight occurred.

Around 30 June 2020 (as reported), the former security advisor for the defunct Gogrial State was assassinated in Kuajok town in Gogrial West county (Warrap state). There is no further information at this time, including information on the attackers.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 30 June 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked Maar in Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing 7 (victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka), amid intense retaliatory raiding in southern Jonglei.

column16: Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); VOA
column17: On 30 June 2020, armed youth from Paloc and Aduel payams of Rumbek East (and presumed to be Agar Dinka) attacked a cattle camp in Aluak-Luak payam in Yirol West county (Lakes state), in the Nyaruach area (note that one source says this was in the Mapuordit area). At least 9 were killed in the attack (1 SSPDF sergeant, 1 police officer, and 7 civilians, likely ethnic Atuot) and 2 women abducted. Hundreds of cattle were stolen, and an unspecified number of people displaced. Unconfirmed reports say 20 SSPDF were killed whilst pursuing the raiders; the army denies such reports.

On 30 June 2020, unknown attackers killed four civilians and wounded eleven in an attack on two vehicles travelling on the Juba-Bor road, at least one of which took place in the Khor Makuac (presumed to be in Bor South county, Jonglei state, and south of Bor town).

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 July 2020, attackers (presumed to be Murle, given recent and similar attacks in the area) killed 4 and wounded 17 at a cattle camp in the Makiir area of Ajuong payam in Twic East county (Jonglei state) (all victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka). An unspecified number of cattle were stolen.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 July 2020, raiders (implied by the source to be Murle, and coded as such) attacked the areas of Paliau and Duk Deng in central Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing 7 (with one source indicating that 5 were killed in Paliau) and wounding at least 20, amid intense retaliatory raiding in southern Jonglei. At least 100 head of cattle were stolen. Fatalities split between two events, with five fatalities in Paliau.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 July 2020, raiders (implied by the source to be Murle, and coded as such) attacked the areas of Paliau and Duk Deng in central Twic East county (Jonglei state), killing 7 (with one source indicating that 5 were killed in Paliau) and wounding at least 20, amid intense retaliatory raiding in southern Jonglei. At least 100 head of cattle were stolen. Fatalities split between two events, with five fatalities in Paliau.

Around 1 July 2020 (as reported), two unspecified groups (both presumed to be inhabitants of the area) clashed in Citcok payam in northern Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing 4, and wounding 1. There is no further information.

On 1 July 2020, the former commissioner of the defunct Burator county was shot and wounded by an unknown armed group between Nyium and Pochalla town in Pochalla county (Jonglei state). The victim was then robbed, before being airlifted to Juba.
On 1 July 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed a radio journalist as he travelled within Tonj South county to Tonj town (Warrap state). There is no further information.

column9: Twic East Clan Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Juba Monitor; Xinhua
column17: Around 2 July 2020 (as reported), suspected Murle raiders attacked Patiou in Twic East county (Jonglei state) once again, and killed at least 6, and wounding around 25 (all victims presumed to be Twic East Dinka). Hundreds of dwellings have been torched, and 5,000 displaced between this attack and another earlier in the week.
Around 2 July 2020 (as reported), a local chief was beaten by SSPDF at an unspecified area of western Tonj North county (Warrap state), as soldiers began a civilian disarmament campaign in the area.

On 2 July 2020, unknown raiders (likely to either be from the Bor Dinka or Lou Nuer clans) killed 29 civilians (assumed from the Murle community) and wounded 7 others in the Gumuruk area of Pibor county (Jonglei state), and abducted an unspecified number of women and children. An unknown number of people were displaced.
On 2 July 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked a cattle camp near Poktap town in Duk county (Jonglei state), killing four and wounding between nine and eleven.

column7: Dok Clan Militia (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Luach-Jang-Rek Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 2 July 2020, raiders from Koch and Mayendit counties (and presumed to be Jagei and Dok Nuer) attacked Luacjang pastoralists at Pakuai-Weng Atek and/or Papaweng cattle camps in Tonj East (Warrap), killing 6 and wounding 10. 368 head of cattle were stolen; the sources do not specify whether a firefight took place.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 3 July 2020, suspected Murle raiders (operating alongside men in army uniform) attacked cattle camps close to Duk Padiet town in Duk county (Jonglei state), prompting a five-hour firefight with armed youth. 38 were reported killed and 44 wounded (one of whom died of their injuries over a week later), whilst over 20,300 head of cattle were reported stolen and five homesteads torched. An 11 year-old girl was also reported missing.

On 4 July 2020, two unspecified sections of the Gok Dinka clashed at Madingkunyuk in Citcok payam of Cueibet county (Lakes state), killing at least four and wounding one. There is no further information.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 4 July 2020, ""unknown gunmen"" killed two Darfurian traders 2km east of Rumbek town (Lakes state) near an official checkpoint, prompting NSS agents stationed close to the site of the attack to fire upon the attackers, who fled the area.

Around 5 July 2020 (weekend of), unidentified gunmen shot and wounded a woman near a river in the Abyei-Chok area (presumed to be in the area of Acierchok in Tonj North county, Warrap state; approximate coordinates taken from UNOCHA map). There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 5 July 2020, UPDF were reported to have ""kidnapped"" two SSPDF soldiers on the South Sudanese side of the border, close to Nimule (Eastern Equatoria state). It is possible the apparent abductions are arrests which are related to a recent clash between SSPDF and UPDF on the Ugandan side of the border.

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Rek Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 6 July 2020 (as reported), unspecified armed youth shot dead a sleeping cattle guard and wounded two others (all victims presumed to be Rek Dinka) at the cattle camps of Piny-den and Makuac in the area of Akop payam in Tonj North county (Warrap state).

On 7 July 2020, two cattle traders were killed in Lafon county (Eastern Equatoria state), likely in the Longiro area. The chief of Longiro is suspected of involvement in the attack, and is at large. Attackers presumed to be from the Lopit ethnic group.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Atuot Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 8 July 2020 (week of), 1 person was killed and three women abducted in the area of Mapuordit payam in Yirol West county (Lakes state). The attackers are believed to be the same as those active in the area on 15 July, who are described as ""rebels"", without the rebel group being specified. All victims are presumed to be ethnic Atuot.

Around 8 July 2020 (as reported), the new administrator of the disputed Greater Pibor Administrative Area said that clashes were ""ongoing"" at an unspecified location(s) in the Pibor area between Murle youth and unspecified attackers (likely either Lou Nuer and/or Bor Dinka). There is currently no mention of fatalities.

column9: Women (South Sudan); Gok Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 11 July 2020, seven SSPDF soldiers raped two women and a 10 year-old girl at Amethdual village in Cueibet county (Lakes state). Two of the perpetrators have been arrested so far.

column9: Pastoralists (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 13 July 2020, suspected Murle raiders attacked a cattle camp close to Pajut town in Duk county (Jonglei state), sparking a firefight with local militia (presumed to be Hol Dinka). At least 7 were killed (including 4 raiders) and 3 injured. 100 head of cattle were stolen, but later recovered.
On 13 July 2020, unknown attackers killed two South Sudanese aid workers and four civilians in Pajut in Duk county (Jonglei state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 13 July 2020, female Nuba refugees from Sudan demonstrated at the UN offices in Yida camp in Pariang county (Unity state), denouncing the lack of humanitarian aid (which had been suspended last September). The source suggests the demonstrators began a sit-in protest, although this is unclear. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a passenger vehicle at the Khor Makuac area of the Juba-Bor road (presumed to be in the Makuach B area of Terekeka county, Central Equatoria state), killing 1. There is no clear motive for the attack.

Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), three members of the organized forces (presumed to be SSPDF) were killed over a land dispute in the village of Boni Boni (presumed to be an alternative spelling on Abonbonyi, Jur River county) along the river Shargi of Western Bahr el Ghazal state in unclear circumstances. Note that the source does not specify whether the attack took place at Boni Boni or nearby Wau city, which is also mentioned in the source.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county clashed in several locations in Kirik payam (Warrap state), specifically in Payak, Manyiel, Aker and Dijok and Toch-Thok close to Rualjok. 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Kirik as well as Awul payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior Achir, Mapeir, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county clashed in several locations in Kirik payam (Warrap state), specifically in Payak, Manyiel, Aker and Dijok and Toch-Thok close to Rualjok. 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Kirik as well as Awul payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

On 15 July 2020, 1 person was killed and 4 wounded on an attack by unknown gunmen at an unspecified location between Agany and Mabui in Mapuordit payam in Yirol West county (Lakes state). The survivors reported that the attackers were ""rebels"", but did not specify which rebel group they belong to. All victims are presumed to be ethnic Atuot.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county (presumed to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka, given recent attacks in the area) were reported to have engaged in clashes in Awul payam (actor 2 presumed to be members of the Atok section of the Rek), specifically at Ageny, Aporlak, Biol, Mabyor/Mabior, Achir, Mapeir, Achiir, Anakudhok and Thiemwien, and at Rual Magok and Pacaak Manyiel in the Kuany Goi area (Warrap state). 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Awul as well as Kirik payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), unspecified youth militia (likely to be from Bor or Akobo counties) were reported to be active in the area of Maroiu (implied to be close to Gumuruk in Pibor county, Jonglei state), amid ongoing reprisal attacks against the Murle in the area. There is no information regarding casualties, nor whether a firefight took place.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county clashed in several locations in Kirik payam (Warrap state), specifically in Payak, Manyiel, Aker and Dijok and Toch-Thok close to Rualjok. 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Kirik as well as Awul payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), unspecified Rek Dinka clans from Tonj North county clashed in several locations in Kirik payam (Warrap state), specifically in Payak, Manyiel, Aker and Dijok and Toch-Thok close to Rualjok. 23,186 people were displaced in clashes in Kirik as well as Awul payams, although the source does not specify injuries or fatalities.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column8: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (week of), SPLM-IO forces based in the western half of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state) ambushed the convoy of Lt. Gen Rin Tueny, head of Military Intelligence division of the SSPDF and currently in charge of organizing disarmament campaigns. The unsuccessful ambush took place at an unspecified location likely along the Wau-Tonj road (coordinates for Makongo base used at GP2). There is no mention of fatalities or casualties.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), SPLM IO and NAS fighters were reported to have clashed in the areas of Rotakudi and Khor Kaya in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state), displacing 300 families between the attacks. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (month of), SPLM IO and NAS fighters were reported to have clashed in the areas of Rotakudi and Khor Kaya (presumed to be Khor Kaya One, closer to Rotakudi) in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state), displacing 300 families between the attacks. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), four civilians were killed by an unknown group as they travelled along the Kapoeta-Ngauro (a.k.a. Lauro) road of Eastern Equatoria state. The killings come amid tension between the Didinga and Toposa communities.

column9: Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), raiders (implied to be from Twic county, and accordingly presumed to be of the Twic Dinka clan) attacked three locations in the Mankien area of Mayom county (Unity state), including Kuel, Kuanydit and an unspecified location in the defunct Bul South county. At least 2 people were killed in clashes with local fighters (presumed to be Bul Nuer) and 5 wounded; ""many"" were displaced in the clashes and 12-13 youth are missing, and 200 head of cattle stolen. The home of a spiritual leader was also attacked, and one of the attackers was captured.

Around 15 July 2020 (month of), armed youth from Kakor in Mvolo county (Western Equatoria) clashed with youth from nearby Alel village in Yirol West county, at an unspecified location (likely to be either Alel or Kakor) along the Mvolo/Yirol West border. The source notes that revenge killings and cattle theft occurred in the incident. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 16 July 2020, SSPDF clashed with NAS rebels at Lowe near Liria in Juba county (Central Equatoria state). NAS claimed to have killed 5 SSPDF, and inflicted ""many"" injuries. Over 1,000 people have been displaced from the area, and the village of Lowe was burned. The army has denied that the incident took place.

On 16 July 2020, fighting was reported between Lou Nuer youth and Murle youth at unspecified areas in Pibor county (Jonglei state), amid ongoing reprisal attacks in the area. There is no information regarding casualties.

On 16 July 2020, fighting was reported between Lou Nuer youth and Murle youth at Nanaam in northern Pibor county (Jonglei state), amid ongoing reprisal attacks in the area. There is no information regarding casualties.

column8: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Wildlife Police
column17: On 17 July 2020, unknown attackers killed a Wildlife officer and his security guard (presumed to also be from the Wildlife Service) in the Khor Makuac area of the Juba-Bor road (presumed to be in the Makuach B area of Terekeka county, Central Equatoria state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

Around 18 July 2020 (as reported), seven traders were killed by an unknown group at an unspecified location along the road between Duk Padiet (Duk county, Jonglei state) and Yuai (Uror county, Jonglei state). Two traders are missing, and there is currently no further information on the attack.

On 18 July 2020, unknown raiders (presumed to be from Lakes state) attacked Agany and Wuncuei in Aluak-Luak payam of Yirol West county (Lakes state), killing one police officer and a civilian and wounding two others in a road ambush. The attackers also stole an unspecified number of cattle. Fatalities split across two events.

On 18 July 2020, unknown raiders (presumed to be from Lakes state) attacked Agany and Wuncuei in Aluak-Luak payam of Yirol West county (Lakes state), killing one police officer and a civilian and wounding two others in a road ambush. The attackers also stole an unspecified number of cattle. Fatalities split across two events.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Sudan Tribune; PaanLuel Wel; Radio Miraya
column17: On 18 July 2020, SSPDF soldiers conducting a disarmament campaign disarmed and arrested several SPLM IO soldiers (including a Brigadier General) in the Jebel Teak area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state; approximate coordinates from humanitarian source used). Reports indicate the IO soldiers have since been released.

On 18 July 2020, SSPDF clashed with NAS rebels at an unspecified location in Lobonok county, implied to be in the Karpeto area (Central Equatoria state). SSPDF claimed the event did not take place. There are no reports on fatalities or injuries.

Around 18 July 2020 (weekend of), clashes were reported between the Awan-Parek and Atok section of the Rek Dinka at an unspecified location in north-west Tonj North county (Warrap state, location presumed to be in the Awul area). At least 10 were killed and 19 wounded in the fighting.

column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); IOM: International Organisation for Migration
column17: Around 19 July 2020 (as reported), unknown gunmen were reported to have ambushed two IOM personnel at an unspecified area implied to be in western Jur River county close to Wau (Western Bahr el Ghazal state, coordinates for Ngapdiit close to the river crossing between Wau and Jur River used at GP2). UNMISS forces were reported to have been prevented from intervening by SSPDF and NSS. The source does not mention whether there were fatalities or injuries.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column16: Sudan Tribune; Nyamilepedia; Eye Radio (South Sudan); PaanLuel Wel
column17: On 19 July 2020, SPLM IO soldiers ambushed SSPDF in the Mapel area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), in retaliation for the disarmament and arrest of their colleagues on 18 July. Two SSPDF soldiers were wounded in the ambush, whilst several SSPDF soldiers were reported to have been captured.

column6: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
column17: On 20 July 2020, an NSS Brigadier General along with his security guards held staff at the land registrary office in Juba at gunpoint, before briefly abducting staff, to force them to sign over disputed land in the capital to him. The general has been suspended.

column6: NAS: National Salvation Front (Lo Buron faction)
column17: Around 21 July 2020 (as reported), 45 civilians (including truck drivers) were abducted on the Juba-Mundri road 15km west of Juba (Central Equatoria state, coordinates for nearby Nyarja Na Mere used), with an NAS faction under the commander of Martin Kenya Lo Buron being implicated in the abductions. The six vehicles belonging to the abductees were also torched. All of the abducted were released around 31 July.

On 22 July 2020, armed youth (likely to be either Lou Nuer or Bor Dinka) attacked Likuangole in Pibor county (Jonglei state) clashing with local Murle youth, amid intensive violence in the Greater Pibor area. 6,000 have been displaced to Pibor town, and there are currently no reports on fatalities.
On 22 July 2020, Mundari and Bari militias clashed in the Mangalla area of Juba county (Central Equatoria state), in a dispute over ownership of the area. At least one member of the Bari was killed.

Around 22 July 2020 (week of), Malual Dinka clashed with Sudanese Misseriya pastoralists at an unspecified location in Northern Bahr el Ghazal state. There is no further information, including whether there were injuries or fatalities.

column9: Thuyic-Agar Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Students (South Sudan)
column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 22 July 2020, members of the Gony section of the Agar Dinka clan killed two students from the Thuyic section of the Agar Dinka at Panbarkou village in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), in what is described as a revenge killing.

Around 22 July 2020 (week of), Bor Dinka youth reportedly attacked villages in the area of Arilo payam in Lafon county (Eastern Equatoria state), accusing the local ethnic Lopit civilians of being Murle, amid reports of large movements of Bor Dinka in Eastern Equatoria, who are seeking to attack Pibor from a southern direction. An unspecified number have been displaced; there was no mention of injuries or fatalities in the source.

On 23 July 2020, SSPDF conducted a counter-insurgency campaign in the Karpeto area attacked civilians (including gold miners), including at Nyarbang, Yapa and a mine close to Karpeto. SSPDF have been accused of raping and killing civilians, and engaging in looting. Hundreds were displaced. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition-Aguelek: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Aguelek Faction)
column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 23 July 2020, gunmen (accused of being from the Aguelek faction of the SPLM-IO) attacked Dhieu village near Lake No in Pariang county (Unity state), killing at least 9 and wounding three in two separate attacks (on 23 and 28 July), and displacing an unspecified number of residents of the area (all victims presumed to be Ruweng Dinka). The IO have denied involvement of their forces. Fatalities distributed evenly across two events.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), SPLM IO forces abducted nine civilians in the Jebel Teak area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state; approximate coordinates from humanitarian source used) in retaliation for the arrest and disarmament of IO soldiers by SSPDF on 18 July.

On 23 July 2020, SSPDF conducting a counter-insurgency campaign in the Karpeto area attacked civilians (including gold miners), including at Nyarbang, Yapa and a mine close to Karpeto. SSPDF have been accused of raping and killing civilians, and engaging in looting. Hundreds were displaced. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), unknown attackers fired upon a civilian vehicle at Makongo Base in Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state), killing one of the eight passengers. There is no clear motive for the attack.

column7: Awan-Parek-Rek Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Atok-Rek Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 24 July 2020, armed youth (implied to be from the Apuk subsection of the Padoch section of the Rek Dinka, and from the Awan-Parek section of the Rek Dinka) attacked members of the Atok section of the Rek Dinka at Mabior Atuok cattle camp in Awul payam of Tonj North county (Warrap state), killing at least 15 and wounding 6. 1,000 head of cattle were stolen, but later recovered. The source does not state that an exchange of fire took place.
On 25 July 2020, the NAS claimed that government soldiers killed two businessmen travelling from Loka West to Lainya town (Central Equatoria state). There is no comment from the army.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 25 July 2020 (as reported), SPLM IO forces abducted six civilians (including two children) in the Jebel Teak area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state; approximate coordinates from humanitarian source used) in retaliation for the arrest and disarmament of IO soldiers by SSPDF on 18 July.

On 25 July 2020, SSPDF were reported to have attacked NAS rebels at Yondu in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state). NAS rebels claimed to have repulsed the attack, inflicting ""some casualties"" on the SSPDF.

column9: Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 26 July 2020 (weekend of), unknown attackers fired upon three pastoralists at Tit Atong near Rumbek town (Lakes state), killing one and wounding two (all victims presumed to be Agar Dinka). There is no further information.
Around 26 July 2020 (weekend of), unknown attackers killed a boda boda driver between Cueicok and Titcok near Rumbek town (Lakes state). There is no further information.
Around 26 July 2020 (weekend of), unknown attackers attacked students, killing one in Rumbek town (Lakes state), before engaging police in a firefight. There is no further information.
Around 26 July 2020 (weekend of), a civilian was killed by unknown gunmen on the main road in the Romich area of Tonj East county (Warrap state). There is no further information.

column9: Bor Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan); Christian Group (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 27 July 2020, Murle raiders attacked Makol Cuei in Bor South county (Jonglei state), killing at least 24 civilians, and wounding at least 12 (all victims presumed to be Bor Dinka). Initial reports suggested 4 were still missing, with subsequent reports indicating that bodies of the missing have been found (4 additional fatalities added). The church compound was torched, with the priest and his family also killed. 500 head of cattle were looted, and 2,500 households have been displaced to nearby areas. The attack comes amid intense violence in southern Jonglei state.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 28 July 2020 (between 27 July - 29 July), unknown cattle raiders attacked Liet village close to Lake No in Pariang county (Unity state). At least 10 people were killed and 3 injured (all victims presumed to be Ruweng Dinka) and 2,000 head of cattle raided between this attack and another on Liet village. Fatalities distributed evenly between two events.

column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 28 July 2020 (between 27 July - 29 July), unknown cattle raiders attacked the administrative headquarters close to Lake No in Pariang county (Unity state; location presumed to be payam HQ at Biu). At least 10 people were killed and 3 injured (all victims presumed to be Ruweng Dinka) and 2,000 head of cattle raided between this attack and another on Liet village. Fatalities distributed evenly between two events.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition-Aguelek: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition (Aguelek Faction)
column9: Ruweng Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 28 July 2020, gunmen (accused of being from the Aguelek faction of the SPLM-IO) attacked Dhieu village near Lake No in Pariang county (Unity state), killing at least 9 and wounding three in two separate attacks (on 23 and 28 July), and displacing an unspecified number of residents of the area (all victims presumed to be Ruweng Dinka). The IO have denied involvement of their forces. Fatalities distributed evenly across two events.

Around 29 July 2020 (as reported), unknown attackers killed 7 civilians in the Roc Roc Dong area of Jur River county (Western Bahr el Ghazal state). A local official has accused SPLM-IO forces of being responsible, but this is currently unconfirmed.
Around 29 July 2020 (week of), four civilians were abducted by an unknown group who attacked an unspecified village in Torit county (Eastern Equatoria state). There is no further information.

column9: Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Students (South Sudan); Amothnhom-Kuei-Agar Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 29 July 2020 (week of), a student was killed by armed youth at Biling Cok village in Rumbek East county (Lakes state). The attack is the latest in a series of revenge killings taking place within the Amothnhom subsection of the Kuei section of the Agar Dinka clan.
On 31 July 2020, two unknown attackers fired upon a civilian travelling along the road near Makpandu in Yambio county (Western Equatoria state). The civilian escaped unharmed.

Around 31 July 2020 (end of month), SSPDF soldiers were reported to have beaten several civilians in the Agoro area of Magwi county (Eastern Equatoria state). The soldiers attacked a woman when she insisted they pay money for alcohol they had imbibed, before beating a local administrator who intervened, breaking his arm. At least three others were beaten by soldiers the following day. All victims presumed to be Madi.

column8: SPLM-N-Agar: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Malik Agar faction)
column17: Around 1 August 2020 (beginning of month), armed militia from Maban county clashed with Sudanese SPLM-North rebels based in Maban (Unity state), at an unspecified location implied to be near one of the refugee camps along the central belt of the county. The clashes follow a defection within the SPLM-N, which has increased insecurity and rebel activity in and around the camps. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 1 August 2020 (beginning of month), armed militia from Pariang county (and presumed to be Ruweng Dinka) attacked SPLM-IO positions at an unspecified location in Guit county (Unity state), after IO forces raided several villages in Pariang in late July. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Around 1 August 2020 (between 29 July - 4 August), 11 individuals (presumed to be Murle) were treated for gunshot wounds in Pibor (Jonglei state), amid intense violence in southern Jonglei state. The identity of the attackers (likely to be either Lou Nuer or Bor Dinka) was not specified, and there is currently no report on fatalities.
On 2 August 2020, a cattle trader was shot dead in the Malou-Pech area of Cueibet county (Lakes state). There is no further information.

Around 2 August 2020 (as reported), ongoing clashes between Bor Dinka militia and Murle militia were reported in the Verteth area of southern Pibor county (Jonglei state). There is no further information, and no mention of injuries or fatalities in the source.

column9: Shilluk Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Labour Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 3 August 2020, Ruweng Dinka militiamen attacked traders travelling from Tonga to Liri in Panyikang county (all victims presumed to be Shilluk), killing at least 3 and seriously wounding 5, amid heightened tensions between Dinka and Shilluk armed groups in the wake of the contested appointment of Lt. Gen Johnson Olonyi.

Around 4 August 2020 (as reported), armed youth from Kakhor village in Mvolo county raided nearby Alel village of Yirol West county (Lakes state), clashing with youth from the village. At least two were killed, and property and livestock were raided. The attack follows tension related to cattle raiding between the two villages.

On 4 August 2020, 8 armed men (four of whom were in military uniform, and have been coded as army) looted a house and raped two female teenagers at Lotoral in the greater Mundri area (coordinates for Mundri, Mundri West county, Western Equatoria state used at GP3). Six men have been arrested.

Around 5 August 2020 (week of), a number of killings and looting events were reported to have taken place in Tambura county (Western Equatoria state), amid tensions between the Zande and Balanda ethnic groups in the county. Four men have been arrested in connection with the attacks. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

column8: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column16: Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); National Salvation Front
column17: On 5 August 2020, NAS rebels attacked government forces in the Gorom area of Bungu payam in south-western Juba county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS claim to have killed 11 soldiers from the Tiger Division whilst suffering 3 wounded; the army has disputed this, saying that the NAS attacked police and SSPDF soldiers at a gold mine at Konyokonyo killing 6 (including 2 civilians). Local reports say fighting took place at Konyokonyo mine and Digala village (and possibly at Kansuk), with NAS likely killing 9 (6 soldiers and 3 civilians). 9 fatalities distributed across 2 events.

column8: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column16: Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); National Salvation Front
column17: On 5 August 2020, NAS rebels attacked government forces in the Gorom area of Bungu payam in south-western Juba county (Central Equatoria state). The NAS claim to have killed 11 soldiers from the Tiger Division whilst suffering 3 wounded; the army has disputed this, saying that the NAS attacked police and SSPDF soldiers at a gold mine at Konyokonyo killing 6 (including 2 civilians). Local reports say fighting took place at Konyokonyo mine and Digala village (and possibly at Kansuk), with NAS likely killing 9 (6 soldiers and 3 civilians). 9 fatalities distributed across 2 events.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column9: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 5 August 2020, youth from the Amothnhom and Nyang subsections of the Kuei section of the Agar Dink clashed at Patuweng cattle camp in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state), killing 6 and wounding between 1 and 4 others. The clashes are an escalation of a fight that began after cattle were driven through an area reserved for use by another cattle keeper.

Around 6 August 2020 (as reported), NAS rebel claimed SSPDF soldiers attacked civilians in Lobonok payam of Juba county (Central Equatoria state), torching houses of local residents who were accused of supporting rebels. There is no comment from the army.

Around 6 August 2020 (as reported), NAS rebel claimed SSPDF soldiers attacked civilians in Bazi in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state), looting animals and property from IDPs sheltering in the area. There is no comment from the army.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; New York Times; Eye Radio (South Sudan); VOA
column17: On 8 August 2020, armed youth (described as 'Gelweng' (cattle guards), and presumed to be Rek Dinka) attacked SSPDF at Romich in Tonj East county (Warrap state), following an incident earlier that day in which one or two of their kinsmen were killed by soldiers. At least 148 were killed in two days of fighting, including 63 soldiers (with 48 wounded), and 94 wounded (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). Hundreds have been displaced, and the market at Romich was looted and torched. A Sudanese trader was among the dead, and two colleagues of the trader were also wounded.

column9: Rek Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: New York Times; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; VOA; Juba Monitor
column17: On 8 August 2020, SSPDF soldiers killed one or two individuals (presumed to be Rek Dinka) in disputed circumstances in Romich, Tonj East county (Warrap state). Some reports suggest soldiers harassed an individual wearing a scarf that detonated membership of cattle guards who are currently being disarmed in the area, others suggest soldiers fired at individual(s) attempting to flee from the soldiers and/or fired into the market place. The incident has sparked intense violence in the area; two soldiers have been arrested.

Around 8 August 2020, soldiers were reported to have engaged in several sexual assaults against women in Romich (Warrap state), carried out whilst clashes with armed youth were ongoing. One woman was gang-raped by 10 soldiers.

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column16: New York Times; Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; VOA; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 9 August 2020, armed youth (described as 'Gelweng' (cattle guards), and presumed to be Rek Dinka) once again attacked SSPDF at Romich in Tonj East county (Warrap state). At least 148 have been killed in two days of fighting, including 63 soldiers (with 48 wounded), with 85 others being killed (a mixture of armed youth and civilians caught in the crossfire) and 94 wounded (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). Hundreds have been displaced, and the market at Romich was looted and torched. A Sudanese trader was among the dead, and two colleagues of the trader were also wounded.

column9: Aid Workers (South Sudan); Private Security Forces (South Sudan)
column17: On 10 August 2020, unknown gunmen attacked an NGO compound and assaulted the security guard in Akobo town (Akobo, Jonglei).

column9: Health Workers (South Sudan); Aid Workers (South Sudan)
column17: On 10 August 2020, unknown attackers ambushed two NGO vehicles (including an ambulance) at Abegi in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). One of the drivers was shot and wounded, whilst the ambulance was looted by the group.

On 10 August 2020, unknown gunmen ambushed one NGO driver of a two vehicle aid convoy (second vehicle was an ambulance) between Yei and Lasu near Abegi (Yei, Central Equatoria), shooting and wounding him.

column9: Lou Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 11 August 2020 (as reported), over 100 individuals (presumed to be Lou Nuer civilians) were treated for various wounds in Pieri in Uror county (Jonglei state) (attackers presumed to be Murle militia), amid intense violence in southern Jonglei state. There is currently no report on fatalities.

On 11 August 2020, unknown gunmen attacked two humanitarian boats close to Shambe port in Yirol East county (Lakes state), killing five, and looting the boat. There is no information on the attackers.

Around 12 August 2020 (as reported), government forces (presumed to be SSPDF) clashed with a local militia (presumed to be Eastern Jikany Nuer) in Nasir (Upper Nile state), killing three militiamen, wounding one, and wounding a government soldier. The reason for the fighting is not specified.

On 13 August 2020, NAS rebels claimed to have repulsed an attacked by SSPDF at Kigwo in Kajo-Keji county (Central Equatoria state), killing 3 government soldiers and wounding several, with one NAS rebel also being killed. The army has not commented.

On 14 August 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a passenger bus in the Aru junction area of the Juba-Nimule highway in Juba county (Central Equatoria state). At least 3 were killed (including the driver) and 1 or 4 wounded. Several people (including children) were also kidnapped, with four children later recovered. 8 suspects have been arrested.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Catholic Radio Network
column17: On 17 August 2020, dozens of women demonstrated in Juba, in protest at the recent murder of three children in the west of the city, and a rise in rape and killings in the capital. [size=dozens]

column9: Toposa Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Miners (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 August 2020, unknown attackers killed 5 Toposa gold miners in the Nakwasigirya area (described as being approx. 30km south of Kapoeta town) in Kapoeta South county (Eastern Equatoria state). A local MP has accused Didinga of being responsible for the killings, which has been denied by the chairperson of the Didinga community.

On 19 August 2020, an SSPDF soldier shot and killed two bodyguards (presumed to also be SSPDF) at the house of an unspecified general in the Tongping/Juba Na Bari area of Juba. The perpetrator has been arrested; there is currently no clear motive for the killing.

column16: National Salvation Front; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor
column17: On 19 August 2020, NAS rebels ambushed SSPDF bodyguards of Vice-President James Wani Igga (who was not present at the scene) in the Lobonok area (rebels have stated the location was at Kuse Pager near Luwala, whilst other sources indicate the location is between Yapa and Karpeto), killing 6 of the bodyguards and wounding 2. One bodyguard may also have been abducted.
Around 20 August 2020, SSPDF and NAS rebels clashed at Opiri near Liria in Juba county (Central Equatoria state), displacing 6,208 people. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.
Around 20 August 2020, SSPDF and NAS rebels clashed at Giwaya near Bari in Lainya county (Central Equatoria state), displacing 1,574 people. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

On 20 August 2020, the spokesperson of Vice-President James Wani Igga claimed that NAS rebels killed a civilian travelling from Pageri village to Yapa in Lobonok payam (Central Equatoria state), a day after rebels attacked the VPs bodyguards in the same area.

column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 23 August 2020, a mob was to have beaten a soldier to death in the Sherikat neighbourhood of Gumbo in Juba county (Central Equatoria state), after the soldier shot dead a retired police Major General. The family of the Major General questioned the account provided by authorities, and expressed doubt that the perpetrator was actually killed. [size=no report]

On 23 August 2020, SSPDF accused NAS rebels of ambushing an SSPDF vehicle carrying food and salaries in the Mile 55 area close to Lainya town (Central Equatoria state). In the firefight, 4 SSPDF were killed and 2 wounded. NAS rebels have claimed that disgruntled SSPDF soldiers were responsible for the ambush (NAS presumed to be the attacking force).

On 24 August 2020, several hundred teachers (estimate at just under 300) demonstrated in Bor (Jonglei state), condemning the failure of authorities to transfer them money they said they are entitled to under an internationally-sponsored cash-transfer program. [size=nearly 300]

column16: Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); VOA
column17: On 24 August 2020, residents of Melut county rioted at the DPOC base close to Paloich in Melut county (Upper Nile state), burning tires on the airport road outside the facility. The demonstrators decried environmental damage, a lack of jobs for local youth, and severe health consequences relating to oil production in the area. Unspecified security services (presumed to be army) attempted to disperse the youth, wounding three. [size=at least three]

column16: Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan); VOA
column17: On 25 August 2020, residents of Melut county demonstrated once again at the DPOC base close to Paloich in Melut county (Upper Nile state), denouncing environmental damage, a lack of jobs for local youth and economic benefits from oil extraction, and severe health consequences relating to oil production in the area. The residents began a sit-in protest, which lasted until 29 August, before senior government officials agreed to implement the protesters demands. [size=no report]

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 26 August 2020 (week of), NAS and SPLM-IO forces clashed at Busia in the north-west Panyume area in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state). Hundreds of civilians were displaced to Yei in the fighting (which also affected nearby Kenyira and Kendila); there are no reports regarding casualties or fatalities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 26 August 2020 (week of), NAS and SPLM-IO forces clashed at Kenyira, south-east of Liggi in Yei county (Central Equatoria state). Hundreds of civilians were displaced to Yei in the fighting (which also affected nearby Busia and Kendila); there are no reports regarding casualties or fatalities.

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 26 August 2020 (week of), NAS and SPLM-IO forces clashed at Kendila in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state). Hundreds of civilians were displaced to Yei in the fighting (which also affected nearby Busia and Kenyira); there are no reports regarding casualties or fatalities.

column9: Bul Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 27 August 2020 (as reported), two people (presumed to be Bul Nuer) were killed at an unspecified location in Mayom county (Unity state), by a suspected raiders from neighboring Warrap state (presumed to be Rek Dinka).

Around 27 August 2020 (as reported), one person was killed at an unspecified location in Unity state (state capital of Rubkona used at GP3), in what is described as a revenge killing (presumed to have been carried about by a communal militia). There is no further information.

column9: Ruop-Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 27 August 2020 (as reported), a local militia (presumed to be Agar Dinka) shot and wounded a youth from the Roup section of the Agar Dinka in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state), implied to be in the Cuei Adukan area.

column9: Ruop-Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: Around 27 August 2020 (as reported), unknown gunmen attacked two youth from Roup section of the Agar Dinka in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state), implied to be in the Cuei Adukan area. There is no information on whether the youth survived or were wounded.

Around 28 August 2020 (as reported), two groups of Bul Nuer militiamen clashed in Mayom town (Unity state), after one group attacked a ceremony being conducted by a spiritual leader. At least 12 were killed and over 20 wounded (including the spiritual leader), in fighting which the source links to rivalries among the Bul Nuer security and military elite.

On 29 August 2020, NAS rebels claimed that SSPDF attacked two trucks operated by Somalis at or near Kalipapa in Juba county (Central Equatoria state), stealing food relief they were carrying for IDPs in Lainya, and torching the vehicles. South Sudan authorities have instead implicated NAS rebels in the attack.

column9: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 August 2020, police clashed with armed cattle raiders from the Pakam section of the Agar Dinka near Rumbek town (Lakes state). There were no injuries, one of the raiders was arrested, and 7 cows recovered.

column7: Macar-Kongor-Gok Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Langdiing-Ayiel-Gok Sub Clan Group; Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Juba Monitor; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 August 2020, a police officer was killed in Cueibet town (Lakes state) in what are described as a series revenge killings between among Gok Dinka sections (with the Kongor sub-sub-section of the Panyar sub-section of the Macar section and the Waat subsection of the Macar section presented as being the attackers, against members of the Ayiel subsection of the Langdiing section).

column7: Macar-Kongor-Gok Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column9: Langdiing-Ayiel-Gok Sub Clan Group; Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column16: Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 31 August 2020, two men riding on boda bodas were killed close to Cueibet town (Lakes state) in what are described as a series revenge killings between among Gok Dinka sections (with the Kongor sub-sub-section of the Panyar sub-section of the Macar section and the Waat subsection of the Macar section presented as being the attackers, against members of the Ayiel subsection of the Langdiing section).

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Twic Media Reports; Juba Monitor; Radio Tamazuj
column17: On 31 August 2020, an armed group suspected of coming from Mankien in Mayom county (and presumed to be Bul Nuer) attacked Goom-gooi village in Twic county (Warrap state), targeting women and children. Two women (one of whom was pregnant) were killed along with two male children, whilst four children were wounded (one seriously).

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 1 September 2020, armed pastoralists from the Waat subsection of the Macar section of the Gok Dinka clan attacked police at an unspecified location in Abiriu payam of Cueibet county (Lakes state), after police confiscated cattle belonging to the Waat youth. One police officer, one raider, and one civilian were killed in the clashes, and five wounded.

On 1 September 2020, a passenger vehicle was attacked at Sanjasiri close to Yei town (Central Equatoria state), killing two and wounding four or five. Authorities have implicated NAS rebels in the attack, but this is currently unconfirmed.

On 2 September 2020, more than 60 former employees of an UNMISS contractor demonstrated at the UNMISS base at Bor (Jonglei state), blocking the entrance to the base (through unspecified means) in protest over changes to the workers contracts (including a lack of sick leave) by the contractor, and the subsequent dismissal of the workers. [size=more than 60]

On 3 September 2020, more than 60 former employees of an UNMISS contractor once again demonstrated at the UNMISS base at Bor (Jonglei state) for a second day, blocking the entrance to the base (through unspecified means) in protest over changes to the workers contracts (including a lack of sick leave) by the contractor, and the subsequent dismissal of the workers. [size=more than 60]

column7: Aliamtoc-Dhiei-Agar Sub-Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column9: Farmers (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
column17: Around 5 September 2020 (as reported), armed pastoralists from the Gony subsection of the Athoi section of the Agar Dinka clan, operating alongside youth from the Dhiei subsection of the Aliamtoc section of the Agar Dinka, clashed with farmers (presumed to be Agar Dinka) at Cuei Adukan in Rumbek Centre county (Lakes state) after the pastoralists entered the farmers land. Three were killed and one wounded.

column9: Agar Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 7 September 2020, two civilians including a local chief of the Panyar subsection (presumed to be Agar Dinka) were killed by unknown gunmen at Liet-heer in Paloc payam in Rumbek East county (Lakes state), with one injured. Two chiefs from the Beer section have been arrested, but deny their involvement.

column8: Abiem-Lou Aguer Geng-Malual Sub-Clan Militia (South Sudan)
column17: On 8 September 2020, members of the Awan Chan section of the Rek Dinka clashed with members of the Lou Aguer Geng subsection of the Abiem section of the Malual Dinka at Akong in Aweil East county (Northern Bahr el Ghazal state), killing two and wounding an unspecified number. The reasons for the clashes - which occurred during an event with traditional dances - is unclear, though two (including a soldier) have been arrested for instigating the violence.

On 8 September 2020, more than 20 former employees of PANCROP company (an UNMISS contractor) once again protested at the UNMISS base at Bor (Bor South, Jonglei state), blocking the entrance to the base (through unspecified means) in protest over changes to the workers contracts (including a lack of sick leave) by the contractor, and the subsequent dismissal of the workers. [size=more than 20]
On 8 September 2020, an unknown armed group ambushed a passenger vehicle on the outskirts of Rumbek town (Rumbek Centre, Lakes). Two people were killed.

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 9 September 2020, SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces were alleged to have jointly attacked an NAS base in Agabe in Morobo county (Central Equatoria state, presumed to be in the eastern area of Lujulu payam given a concomitant attack in the same area). NAS soldiers claimed to have killed 4 of the attackers and wounded an unspecified number between this event and another in Laiza, whilst the rebels stated they suffered one fatality and two wounded (fatalities distributed evenly across two events).

column8: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 9 September 2020 (week of), SPLM-IO forces claimed to have repulsed an attack by an unspecified rebel group (presumed to be NAS rebels active in the area) at ""Pannyi"" payam (presumed to be a misspelling of Panyume payam), sustaining minor injuries, and abducting one or two of the attackers, with the remainder fleeting across the Congolese border.
On 9 September 2020, a South Sudanese INGO staff member was shot dead in Wau town (Western Bahr el Ghazal state) by unknown attackers, who then stole his motorbike.

column9: Bul Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: Around 9 September 2020, unknown attackers (reported to be from Warrap state, and presumed to be Rek Dinka militia) attacked a pastoralists community in the area of Ria/Buomria payam in Mayom county (Unity state). 17 people (largely women and children) were killed (5 of whom died later of their injuries) and 25 others were injured, whilst over 200 head of cattle were stolen (all victims presumed to be Bul Nuer).

column7: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 9 September 2020, SSPDF and SPLM-IO forces were alleged to have jointly attacked an NAS base in Laiza in Morobo state (Central Equatoria state). NAS soldiers claimed to have killed 4 of the attackers and wounded an unspecified number between this event and another in Agabe, whilst the rebels stated they suffered one fatality and two wounded (fatalities distributed evenly across two events).

On 10 September 2020, over 1000 IDPs took to the streets of Juba and went around Jebel Kujur, demonstrating against the withdrawal of UNMISS forces in Juba town (Juba, Central Equatoria). The protesters urged the UNMISS body not to withdraw at this time of crisis. [size=over 1000]

On 14 September 2020, unknown attackers (reported to be from Cueibet county, and presumed to be Gok Dinka militia) shot and killed an SSPDF soldier in the Ameth Chok area of Tonj South county (Warrap state).
On 14 September 2020, unknown gunmen attacked a family and sprayed bullets in Tonj town (Tonj South, Warrap). Two people were killed.

On 15 September 2020, Eastern Jikany Nuer youth from Ying and Nyangore payams clashed in Ulang town (Upper Nile state). A NGO staff member was shot during the crossfire, and died the next day. There is no information on casualties or fatalities among the clashing youth.

Around 15 September 2020 (month of), unknown cattle raiders attacked the Otallo area of Pochalla county (Jonglei state), stealing an unspecified number of cattle, some of which were later recovered. The source does not mention whether there were fatalities or casualties.

On 18 September 2020, hundreds of striking teachers demonstrated in Bor town (Jonglei state), calling for money from an international cash-transfer program to be paid to them. The Education Director of Jonglei state fired several shots in the air to disperse protesters, and was arrested by police for doing so. [size=hundreds]

column7: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column9: Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan); Pastoralists (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 September 2020, two subsections of the Luo section of the Ciec Dinka (the Kuacdit and Kuacthii subsections) clashed at an unspecified location of Yirol East county (Lakes state), implied in the source to be near the state capital of Adior. 4 were killed, and two dwellings torched, in what is described as a cattle-related clash.

column9: Gok Clan Group (South Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 18 September 2020, an unspecified group shot and killed at least 2 people riding on a motorbike at an unspecified location in Cueibet county (Lakes state), in what is implied to be an ongoing series of revenge killings in the area. Both perpetrator and victims are presumed to be Gok Dinka.
On 20 September 2020, an unknown group shot and killed a woman in the Sindiru area of Juba county (Central Equatoria state), wounding her baby and abducting her other two children.

column9: Dok Clan Group (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)
column17: On 20 September 2020, two people were killed in Rubkuai in Mayendit county (Unity state), in unclear circumstances which may be a revenge killing. Both victims and perpetrators presumed to be Dok Nuer.

On 21 September 2020, striking teachers demonstrated once again in Bor town (Jonglei state), calling for money from an international cash-transfer program to be paid to them, burning tires in the streets. [size=no report]
