Conflicting reports have 62 deaths, other more. The Misseriya who drive their cattle south to graze during the dry season claimed sole responsibility for the attack. More than 3,200 civilians are forced to flee after their homes were destroyed. Clashes last over several days.
Hundreds of Darfuris held protests in three cities in the north, the latest in small anti-government demonstrations. No report of police intervention.

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Students (Sudan)
column17: In the Sudanese capital, meanwhile, around 100 students from Al-Nilein University demonstrated outside the campus, shouting ""Ocampo, you said the right thing!"" in reference to the ICCs chief prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo.
20 are killed, 350 structures burned when a village comes under attack by unknowns.
Three are killed when their vehicle is struck by a landmine.
Hundreds of Darfuris held protests in three cities in the north, the latest in small anti-government demonstrations. No report of police intervention.

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Protesters of Ad Damazin said the police dispersed their protest without arresting any of the 600 hundred protesters. They praised the state government led by the SPLM North Sudan President Malik Agar saying local authorities understand their cause.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole, Pibor county over 18-24 April left approximately 200 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen. 27 killed in one event on 19 April.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: A peacekeeper serving with the joint United Nations-African Union mission in Darfur was killed today after being abducted by armed men following a firefight in the north.

Rebels from the newly formed SSLM/A of Peter Gadet in south Sudans oil-rich Unity state continued for a third day to attack southern army positions, both militia and military officials said. On 21 August, SSLM/A allegedly seized Mankien in Mayom county for a day, and ""destroyed several vehicles"" belonging to the SPLA, before SPLA reinforcements arrived and recaputured it. SSLM/A forces advanced toward Mayom, causing significant civilian displacement, destroying the local market and some homes, and looting and severely damaging the compound of an international NGO in Mankien. Throughout the campaign 250 people are killed in Mayom (35 fatalities already coded, remaining 215 split between 3 events)

WFP Senior Programme Assistant, Santino Pigga Alex Wani, was killed in an ambush on 22 April by unknown assailants near Duk Payuel, Duk County in Jonglei State. Santino - who was a Senior Programme Assistant - was on mission with members of WFPs cooperating partner, Joint Aid Management, or JAM, when the vehicle they were travelling in was attacked.

The SPLA sustained heavy losses when the newly formed SSLM/A of Peter Gadet ambushed a group of wounded soldiers in an unarmed convoy. No details of exact casualty numbers. Throughout the campaign 250 people are killed in Mayom (35 fatalities already coded, remaining 215 split between 3 events)
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole, Pibor county over 18-24 April left approximately 200 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen. 27 killed in one event on 19 April.

At least 55 people were killed and scores wounded in fighting in northern Jonglei State between south Sudans army and rebel militiamen loyal to Khartoum. The SLPA claims victory and takes a small village once in control of Gabriel Tangs militia.
""A national staff of a UN agency was killed during an attack by armed assailants while traveling on duty.""
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole, Pibor county over 18-24 April left approximately 200 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen. 27 killed in one event on 19 April.
Surrender/Defect:""Gabriel Tang and around 1,300 of his men surrendered peacefully on Sunday,"" said Malaak Ayuen, spokesman for the souths Sudan Peoples Liberation Army (SPLA).
Gabriel Tangs militia surrenders peacefully after an estimated 160 are killed. 266 are believed killed over the course of the week.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole, Pibor county over 18-24 April left approximately 200 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen. 27 killed in one event on 19 April.
Recent clashes between residents of Rumbek county and Cueibet county that lead to the death of one woman in Cuibet. The woman was killed by pastoralist youth from Rumbek North county.

Demonstrators gather chanting anti-government slogans and calling for trying President Al-Bashir at the International Criminal Court which charges him with masterminding war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide committed during Darfur conflict.
Sudanese military planes bombed two villages in southern west Jebel Marra , on Wednesday destroying drinking water well, a rebel spokesperson said.
Anti-regime protests are organized in the capitals of Darfurs three states. Several reportedly arrested.
Anti-regime protests are organized in the capitals of Darfurs three states. Several reportedly arrested.
Anti-regime protests are organized in the capitals of Darfurs three states. Several reportedly arrested.

A heavily armed Sudanese military convoy moved illegally into the flashpoint border district of Abyei, sparking clashes with SPLA police that left 12 people dead. Northern troops retreated to Goli, still within the districts boundaries.

Tribal clashes over a land dispute in Sudans oil-producing state of South Kordofan left at least 15 people dead and 10 injured. The clash was between different, unnamed, branches of the Misseriya tribe.

Five people were killed in cold blood last night in Rumbek Central county on Monday by pastoralist youths the counties commissioner suspected to be from Cueibet county. Foru women including a young girl, and one man, were killed in the attack.

Fighting took place between Goli and Todach over attempts made by Sudan Armed Forces component of the Joint Integrated Units in the area to beef up its military forces. Clashes took place between SAF and local SPLA police.
The United Nations said it had recovered the bodies of three civilians at the scene of fighting in Abyei.
A fresh attack by rebels from the newly formed SSLM/A of Peter Gadet left a further eight people dead in oil-producing Unity state.
Around 1,000 people on Tuesday gathered in the centre of the Sudanese capital Khartoum to praise the late al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden, chanting ""Death to America"".

Fighting continued on Tuesday over attempts made by Sudan Armed Forces component of the Joint Integrated Units in the area to beef up its military forces. Clashes took place between SAF and local SPLA police.
Clashes in south Sudan have left many dead in separate cattle raids and attacks in Pibor county, officials said on Tuesday.
Warring ethnic groups clash over cattle. One group made the initial attack and the other responded in revenge. There were many deaths reported, though no numbers are provided.
After being repelled by SPLA in Unity State, SSDF forces attached cattle camps in Warrap State, killing 34 and wounding 45 civilians.
Militiamen, under the leadership of southern rebel Philip Bepan, attacked the southern Sudan Peoples Liberation Army in Unity state on Saturday but were repelled.
Following a cattle raid, the SSDF were attacked by cattle herders who were under-armed and suffered heavy losses.
Two merchants were shot dead by soldier from the South Sudan army (SPLA) soldier at Rubkotna Mosque in Unity state on Sunday. Another merchant was seriously wounded in the shooting.
South Sudans army (SPLA) has attacked forces from the newly formed SSLM/A of Peter Gadet in the Nyadiet area of Unity state on Sunday and Monday killing 84 according to a local official.

A South Sudan rebel group carried out a cattle raid in Warrap state that killed 34 people, including women and children. The rebel group were later tracked by herders resulting in a clash that killed 48.

A South Sudan rebel group carried out a cattle raid in Warrap state that killed 34 people, including women and children. The rebel group were later tracked by herders resulting in a clash that killed 48.

10-15 LRA disguised as SPLA soldiers abducted 7 people from the village of Sangu, S. Sudan while the civilians were attending a funeral on May 9th, 2011. Local police forces pursued the LRA as they fled west towards CAR.

Agreement: North and south Sudan have agreed to start withdrawing unauthorised troops from the flashpoint Abyei border region, a week after clashes there left 14 people dead. Later in the month, on 31 May, the forces agreed to establish a 20km long demilitarized zone between Sudan and the newly formed South Sudan before the South is able to gain full independence June 9th.
South Sudans army (SPLA) has attacked forces from the newly formed SSLM/A of Peter Gadet in the Nyadiet area of Unity state on Sunday and Monday killing 84 according to a local official.

column6: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Attackers shot and wounded four Zambian peacekeepers in the disputed Sudanese region of Abyei
Five people, including a child, were abducted and one killed when the LRA attacked a funeral procession in Bangu in Western Equatoria state.
80 or more, SPLA forces and civilians, are killed when Sudanese forces attack a southern stronghold.
Twelve are killed when a heavily armed Sudanese military convoy (North) moved illegally into the flashpoint border district of Abyei, sparking clashes with police (South).
Eight people were wounded in two separate blasts when police came to clear away a cluster of bombs discovered there. There were 19 grenade type bombs discovered there.
Sudanese warplanes bombed two small towns in Southern Darfur. Nine civilians killed, seven others injured.

The UN reports Sudanese forces have killed 1,000 Nubian tribal civilians since the beginning of the year, most of which during the month of June 2011. Reportedly the forces would engage in aerial bombardments, gunfire attacks and door-to-door searches. Fatalities split across the first 6 months of 2011, with 500 coded in June.
Sudanese warplanes bombed a small town in Northern Darfur. No word of causalities.
The UN reports Sudanese forces launched an air strike on two towns in Northern Darfur, killing 10 civilians.
Sudanese forces launched an air strike on a small village in Northern Darfur, but caused no causalities.
The UN reports Sudanese forces launched an air strike on two towns in Northern Darfur, killing 10 civilians.
Southern forces ambush a Northern convoy, reportedly kill 22 soldiers.

column7: UNMIS: United Nations Mission in Sudan (2005-2011)
column17: SLPA forces attack a joint Sudanese military/UNMIS convoy, drawing condemnation from the UN. No report of injury of death. The Sudanese army responded with an aggressive military offensive on the town of Abyei and surrounding villages, deploying more than 25 tanks and shelling and bombing civilians areas.

Sudan military tanks enter Abyei and they and the SPLA begin heavy fighting. Rivalry between the Misseriya northern Arab nomads and the pro-southern Dinka Ngok is the main source of the conflict in Abyei.
Northern and Southern forces exchange artillery fire in areas north of Abyei.

Thousands of rebels and civilians loyal to them flee Abyei after northern forces gained control of the town. Over 100 people have been killed since the battle for the town began and possibly 100,000 displaced. Northern forces claim the majority of the city.
Northern forces took control of Abyei after bats of fighting throughout the city, and most of Abyeis residents had fled south toward Bahr el Ghazal.
Armed looters set fire to parts of Sudans disputed Abyei border town, days after northern forces had claimed the area. Northern forces drive out nearly 20,000 residents out of the city.

""One national INGO staff was badly beaten and treated for head injuries when four INGO staff were stopped by SPLA at a checkpoint. The staff members were brought to the military barracks and one was badly beaten.""
A woman was abducted by suspected LRA forces from Nabiapai, southern Sudan, on June 1st, 2011.
Sudanese government troops fought with rebels in the western Darfur region on Wednesday and Thursday, killing at least two rebel fighters.
Sudanese police used batons to disperse 400 farmers demonstrating against what they said was an insufficient government offer to buy their land to operate a state run farming scheme.
Sudanese government troops fought with rebels in the western Darfur region on Wednesday and Thursday, killing at least two rebel fighters.

""A driver contracted by an INGO to transport supplies was killed when his vehicle was struck by a landmine. Several other people were also killed, but they were not working for the contractor or the INGO.""
Reports of fighting in an area 35km southeast of Kadugli. Some 53,000 people are said to have been forced to flee.

The UN reports Sudanese forces have killed 1,000 Nubian tribal civilians since the beginning of the year, most of which during the month of June 2011. Reportedly the forces would engage in aerial bombardments, gunfire attacks and door-to-door searches. Fatalities split across the first 6 months of 2011, with 500 coded in June.
An unknown armed group loyal to northern forces clashes with SPLA forces. No reported deaths or injuries.

Two day fighting between elements of Sudans northern and southern armies in Kadugli, capital of volatile South Kordofan state, has killed six people and forced UN agencies to suspend operations in the town.
SPLA forces attack a police station in a border town and steal weapons.

Reports of ethnic atrocities at the hands of the Sudanese military. Including summary executions, wanton killings, arbitrary arrests, torture, arson and disappearances in addition to destruction of physical infrastructure and burning of churches. No numbers of deaths.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
column9: Government of Sudan (1989-2019); Nuba Ethnic Group (Sudan); Prisoners (Sudan)
column17: On June 7th, Military Intelligence agents arrested over 25 civilians (predominantly government employees, and members of the Nuba ethnic group) in Kadugli, who are reported to still be in detention as of September 2019. Information suggests the detainees have been kept in very poor conditions, and several have been severely tortured.
""A UN national staff member was shot and wounded by Sudanese Armed Forces (PDF), near PDF HQ.""
Heavily armed cattle raiders kill 71 in Lakes State.

The national army chased remnants of southern forces out of the town ahead of a transfer of power to the southern government in approximately a month. A precondition of southern independence was the complete expulsion of southern forces from the north, or a disarming of them.

The Sudanese army has launched repeated air strikes on southern army positions in Unity state, less than a month ahead of the souths independence, in a bid to seize the states oil fields. Three killed. Other reports of ""mass suffering"".
Southern fighters shoot down two northern fighter planes. This claim is denied by the Sudanese government.
Two Catholic Church workers were murdered by government forces in Sudans South Kordofan State in what one church adviser called a campaign of ""ethnic cleansing.""

Sudanese warplanes carry out an aerial bombardment of a small village early in the morning. It is not clear if there were causalities, but many of the citizens were displaced and moved to an adjacent village.
A SPLA cattle raid kills 29 ranchers.

Scores of Kenyan pastoralists are feared to have been killed while on a mission to steal animals in South Sudan. The raiders, from Turkana West district, are said to have died in a fierce fight with Toposas as they attempted to escape with livestock bounty into Kenya.
The Sudanese army reports targeting rebel (southern) forces in various parts of the state.

The UN accused the Sudanese government of carrying out an extensive bombing campaign of South Kordofan, targeting tribal Nubans. 140,000 civilians have fled from fighting over the course of several days and weeks.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
In June and July, forces loyal to Athor furthered their assault on members of the murle tribe in Pibor county. Casualties are unknown.
South Sudans army said it clashed with northern troops in the disputed Abyei border region. Five northern troops reported killed.

Agreement: Rebel leader David Yau Yau and about 200 of his troops surrendered to Juba in June 2011 and were given amnesty. Yau Yau and his commanders were given accommodation in Juba as they awaited their integration package from the SPLA, while his troops were sent in various regions for training. Yau Yau will re-defect in 2012.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
8 LRA forces attacked Kidi, near Gangura, South Sudan on June 17th, 2011 and abducted 2 children and injured 1 other civilian.
Sudanese armed forces shelled a UN base in Abyei. No report of causalities of injuries.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Sudanese Armed Forces shell the southern border town of Agok, where tens of thousands of people fled to after northern troops overran Abyei last month. No reports of causalities.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Darfur rebels raided a village and killed seven and clashed with government forces.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Fierce clashes were witnessed between unidentified armed men and the police in Tonj. Assailants killed innocent civilians and raided cattle in the melee. Nearly fifty civilians reported killed.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Clashes between northern and southern forces in South Kordofan State. The area of the state where the fighting took place is very ethnically divided.
One woman was killed and four others, including two children, were wounded in an aerial attack on Kauda
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.

""A UN worker and his (pregnant) wife were beaten when three intruders broke into their residence in the middle of the night. They were hospitalized for their injuries. Nothing was stolen and the reason for the attack is unclear.""
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
Clashes between ethnic Lou Nuer and Murle in Likuangole and Gumuruk, Pibor county over 15-24 June left approximately 400 Murle dead and thousands of cattle stolen.
A train carrying south Sudanese home just two weeks before their country celebrates full independence from the north was attacked on by Misseriya Arab militiamen loyal to Khartoum.

Change to armed group: SPLA dissident and former Government of Southern Sudan presidential adviser, Maj-Gen Abd-al-Baqi Akol, announced the formation of the Islamic Army in South Sudan to defend the constitutional rights of Muslims and practice of their religious rituals.
The northern army carried out cross-border air strikes that killed three civilians and wounded 17 in south Sudans oil-producing Unity state just a week before independence.

Non-violent activity: More than 400 fighters from rebel and government groups laid down their arms and take part in a disarmament and reintegration exercise run by the United Nations-African Union Mission in Darfur (UNAMID).
At least three people have been killed and ten others injured when a Sudan Armed Forces plane bombed two villages in Southern Kurdufan State.
Unidentified ethnic groups fight over cattle. Deaths reported, however numbers are not given.
The Sudanese Army said Tuesday it repulsed an attack launched by the forces of Sudan Peoples Liberation Army. No causalities reported.
Police forces fire tear gas to disperse two separate protests against the lack of running water in the city.
Across the Nile, in a Khartoum suburb police disperse a protest over the lack of running water.

column6: ANCD: National Alliance for Change and Democracy
column17: Arrests: Chadian rebels have denounced the repatriation and imprisonment of 27 senior members of their force captured in Sudan. Sudan picked them up and flew them back to Chad, where they were now in prison, said the statement from Mahdi-Ali Mahamat of the National Alliance for Change and Democracy (ANCD).

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: A landmine in the disputed area around Abyei kills four Ethiopian UN Peacekeepers in a disputed area of Abyei.

column8: UNMIS: United Nations Mission in Sudan (2005-2011)
column17: Gunmen on Friday killed an African UN peacekeeper and badly wounded another in an ambush in Sudans strife-torn Darfur region.
An Italian humanitarian worker employed at a child-care centre in western Sudans Darfur region was kidnapped by unknown persons when she was driving to a local airport with two others.
SAF dropped bombs on a secondary school in Kauda in August 2011. No casualty.
Water shortages sparked a new bout of protests in Sudans capital Khartoum, where the police forcibly dispersed the demonstrators and arrested some of them.
At least six people were killed and 13 injured when a military forces Antonov bombarded Um Durayn County in conflict-hit South Kurdufan State, however, the Sudanese army denies this.

Arrests: The [ruling] National Congress Party has banned the Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (SPLM) in all states and arrested a large number of its members and seized property and documents belonging to it in different states and localities.
SPLA guerillas attack army positions, however, the Governor of Blue Nile State denies this claim.
Property destruction: SPLA claims the Sudanese military is intentionally destroying crops and farms belonging to the Nuba people in an attempt to starve the state.
Sudanese television reports that forces loyal to the South have attacked civilians, killing 17 of them, some of them children, and injuring another 14.
Sudanese military attacked militia groups aligned with South Sudan. Causality list not reported.
Sudanese military jets carry out strike missions several cities and towns controlled by the SPLA. No report of causalities.
Clashes between forces in the capital of Blue Nile State included a raid on the home of the Governor. No causalities reported.
Clashes between forces in the capital of Blue Nile State included a raid on the home of the Governor. No causalities reported.
An aerial bombing of SPLA positions kills four civilians.
Military rule established for a town heavily displaced during the recent civil war.
Sporadic clashes occur. Vague details.
Heavy fighting reported among government forces and rebels. Gun fights lasting more than 20 minutes witnessed. Details vague.
Two children were killed and three others seriously wounded in Sudans war-ravaged Darfur region when unexploded munitions they were playing with exploded.

The Sudanese army inflicted heavy losses on rebels in the embattled border state of Blue Nile when they fought in Baw town. A number of causalities, though no numbers are provided. Sudan military forces implement fighter aircraft and gunships.
""One national staff of an NGO was injured and subsequently died when he was shot by two armed men who entered his house and tried to steal a vehicle at gunpoint.""

Thirteen police and killed and 30 more wounded when the officers attempt to rescue a group of hostages taken in the region last month (August). The police were specific to report they kidnappers were an armed gang, not a rebel group.
SLA authorities claim they kill 33 members Sudanese military in a clash. Witness claim they saw members of the SLA kidnap a civilians, though the SLA denies this claim.
SLA command reports they were attacked by 43 four wheel vehicles of the Sudanese army near Kass.
Heavy fighting reported. Sudanese forces claim they have broken a ""siege"" of the town, but it is unclear if they had gained control of the city.
Sudanese forces claim they have gained control of Qaysan in Blue Nile State.
Sudanese forces attack a garrison town held by the SLPA. The SLPA was able to repulse them, but not before much of their equipment was damaged.
A clash between Sudanese Forces and members of JEM leaves one dead and a JEM cache of weapons confiscated. The clash took place in extreme Northern Darfur State, where Libya, Chad and Sudan meet.
Two residents of Gadaref, who are of an unidentified ethnic minority group are allegedly killed by police, sparking a protest the following day.
A group of farmers attempt to stop of group of nomads from cross their land, but the nomads react by opening fire on them, killing three and injuring two.
The SPLA reports that 30 of their soldiers were killed and 60 members of the Sudanese military were killed during clashes. The SPLA were eventually forced to retreat from the location.
Police fire tear gas to disperse a group of ethnic minority protesters who were calling for the chief of police to step down after two of their fellow tribesmen were killed the previous day.
Rebels attacked an army checkpoint in Sudans war-torn border state of South Kordofan, killing an NGO worker and 12 Sudanese soldiers, according to the UN.
The Sudanese army attacked two unnamed villages in North Darfur, killing seven of their inhabitants.
The SLA accused the Sudanese military of killing two civilians in Northern Darfur,
Police fired tear gas and used batons to break up a protest in Khartoum against the punitive rise in food prices, with protesters burning tires and demanding cheaper food.

column8: UNMIS: United Nations Mission in Sudan (2005-2011)
column17: Three UN Peacekeepers are killed in Darfur by unknown attackers. The names and nationalities of the slain peacekeepers have not yet been released, but UN said two were soldiers and one was a police adviser. Six other peacekeepers were injured in the ambush, three of them seriously, while one of the assailants was also killed.
Sudanese forces claim they have taken the town of Sali after heavy fighting, however, rebel forces deny this.
""An INGO local staff driver was shot in the leg when his vehicle was carjacked in Nyala by two armed men. The driver was hospitalised.""
Aerial bombings of a rebel held town cause most of its inhabitants to flee into neighboring Ethiopia.

Conflicting report: Sudanese army spokesman reports its forces attacked a rebel military camp and captured it. SLPA authorities claim they were attacked, but were able to repel the Sudanese, killing 15 of their soldiers.
The Deputy Governor of Blue Nile State reports rebel forces have fled the town of Kurmuk at the sight of advancing Sudanese forces.

Hundreds of Sudanese Islamists and others staged a rare demonstration in central Khartoum in solidarity with Syrias anti-government protesters and called for an end to President Bashar al-Assads crackdown.
Local government reports that ""hundreds"" of rebel forces were killed in a clash with Sudanese forces.
Heavy fighting in and around Talawdi, no causalities reported.

Sudanese authorities report the capture of a town after clashes. Both sides claimed considerable losses. This area was formally a rebel stronghold, who vowed to fight back and reclaim the town, which borders Ethiopia.
Heavy fighting in and around Talawdi, no causalities reported.
Sudanese police fired tear gas to disperse some hundreds of demonstrators who protested against the accidental killing of boy by the security forces several days ago.
Rebels in Sudans main oil-producing state claimed to have destroyed four tanks during tow days of fighting near the states capital, drawing a denial from the countries army.

column8: UNMIS: United Nations Mission in Sudan (2005-2011)
column17: Unidentified gunmen killed one UN peacekeeper and injured two others in an attack while they were on a patrol.
Change to armed group: An alliance of rebel groups committed to regime change in Sudan (SLM/JEM) said on Saturday that a key Darfur rebel movement had joined them, the newly formed SRF.
Residents begin a sit-in demonstration against the Merowe Dam, which displaced many residents. The protest lasts over a month without reported police interference.
The Sudanese military claims it has captured a rebel held town 17km south of Kurmuk.
""A nurse working for an INGO was knocked off his motorcycle and beatne. He suffered fractured ribs and a concussion.""
Sudanese forces attack rebel held positions with heavy artillery killing two civilians and badly wounding four others.

The Sudanese Army gained control of the Turouji area south of Kadogli, capital of the South Kordfoan State which is witnessing armed clashes between Sudanese army and fighters of Sudan Peoples Liberation Armys (SPLA) northern sector.
Sudanese forces gain control of rebel held areas, including a supply route near Lake Jau.
Sudanese forces overran a rebel base, a number of rebels were killed in the fighting.
A police officer is killed by an armed man outside a market.
The armed forces of Sudan and South Sudan clashed in a border region claimed by both sides. Warplanes and artillery used in the fighting,
Protracted fighting reported in the Rashad locality. No report of causalities.
Sudanese forces capture an area known as Al-Atmur.
Protracted fighting reported in the Rashad locality. No report of causalities.
Sudanese forces capture several tanks and other weapons from rebels.
Protracted fighting reported in the Rashad locality. No report of causalities.
22 students are injured after they were attacked by members of the NCP. The student group was protesting against the political party for various alleged abuses.

Sudanese Security forces opened fire on inmates in El-Fasher prison two days ago when they attempted to prevent the execution of some rebels sentenced to death. The rioting began when rumors of the executions spread.
Heavy fighting between government troops and SLPA rebels in Warni, at least 19 government troops killed.
Prisoners riot, resulting in the death of one and the injury of nine others.
Sudanese and SLPA forces clash over a disputed border town.
Fighting reported in the Taruje area of Blue Nile State.
Two Sudanese soldiers reportedly rape a woman in Zam Zam camp.
Sudanese riot police used batons to beat youths shouting anti-regime slogans in support of residents displaced by the giant Merowe Dam in the north. Nearly 100 were gathered.
Police used tear gas and batons to break up protesters reassembled to demonstrate against a dam that displaced residents.

The Sudanese army said it killed Khalil Ibrahim, the leader of a main Darfur rebel group, JEM, along with thirty of his fighters, during fighting west of the capital Khartoum, touting the death as a key victory over the rebels who had rejected a peace deal with the government. It is unclear if he was the only causality in the fighting.

University of Khartoum students hold an exam boycott and assemble to protest the placement of a dam. Police fired tear gas and wielded batons while the youth fired back with stones. No report of causalities. 70 arrested, two injured.

A massive student protest took place inside the campus of Khartoum University against the background of last weeks events in which the Sudanese police entered the university twice and cracked down on students.
Police teargas brawling and rioting political supporters.

At least twelve students have been injured when violent clashes erupted between student supporters of JEM Darfur rebels and those of the ruling National Congress Party (NCP). The clash was sparked by the killing of a JEM leader over the past weekend.
Police inexplicably fire tear gas at an independence Day gathering, three are killed when they are trampled.
Fighting between rivals spills over into Blue Nile State.
Fighting between the army and northern rebels. Rebels claim the killing if nine government troops, but the army denies this. Others claim 16 villagers were killed.
Fighting between rebels and military continues for a second day.
Fighting between government forces and SPLA rages. Six soldiers killed, many military vehicles and aircraft destroyed.

Unknown Khartoum backed rebels kidnap two Catholic priests because the parish was harboring a former member of the Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army. Parishioners also claim there has been ongoing political intimidation directed toward them.
Churches report militias loyal to Sudan (north) have been intimidating civilians because of their loyalty of to the south.
SPLA rebels shoot down a military aircraft, but the government denies this.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: A Nigerian UN peacekeeper is killed in an attack, three others injured.
Rebel forces claim to have shot down a government helicopter, but the military denies this. Official report is that six soldiers were wounded in a clash.
26 reported dead in Blue Nile clashes.
Reports of human trafficking of Eritrean refugees by the Rashaida tribe.
Police disperse protesters of a recently installed governor. Injuries reported.

Government protesters hurl rocks at police trying to disperse them for a second day. Two rioters dead. 28, including 18 police were wounded. Property destroyed by rioters. The protestors, who were chanting ""the people want Kasha back"", set on fire the headquarters of the ruling National Congress Party (NCP).
Two demonstrators killed by police on the third day of rioting.
29 Chinese workers and 9 members of the Sudanese military are kidnapped by the SPLA and held for ransom. The group released a portion of them several days later.
Government forces rescue 16 Chinese workers kidnapped by rebels. The remaining were released in the coming week.
Government aerial forces drop bombs on a school in the Nuba Mountains. Soon after the United States accused the government of intentionally targeting civilians. Four women suffered minor injuries.
Opponents of the constructing of a dam north of the city gather to protest near the presidential palace. The group was dispersed by police.
A armed group kidnapped three villagers near Tabet location.
South Sudan forces claim northern forces launched an aerial bombardment on a disputed border town. Four South Sudanese soldiers killed.

South Sudanese fired from their government jobs (most were soldiers) in neighboring Sudan blocked a major road in Sudans capital Khartoum on Wednesday, hurling rocks at passing cars and demanding severance benefits.
In February 2012, SAF bombed Heiban county, destroiyng buildings of a bible school. No casualty.

Sudanese police arrested hundreds of students in a pre-dawn raid on dormitories in the University of Khartoum on Friday, in a crackdown on a campus that has been at the center of recent anti-government protests in late 2011.
""One UN staff member sustained injuries to his head after being assaulted by police officers affecting an arrest in the UN compound.""

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: JEM militants capture 49 UN peacekeepers and release them the same day. Exact location unknown.
Fresh fighting in Sudans Darfur region has killed 12 government soldiers when they are ambushed by Minni Minawi militia.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: Gunmen ambushed a bus carrying international peacekeepers in the Darfur region of Sudan, wounding two peacekeepers.

Southern forces launch an attack on government forces near al Aabyad, breaking the armistice agreement. 150 Sudanese forces reported killed, unknown opposing. Political fallout immense - Khartoum believes rebel forces are in league with those of South Sudan and are operating under that assumption.
JEM reports they have taken over and now control Jau.

SRF and SPLA forces from the south both claimed credit for fighting around Jau, suggesting that they acted in unison, taking control of a second town new Jau. Many Sudanese losses reported, including armaments.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: A second attack on UN forces in ad Duwayn in a week results in two injuries.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: A UN patrol is ambushed by unidentified men. One death reported.
Sudanese Armed Forces expelled an attempt by the SPLA to attack Mafloa area north of Talodi city inflicting the rebel forces heavy losses in lives and materials. Exact numbers not reported.
SPLA rebels shell a small town under the control of government forces with heavy artillery. No injury report.

column9: Aid Workers (Sudan); Civilians (International); Aid Workers (International); UN: United Nations
column17: ""A UN international staffer was kidnapped along with his Sudanese driver as they headed towards the office near Al-Hilal stadium in downtown Nyala. The two were kidnapped by unknown armed men driving a Land Cruiser vehicle. UPDATE: The driver was released shortly after the abduction, and the international staffer was released 86 days later following concerted negotiations.""
Security forces stage a full scale attack on JEM forces in Darfur. Many causalities, though specific numbers are unknown.

A group of 100 or more rioters storm a police station after the mob believes they were involved in the killing of a girl the previous day. One woman injured, later died. Later in the day a group with the same grievance set up barricades in a road.
A group in a small town protests police violence in Khartoum after a girl is killed there in an unexplained dispute.
Sudanese military claims victory after fighting with two confederated rebel groups. Causalities unknown.
Murle militias raid a Lou Nuer area, clash, steal women and cattle. The clashes lasted over two days and produced more than 220 deaths.
Second day of clashes between ethnic groups.
An unidentified armed group attacks and kills two police in an attempt to steal their vehicle.
SRF and SPLA forces both claimed credit for the shooting down of an unmanned IranianSAD plance in South Kordofan on 13 March, suggesting that they acted in unison.
A second woman is killed in aerial attack by the Sudanese military. This event was reported south of Kalkadda.
A woman is killed in a Sudanese aerial attack.
The Sudanese Army kills a ""large number"" of rebel forces in a clash.
The armies of the north and south clash in several areas on the run up a peace talk.
A member of the military shot and killed a civilian because the person was upset he had to move his selling station in a market.
Refugees, numbering in the 200-300s gather outside their camp near El Fasher. It was unclear what they were protesting.
As north/south fighting continues southern forces loose ground. Northern forces claim victory.
""One UN national staff member was shot and wounded by an unknown assailant while he was exiting the UN compound in Kabkabiya.""
SLPA forces capture the towns of Um Dual and Mafloa from state forces.
Fighting in a small town reported by both the north and south. At least 20 northern forces killed.
Police kill a student and political activist.
Police fire tear gas and arrest 10 to disperse a funeral procession/protest demonstration for a student activist allegedly killed by security agents.
Authorities Darfur have managed to repulse and chase away a rebel group which sneaked from South Sudan into Asalaya locality in south Darfur. No causality report.
Clashes killed 13 government troops and one rebel fighter in an area 20km south of Damazin.
South Sudanese forces attacked a northern oil site near their shared border.

Movement of forces: The government and military forces of Sudan declare a general state of mobilization for their fighting forces to combat those of South Sudan as well as officially ending planned peace talks between the nations.

Government air raids on Talodi, South Kordofan, in April 2012 injured 18 people. Some victims became paralysed, had blurred vision, vomiting, or diarrhoea, which could be the result of exposure to insecticides and herbicides, or nerve agents.
Sudanese authorities seize weapons and documents from a South Sudanese Politians home. The owner was not present.
Non-violent activity: A police college expels all its southern cadets.

Commander of 4th Infantry Division in Damazin, Gen Murtada Abdullah Warraq, has affirmed that the Armed Forces supported by other regular forces defeated the SPLA and took full control over Mugan, Jelgo, and Gabanite. 50 rebels killed, 17 captured.

Commander of 4th Infantry Division in Damazin, Gen Murtada Abdullah Warraq, has affirmed that the Armed Forces supported by other regular forces defeated the SPLA and took full control over Mugan, Jelgo, and Gabanite. 50 rebels killed, 17 captured.

Commander of 4th Infantry Division in Damazin, Gen Murtada Abdullah Warraq, has affirmed that the Armed Forces supported by other regular forces defeated the SPLA and took full control over Mugan, Jelgo, and Gabanite. 50 rebels killed, 17 captured.
A Muslim mob has destroyed a church compound in Sudan, the pastor said, amid a mood of nationalist fervour after Khartoum said it liberated an oilfield occupied by South Sudan.
The military repulsed a large attack by Sudan Peoples Liberation Army [SPLA] on Taludi town. No report of death or I injury.

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: A Togolese police unit serving with the African Union-United Nations Hybrid Operation in Darfur (UNAMID) has come under a surprise attack in western Darfur. One causality.
Members of the SLM-MM/SLA-MM militia killed eight and injured several others after a group of people refused to pay extortion money for protection from the militia.
At the end of April, SPLA-N rebels in South Kordofan tried once again to take the control of Talodi which located near the border with the South Sudan. But the government forces repelled the attack.
A group of 15 gunmen traveling on camels shot two men dead on Friday in Absafariq, three km from Gereida camp, South Darfur.
Four children were killed and one was wounded when leftover munitions exploded in Sudans Darfur region, the African Union-United Nations peacekeeping mission (UNAMID) told AFP.
South Sudan said on Monday it is completing withdrawal processes of police forces from the contested area of Abyei, apparently in conformity with the United Nations Security Council resolution.

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: Rebel fighters belonging to the faction of Sudan Liberation Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLA-MM) managed to seize the town of Gereida in South Darfur from the hands of government troops. SLA-MM fighters attacked from southeast and engaged with an army garrison before proceeding to control the town.

column9: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: The Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) announced today that it has expelled rebels who yesterday took control of Gereida town in South Darfur.

Fighting between government forces and armed opposition movements has displaced a large number of civilians from Tabet in North Darfur. Witnesses living near Zam Zam camp said they could hear the echoes of bombs and missiles towards Tabet, where soldiers and militias are based. The armed opposition group was not identified.

South Sudan said on Thursday it has withdrawn a significant number of its police forces from the contested border region of Abyei, apparently in compliance with the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) resolution endorsing African Union recommendations.
Two herders were injured and more than 80 sheep killed when an Antonov plane dropped four bombs on a valley near Labadu in South Darfur this morning.

Arrests: On Saturday security authorities in Gereida arrested 25 people thought to be conspiring with the Revolutionary Front. Witnesses said the raids were carried out by pro-government militia. They fear that the detainees may have been killed.

A man was killed and eight others wounded in air strikes south of Tawila, North Darfur. A resident described the ongoing aerial bombardment by the Sudanese air force in Numeira, Kouto, Dali, Crowla and Masalit areas of Tawila last Friday to Sunday.

Witnesses said On Sunday and Monday masked pro-government militias and others in army uniforms looted cars, beating the passengers before stealing their belongings. They said three people suffered head injuries in the attacks.
Arrests: The Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) accused the Sudanese security service of arresting 30 people in Gueraida a South Darfur area.

Displaced people in Tawila camps have also reportedly been suffering random attacks from Abu Tira (central reserve forces). A camp resident told Radio Dabanga that Abu Tira forces have been violently attacking and stealing from displaced people, particularly at night time.

Witnesses said On Sunday and Monday masked pro-government militias and others in army uniforms looted cars, beating the passengers before stealing their belongings. They said three people suffered head injuries in the attacks.
Clashes broke out between student political groups after NCP-affiliated armed youths attacked a SLM political leader. 12 studenst were injured in the ensuing clash.

column9: SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); Students (Sudan)
column17: NCP students attacked a pro Sudan Liberation Movement led by Minni Minawi activist, Abdullah Genki with batons and sticks causing him serious injuries.
Five pro-government militants seriously wounded two displaced people in an assault near Mornei camp, West Darfur.

Hundreds of displaced people have fled back to Neem camp in East Darfur after they were attacked by new settlers on their original lands, when they returned with state authorities as part of the programme of voluntary return

The Sudanese army known as SAF has wrestled control of two areas - Suda and Gam areas in the Angasana Mountains - held by the rebel Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement/Army North (SPLM/A-N) in Blue Nile State. According to the deputy governor, capturing the two areas came after five days of fighting in which SAF inflicted on rebel forces ""great losses in lives and equipments.""

According to the deputy governor, capturing the two areas came after five days of fighting in which SAF inflicted on rebel forces ""great losses in lives and equipments.""

Gunfire broke out on Monday at a refugee camp on the Sudanese border with Eritrea during a clash between refugees and police that left one policeman wounded. About 300 people had gathered outside the administration office of Shagarab camp, which is largely populated by Eritreans, to protest security conditions. ""A number of police surrounded them. Then I heard shooting and the people scattered. I saw one police officer injured, and a soldier tried to help him,"" a witness reported.
300 people protesting witnessed gunfire on Eritrea-Sudan border between police and refugees. One policeman was injured.
Sudans official news agency says a car has exploded in a Red Sea port in the countries east, killing one man. Car bombs are unusual within Sudan. Israel is accused of involvement by Sudan.

According to the deputy governor, capturing the two areas came after five days of fighting in which SAF inflicted on rebel forces ""great losses in lives and equipments.""

Weapons Seizure: On May 24, The Independent newspaper in the United Kingdom published photos of a failed cluster munition in the settlement of Ongolo in Southern Kordofan. Residents said that it had been dropped from a government aircraft on April 15. Rights groups called on the SAF to explain the use of cluster munitions and join the international treaty banning the weapon.

According to the deputy governor, capturing the two areas came after five days of fighting in which SAF inflicted on rebel forces ""great losses in lives and equipments.""
Shooting throughout the night in Hamidiya camp for displaced people in Zalingei is terrorising camp residents

Military spokesperson yesterday in press briefing put Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) death toll to 64 soldiers killed following Monday fighting. For the past three days there has been continuous aggression of aerial bombardment by Khartoum in Warguet, Majak Woi and Kiirkou in Northern Bahr el Ghazal State.

For the past three days there has been continuous aggression of aerial bombardment by Khartoum in Warguet, Majak Woi and Kiirkou in Northern Bahr el Ghazal State.
A displaced man was shot dead by pro government militia and his body dumped in Dummah camp near Nyala in South Darfur.
Civilians in North Darfur remote area of Forog demonstrated to the United Nations on Wednesday to provide them with more humanitarian assistance complaining from shortage of water and medicines.
The Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF) and the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) reportedly clashed in Um Sinetaya, some 21 kilometers sout-east of Babanusa on Thursday.
Planes of the Sudan Armed Forces bombarded the area. One civilian was reportedly killed in the bombings. Others were brought injured to the hospital in Babenusa.

Inhabitants of Al-Sahafah neighbourhood in south Khartoum yesterday afternoon blocked Muhammad Najib main street and another side road in the Mahatat Sabah protesting water cuts and the demonstrations continued for more than three hours before they were dispersed by riot police.

Movement of forces: A Sudanese police contingent has pulled out of the disputed Abyei area, Sudans army said on Friday, after the foreign ministry denied their presence and the UN called for their withdrawal.
Rebels in Sudans South Kordofan on Sunday claimed to have killed or wounded almost 100 government fighters ahead of the June 5 first anniversary of war in the state. 48 reported killed.

Inhabitants of Al-Sahafah neighbourhood in south Khartoum yesterday afternoon blocked Muhammad Najib main street and another side road in the Mahatat Sabah for the second time in two days protesting water cuts and the demonstrations continued for more than three hours before they were dispersed by riot police.
Three pro-government gunmen shot a displaced man, Abbakr Omer Musa on Saturday seriously wounding him in the leg before stealing his belongings.

Justice and Equality Movement military spokesman Badawi Sakin Musa told Radio Dabanga that JEM and the Sudan Liberation Movement Unity faction carried out an attack on military forces in North Darfur. Both sides claimed victory. 45 reported killed.
Two people were killed in an exchange of gunfire with militants at a village near Dali.
Agreement: Sudan and South Sudan have agreed to unconditionally withdraw their forces for 10 km north and south of the disputed border areas to establish a demilitarized zone on their joint border.

Residents that fled Dali near Kabkabiya have said their village was completely burned down by militias. Witnesses told Radio Dabanga that dozens of residents fled towards Kabkabiya yesterday evening after gunmen attacked killing one resident and wounding several others.

Sudanese journalists and Communist Party members held a sit-in on Tuesday to protest against repeated restrictions against their newspaper, part of what press freedom advocates describe as an intensifying clampdown on critical voices.
Student recruits at the national [compulsory] service camps in Al-Abbasiya in South Kurdufan State have rallied in protest against what they termed as overdosed military training.
Seven government troops were killed and six injured in Tabaldi in East Darfur in clashes with the Sudan Revolutionary Front on Wednesday.
A clash took place between Military Forces of Sudan (1989-) and Military Forces of south Sudan (2011-) in Al-Meram area in South Kordofan, 33 km inside the Sudanese territories.

column6: SPLM-Peace: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (Peace Faction)
column17: Change to armed group: SPLA/M-Peace, a dissident faction of SPLM, held its founding convention in Khartoum.

Looting: Rebels (South Sudan) active in Jebel Si. Looting.

Looting: Rebels (South Sudan) active in Abu Gamra. Looting.
Military forces of Sudan (1989-) attack SPLA/M in Silik near Damazin, they were defeated. Unknown number killed. Military forces of Sudan dispute claims of this battle.
Looting: Rebels (South Sudan) active in Wadi Hawar. Looting.
SPLA/M, led by Minni Minawi stole an ambulance, leaving the woman it carried in labour on the roadside without medical help & abducted driver. SPLA/M deny involvement in this event.
Movement of forces: Rebels in 21 military vehicles equipped with various types of weapons entering the vicinity of Shangil Tobaya area.
22 year old woman shot in leg in a random shooting by an unidentified armed group (Sudan) thought to be a pro-government militia
Unidentified armed group (Sudan) shot a man in Kassab Camp in Kutum Monday evening following a demand for possessions.
Military Forces of Sudan (1989-) killed a woman in air strikes in an area 30 km west of Numeira village in North Darfur.
2 policemen were killed and 6 others injured when their car was ambushed by an unidentified armed group (Sudan), around 3km from Habila in Western Darfur.
1 man shot dead by an unidentified armed group (Sudan) following a demand for his horse in Kereinik, Western Darfur.
1 man shot & injured in his car following an accusation that he loyal to the Sudanese government. Police Forces of Southern Sudan (2011-) tried to catch the gunmen but failed.
Five men wearing Military Forces of Sudan (1989-) uniforms looted a car travelling from Um Duhun near Garsila.
An Unidentified armed group (Sudan) of 30 men on horseback shot a man and tried to expel farmers from their land near Gereida in South Darfur.

Protesters (Sudan) protest in Atbara.
Unidentified armed group (Sudan) attacked Um Ajora town in Al-Salam locality and targeted properties of civilians (Sudan).
Military Forces of Sudan (1989-) repel rebels in Um Ajora in the Al Salam locality following attacks on civilians from an Unidentified armed group (Sudan).
SPLA/M- Minnawi faction and JEM rebels who had seized control and were looting passengers on the El-Fasher/Nyala road were stopped by Military Forces of Sudan (1989-).
Khartoum University students protest over food prices Saturday evening. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) break up the protest with tear gas.
Khartoum University students protest over food prices Sunday. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) break up the protest with tear gas and batons. 7 protesters arrested on charges of instigating riots.
Displaced Darfuris in camp Kendeby of West Darfur were chased from their farm lands in Sirba. Settlers beat 5 women & confiscated their seeds as they tried to return to their land.
Student protests took place in Kassala following austerity measures.
Student protests took place at Shendi University following austerity measures.

Arrests: Police forces of Sudan (1989-) arrest 79 people - including 25 students - for participating in demonstrations in Khartoum. On the same day, police arreszed 40 members of opposition groups during a meeting at the premises of the Haq movement in Khartoum on charges of inciting riots.
Protest held at Ahlia University over austerity measures. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) were seen beating protesters with batons.
Protesters (Sudan) demonstrate at Blue Nile University in Damazin.
Protesters (Sudan) attempt to start a protest at the main bus station in Khartoum but are dispersed by Police forces of Sudan (1989-).
Anti-regime protesters riot in the North of the city about austerity measures, burning tires. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) dispel the riot by beating protesters with batons.
Student protests took place in Kassala following austerity measures.
Students protest at Khartoum University over austerity measures. Police used force to disperse the protesters.

An imam and local leader for the displaced people, Ibrahim Haroon Ahmed (52) was shot dead on Tuesday evening by an unidentified armed group (Sudan) near the offices of Hamedya camp, one of the main IDP-camps in the vicinity of Zalingei.
Police forces of Sudan (1989-) use tear gas to disperse 200 protesters chanting anti-regime slogans in Omdurman market.
Protesters (Sudan) gather at the headquarters of the opposition National Umma Party in Omdurman. Reports indicate that a number of protesters were arrested by Police Forces of Sudan (1989-).
Students riot at Khartoum University over austerity measures. Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) suppress them with tear gas.
200 rioters (Sudan) gather in the Thawra district of Omdurman, condemning the government and burning tires.
2 displaced women from Kassab camp, near Kutum in North Darfur, were raped on Wednesday by gunmen belonging to a militia.
Military Forces of Sudan (1989-) and SPLA/M-N rebels clashed in South Kordofan village of El-Fragil west of Dilling.
Khartoum University students protest in Khartoum. Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) use tear gas to disperse them.
100 Students at Ahlia university protest again, calling for regime change. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) used tear gas and some rioters responded by throwing stones.
Students at a private business college protest, attempting to close off a main street in the city centre. Police forces of Sudan (1989-) dispel the protest with tear gas and batons.
Protesters (Sudan) held a sit-down protest on chairs to block a road. Riot police beat and detain several of the demonstrators objecting to the cost of food.
JEM carry out attacks in disputed Southern Kordofan state.
Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) clash with students protesting in Khartoum.

100 rioters (Sudan) mainly from the opposition Umma Party, separately gathered in Omdurman to call for regime change. Rioters (Sudan) hurled stones while PoliceForces of Sudan (1989-) used batons against them.
Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) used force against demonstrators heading towards Freedom Square in Kosti.
Protesters (Sudan) chanted anti-government slogans at the industrial harbour in Port Sudan and were chased by Police Forcs of Sudan (1989-) using teargas.
Protesters (Sudan) blocked neighbourhood streets with stones in protest over high prices. Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) use tear gas.
100 youth rioters (Sudan) burned tyres and shouted, ""No, no, to high food prices,"" but they dispersed when riot police arrived.
300 protesters (Sudan) demonstrated against rising prices in Sennar. Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) used tear gas and batons.
Protesters (Sudan) hold anti-regime demonstration in El Obeid.
Protesters (Sudan) hold anti-regime demonstration in Wad Medani.
Protesters (Sudan) protest in Al Daim district in Khartoum.
Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) disperse 150 rioters (Sudan) who attacked them using tear gas- no injuries on either side.

Protesters took to the streets in several locations in the Sudanese capital and across the country, chanting slogans about overthrowing the regime on Saturday. Police fired teargas in Omdurman to disperse protesters.

In the area of Fitihab in Omdurman a student demonstration was dispersed by security forces using tear gas, batons and rubber bullets. A student witness tells Radio Dabanga that around fifty [50] students were injured during the crackdown.
The Sudanese Air Force Antanov planes attacked the areas of Sabi, Mashruh Abuzaid and Kira in the East Jebal Marra area in North Darfur. No report of fatalities.

Protests also took place in the cities of Gedarif, Kosti and Sennar.

Radio Dabanga has reported that students demonstrated in front of the Faculty of Education of the University of Khartoum in Omdurman. Demonstrators have yelled slogans as ""People want to overthrow the regime!"". Police fired teargas to disperse the protest.

Sudanese lawyers joined on Sunday a widening protest movement against high prices. The lawyers took to the streets near the courthouse in El Obeid, capital of North Kordofan state, where some were arrested, the witnesses said.

The Sudanese Army, led by Colonel Ammar, and pro-government militias raided the Garwid Barsham-market on Sunday. Witnesses told Radio Dabanga that they entered the market in the Dar El Salaam area in North Darfur with seven (7) Land Cruisers and started looting. Stall owners and citizens doing their daily shopping were assaulted and had their money and cell phones stolen.

A women's demonstration took place in front of the house of former Prime Minister Ishmael Azharis house in Omdurman. The women were banging pots and pans in order to show their anger with the high food prices.
Protests also took place in the cities of Gedarif, Kosti and Sennar.

The sleeping accommodation for students in Al Maselma and Wad Nubawi of the Faculty of Education of Khartoum University in Omdurman was set ablaze by security forces and allied militants. Reports of students being assaulted across the campus, some hospitalised.

Burgeoning demonstrations continued for the tenth day in sporadic parts of Sudans capital Khartoum and other provincial towns as the government reaffirmed its intention of going ahead with planned austerity measures.

Sudanese police on Wednesday kept up a 12-day crackdown against anti-regime demonstrators, witnesses said. Students in the eastern town of Kassala protested two days in a row, dispersed by riot police with tear gas.

In Khartoum the Sudanese Lawyers Syndicate organized protests in front of the Supreme Court, the Khartoum District Court and the courts complex in AlArda Street in Omdurman. An activist lawyer told Radio Dabanga they raised banners which read: ""no to price hikes"" and ""no to the unlawful trial of students and protesters"".

The rebel Sudan Liberation Movement led by Minni Minawi (SLM-MM) ambushed a Sudanese army logistical convoy in Darfur. The attack occurred on Nyala - El-Fasher road at 05:00 pm local time, said a statement issued by Adam Saleh Abakr.

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
column17: In a federal prison in Port Sudan around a 140 prisoners on death row, the most of them from Darfur, clashed with the Prison Guards and police. Eyewitnesses informed Radio Dabanga that they saw police officers firing bullets at the inmates and heard sporadic gunshots until Wednesday evening.

The Sudanese Air Force bombed Korungo Abdullah in the state of South Kordofan Wednesday morning. A witness told Radio Dabanga that an Antonov aircraft dropped 10 bombs on the area, seriously injuring the two brothers Khalifa Jaburat and Kafe Jaburat, and Naima Bahr Addar.

Sudanese police on Wednesday kept up a 12-day crackdown against anti-regime demonstrators, witnesses said. Students in the eastern town of Kassala protested two days in a row, dispersed by riot police with tear gas.

Heavy bombing by the Sudanese Air Force in the the Malam area prevented citizens from leaving their homes eyewitnesses told Radio Dabanga. They said that the Sudanese Air Force bombed the towns of Malam Menawashi, Abu Hamra, Girdeed and Dabba-Nayra in East Jabal Marra, West Darfur.

Heavy bombing by the Sudanese Air Force in the the Malam area prevented citizens from leaving their homes eyewitnesses told Radio Dabanga. Adam Salah, the spokesperson of SLA-Minnawi, said the bombing of these areas in addition to Mashruh Abu Zeyd case continued the whole of Wednesday. He also said over six bombs were dropped in the area of Jabal Al Farra and Sibai in South Darfur.

In Wad Medani the protests had started on Thursday evening and continued after Friday prayers. The people were chanting and calling for the fall of the regime. Police and security forces stopped the protesters and managed to disperse the crowds. A female activists told Radio Dabanga that four demonstrators were arrested

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)

Students of the Omdurman Islamic University demonstrated after the Friday prayers. They attempted to reach the center of Omdurman but the police prevented them by force and arrests.
Activists are also reporting that demonstrations erupted following Friday prayer in the central market in Kassala town in the eastern region as well as in Al-Obayid town in North Kordofan State.

In Khartoum demonstrations erupted in Buri, 16 street, Al Daeim, Jabra Al Iskan, Id Husein, Al Kalakala Al Wahda. Security and police forces were stationed around the main hubs of protests before the end of the Friday prayers. Many protesters were arrested or injured by security forces.
First outbreak of demonstrations was reported in Wad Nubawi Mosque in Khartoums sister-city of Omdurman - reports of protests elswhere, include in Ombada area.
Activists are also reporting that demonstrations erupted following Friday prayer in the central market in Kassala town in the eastern region as well as in Al-Obayid town in North Kordofan State.
Protests erupted in Khartoum North town known as Bahri, where activists say police and security agents are firing heavy teargas and arresting protesters.

Armed security agents on Friday raided the AFP bureau in Khartoum and arrested a correspondent who had taken pictures of the protests. Two agents from the National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS), one of them wielding a pistol seized the journalist and kept him in custody for more than 12 hours without charge.

First outbreak of demonstrations was reported in Wad Nubawi Mosque in Khartoums sister-city of Omdurman where around 300 protesters including members of the Ansar sect of the opposition National Umma Party (NUP) started chanting slogans calling for the downfall of the government as soon as the prayer ended. Teargas and rubber bullets used to disperse crowds.
In Al Nuhud security forces arrested more than 20 protesters after Friday prayers. The protesters were beaten and chased by the security forces.

In Wad Medani the protests had started on Thursday evening and continued after Friday prayers. The people were chanting and calling for the fall of the regime. Police and security forces stopped the protesters and managed to disperse the crowds. A female activists told Radio Dabanga that four demonstrators were arrested

column7: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; Students (Sudan)
column17: Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) announced it support to the peaceful protests in Sudan calling for the downfall of the regime of the National Congress Party (NCP). What was a protest by universities students in Khartoum against the cut of oil subsidies has become, day after day, a national movement demanding a regime change in Sudan.

The Sudanese Air Force (SAF) bombed the area of East Jebel Marra, including the towns of Abu Hamra, Dabaneira in the South Darfur state. An eyewitness told Radio Dabanga that the SAF have dropped five to ten bombs per day for seven consecutive days now.

A group of armed men, sympathetic to the government in Khartoum, intercepted a commercial vehicle in north Kabkabiya, North Darfur. column17: The dead body of Mustafa Mohamed Isa was found after he was kidnapped last week by a pro-government paramilitary group.

Now into its fourth week, ordinary citizens tired of deteriorating conditions in their country are taking to the streets alongside students, members of youth movements and opposition parties, and civil society activists, to chant against the government. The largest protests often begin from mosques after Friday prayers, with each weeks demonstration accorded a different theme. Past Fridays have been labelled Sandstorm Friday, Elbow Licking Friday (in reference to a remark by one of Al-Bashirs advisors that those who want to overthrow regime have a better chance of licking their elbows) and Outcasts Friday (referring to Al-Bashirs recent speech in which he called protesters outcasts). Todays, planned as Kandaka Friday, is dedicated to the revolutionary women of Sudan.

Sudanese army and rebel groups in South Kordofan state and Darfur region confirmed clashes in the two regions but they delivered different accounts about the outcome of the fight... Al-Sawarmi Khalid, Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) spokesperson said in a statement released in Friday that government troops killed some 77 rebels in clashes with the SPLM-N and Darfur rebel groups. The military spokesperson said the army repulsed a SPLM-N attack on the village of Hagar Al-Dom 30 kilometers northeast Kallugi, South Kordofan on Thursday. He added that 45 rebels were killed during the fight and accused the assailant force of killing 21 civilians.

Sudanese army and rebel groups in South Kordofan state and Darfur region confirmed clashes in the two regions but they delivered different accounts about the outcome of the fight... Also the rebel Justice and Equality Movement reported Friday clashes between the army and a joint rebel force from JEM-and SLM-AW fighters in South Darfur.
